tablet_galaxy_tab|I've had the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 for a couple of weeks now and loved it from day one. I considered the iPad, but don't use an Apple (except iPod) for anything else because of the nature of my work. I've used the iPad 2 and iPad 3 owned by a relative and found it overpriced for something that's more like a toy and isn't that practical. The iPad is also embarrassingly large (it's funny watching people with these large tablets in airports). I wanted something smaller and more practical that would be compatible with the work I do every day, and the Galaxy Tab definitely fits the bill. I'm not sure I'd find the iPad mini much better.The only glitch I had was that I had to restart my router on the second day so that my wifi connection would remain stable. Haven't had any problems since. I like the fact that I can check e-mail from my own server, download, view and edit/create MS Office documents using free software, read Kindle and ePub content using free apps, organize music, books, photos, etc. into various folders on the external SD card and surf the Web easily with Chrome or the default browser. I rarely use my laptop or computer for simple tasks anymore, unless I have to use proprietary software for my work. This handy device will be great on flights. Say goodbye to paid carry-ons and hello to free personal items! :o)The system updates to 4.04, which seems to work pretty well, but I preferred the keyboard on the 4.01 version. Some people recommend the Hacker's Keyboard, but if you use one like that, beware that some data (such as credit card numbers) can be transmitted to the keyboard designer. Of course, I don't plan to make any purchases using the Tab, but it's something to think about. I initially added the German keyboard to the default US keyboard (not Hacker's version), but found it a real pain because every time I tapped the spacebar it switched keyboards instead of adding a space, so I removed it. I also turned off the autocomplete feature because it is more of a pain than helpful. Google's voice recognition is a great feature in lieu of typing, but you have to have an online connection to use it.Battery life can be extended using airplane mode and keeping the brightness setting down. I don't care for the glossy screen, so I'm getting a non-glare screen protector. Streaming Netflix and YouTube works well. I'm looking forward to trying Skype and/or Google Voice on it. Before I bought it, I wasn't sure if I would use it much, but now that I have it, I don't think I'd want to part with it.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|We were told about the Samsung by a friend and we were looking for one for our 13 year old daughter. This has been perfect for her!!
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|I love it soooo much, I have been going to bed two hours later than I should every night 'cause I'm having so much fun with it. It plays every video format I have thrown at it including .MKV--on the app that comes with the device. I've put magazines and books from the library on it. I still prefer the real thing, but I do like knowing that there are 14 magazines and six books in my purse at any given moment should I find myself in need of distraction/time-killing. It does suck that it doesn't come with a manual, but nothing really does any more. I keep wondering what I am missing out on, but what I've figured out so far has been pretty great.Now I come to the reason for leaving a review. When you're looking to buy this, you might do what I did and get a 32GB micro card, a multi-format adapter, and the best case for how the tablet will be used. By all means, do just that. I did, and I don't regret it. There is one more thing to do.******BE SURE TO BUY AN ADDITIONAL DATA/SYNC CABLE!!******Seriously, get one now!! When you need one due to loss, damage, or accidentally leaving it at work over the weekend (as I have), you WILL NOT be able to readily buy one. Target doesn't have them. WalMart doesn't have them. Radio Shack will tell you when you call that they do have them, but when you arrive to purchase, you'll discover the kid on the phone had no idea what he was talking about. Then you'll remember seeing a Sprint commercial for this device, and will go there. You will point to the cable on the display tablet and tell the really nice guy trying to help you, "I need a data cable." He'll stop cold and say, "I don't think we have those." And they don't. Honestly, if the one on their display model goes out, they will have to order one from Samsung (or Amazon, of course) If you're lucky the really nice guy at Sprint will offer to lend you his for the evening. (Just throwing that in 'cause I thought it was waaay cool) You will eventually find one at the Verizon store several miles up the road. They want 30 bucks for it.So to ensure the fun continues and doesn't spiral into a weekend filled with despair, angst, and price gauging, GET ANOTHER DATA CABLE NOW!!As I am writing this, they are available on this site for less than six bucks.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|The Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 (which is what I'm using to write this review) is pretty slick. Though the screen resolution isn't ideal, Samsung certainly made up for it with the sheer quality of the screen. Size and weight are perfect; not too big to be unwieldy, but big enough to be useful for getting things done (unlike my smartphone, a Samsung Epic 4G Touch).The only downside I had was with Samsung's version of Android (with TouchWiz); the stock firmware leaves a lot to be desired in terms of performance. However, a good hour or so of flashing ClockworkMod and CyanogenMod 10.1 + GAPPS fixed the tablet right up.Now I just need a screen protector, case, and keyboard, and I'll be all set.

tablet_galaxy_tab|This is my first tablet device. I wanted something affordable (but not from some unheard-of mystery manufacturer) and this seemed ideal. At the current Amazon price ($180) I think you'd be hard pressed to find anything better. For that kind of money I wouldn't lose too much sleep if something awful happened to it...I'd just buy a new one! It might not be as high-spec as a $500 device, but it does the job. Minor complaint is that the cord on the charger is a little short, which is a pain if the battery's dead and you need to use it while charging. My only other gripe is that a lot of TV streaming services work only in "landscape" format, with the tablet held horizontally, but the speakers are on the bottom edge, so stereo is impossible! The sound all comes out of the right hand side!! I'm sure this probably applies to most (perhaps even all) tablets, but it's a really dumb design mistake in my opinion. On a similar note, it would make sense to have the volume control reversed when using it horizontally...so that you press the left hand side to lower the volume, right hand side to raise it. Maybe someone at Samsung will read this review and take note! :-)
---

Maybe I just got a bad one. Might be something you want to check out before you buy. Amazon was great about returning the purchase.

I may say it a great tablet for such a low price.SOUND.It has its own speakers, wich are actually grat, but whe holding horizontal, you them with the hands.CAMERA- no flash.The rear camera is only 3mp but it takes quite good pictures, though It would have been nicer if it had at least LED flash.PERFORMANCE.This tab offers a great performance, with its 1ghz processor allows you to run some of the best apps and games, though it lacks of Flash Player support, there are many tricks you can make to have Flash.SCREEN.The screen resolution is quite good, you can play HD videos, and its colors are brilliant. I LOVE IT.APPS.It runs all the Google Play apps plus the Samsung Media Hub wich allows you to watch your favorite series for free.BATTERY PERFORMANCE.The battery performance is up to 4 and a half hours, though it charges very fast (half an hour i got 75% charged.CONS. It wont charge when plugged in to a computer.In the box: Tablet, USB Cable, and the USB AC Adapter for Charging.I will recomend to buy this tablet with a Crazy On Leather Case Bundle (Great Quality for such low price), and you should get an 32GB microSD.You wont regret buying it!

Extra! : I'm editing this review to say that I found that you can get Adobe Flash by going to the bottom of the product's page here on Amazon to the customer questions section. WJ had the answer that worked for me. Here it is copied and pasted."Go to the Adobe Flash Archives:Before going to the link below make sure you go to setting, security and select or check the "unknown sources" box.[...]Scroll down and find "Flash Player for Android 4.0 archives"DownloadHope this is helpful :)WJ answered on January 1, 2013"

tablet_galaxy_tab|I have owned this tablet for several weeks and am very impressed. It is quick and the screen is very bright and clear. Battery life is excellent. The features work as advertised and it is a high quality unit. That said I ordered the Nexus 7 - in spite of the lack of SD slot. These are the reasons. I personally hate the 30 pin adapter that is needed to charge the unit. Maybe we will get HDMI from it - if Samsung ever released an adapter that will work with it. But at this point it is simply a more complicated and fragile charging/USB port and if I lose it I am SOL. Nexus 7 wisely uses standard micro USB. Next - the screen resolution on the Samsung means that you often have to move web pages sideways to activate buttons as so many sites are designed 1280 pixels wide. The Nexus 7 has 1280 resolution. It is aggravating to have to move your pages around to locate buttons. As far as storage I will buy one of those new wireless portable hard drives. Bottom line is the Samsung is GREAT, but for my needs the Nexus looks better.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|Google announced Nexus 7 a couple of days after i had purchased this tablet. I was regretful initially until i did some research. A couple of reasons why Galaxy Tab 2 is still a better value for me. Nexus does not have a back camera. I would like the option of being able to snap a photo or video once in a while with this tab. Second the Nexus does not have an expandable memory slot. So no slot of a Micro SD card. If you buy 8GB tablet you cannot increase the memory. I have already expanded the memory of my Galaxy Tab with 16GB Micro SD card and i think i will need the extra memory. The Google website is also charging sales tax depending on the state in the shipping address. For the time being i am quite satisfied with my purchase.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I bought myself an iPad for christmas, and kept it for 3 weeks before sending it back. it was frankly not as much fun as I thought, too wide and bulky to be easily read/keep out of the way at a cafe, and in it's solar case almost as heavy as my netbook I was replacing.I needed a device that could be tethered, would be able work with dropbox and gmail as well as take decent pictures. This one does everything the iPad does, at a third the price and still has a super sharp screen and a whole lot more control. Fuctionality wise it's been easier to customize and is better suited for people who need to produce rather than consume.Working with video editing apps has been a ton easier than iPad ever was. Kindle always works smoothly. wiFi connection never kicks me off. I'm very very happy with it, most of all the size is much better suited to someone like me who has small hands. the iPad was just too big and bulky to be worth the effort.Plus, in a simple leather case, this looks like a day planner, where as a 10" tablet looks like a 10" tablet, and makes you more noticiable to those around you. This one gets no stares, and I love that.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I am a professional piano tuner/technician and I wanted something to be my "administrative assistant" as well as a tool in my toolbox. As a tuner I use specialized analysis software to verify my work and needed something portable. I got that and more. Not only can I use my software with this, but I can even use it as an accurate a440 tuning fork, if needed.When two of my children's offbrand tablets malfunctioned within the warranty period and that other manufacturer wouldnt even answer the phone, we bought two more of these samsung units to replace the offbrand units. The children love them.We use them for e-readers, using kindle app, fbreader and adobe reader. We use them for offline gps with gps copilot. We use them for educational purposes with multiple language and drawing apps. I use mine for work both as a toolset and administrative assistant.The biggest drawbacks we have found so far, other than having to use power save mode all the time and gps causing fast power drain without external power, come from android 4.1.1 and are generic to all units running this release, but are only minor issues. IIRC, samsung has already released 4.1.2 in several countries but continues to hold north america to older software. Android no longer allows for the moving of apps to the expansion card via settings and app developers have yet to "pick up the slack." On apps that can be manually modified to do so, config files have to be found and corrected and relevant folders have to be manually moved. This isnt something the average user wants to be bothered with. Jelly bean 4.1.1 seems to want to reboot on rare occasions that appear to be with moving large quantities of files, and it is difficult to remove bloatware, requiring a 3rd party app that can perform "rooted" tasks or can bypass that need. One samsung specific quirk that I don't like is the proprietary usb connection on the device. If the usb cable messes up, it will be a pain to replace it. This also limits connectability flexibility when trying to connect to devices with a micro usb slot.Pros:Dual cure processor, 1gb ram, 32gb expansionLightning fast gps tracking, bluetooth, wifiE-reader compact sizeFunctional flexibiliyEconomical priceCons:Must be run in power save mode AND airplanemode for optimal battery performanceEven with external power, the gps function will slowly drain power.Android 4.1.1 specific glitches and bloatware.Proprietary usb slot on deviceStorage limits for the technically illiterate.Summary:Great unit with just a few drawbacks that can be worked around. Biggest drawbacks are usb slot/cable, battery consumption when using gps or communications features and issues specific to android 4.1.1 that will hopefully be fixed with the eventual update. But if you tend to download a lot of apps and dont want to be bothered with manually configuring them to use the expansion sd card, then you may want a different unit with 64gb of internal storage instead. However, if this unit withstands the test of time then I will be extremely pleased.

tablet_galaxy_tab|Recently there was an article in the "New York Times" cautioning buyers of tablets to try them in the store "hands on" before making a decision. When purchasing my Galaxy Tab 2 I didn't. I also was not paying much attention to its features (or lack thereof). Here is what I have learned after three month's use.This is my first tablet and for the most part I think it is terrific. Because I have an aversion to Apple's business model and because I have found that the many Samsung products I own are of excellent quality, the Tab 2 was my obvious choice. In addition I have three year's experience with the Android OS and expected the learning curve to be substantially shorter. It was. The 7" screen is the perfect size. I can't imagine how I would navigate the 10".What I wish I had been paying attention to are:1) This tablet was engineered for right handed people. This makes perfect sense since most of the world is right handed. Unfortunately I am not.2) There is noSamsung Galaxy Tab 2 (7-Inch, Wi-Fi) flash which means that for all practical purposes snaps are limited to those taken in bright light. Goodness knows there is plenty of room on the back of the unit for a flash.3) The buttons on the right side are a design disaster. The top one turns the screen or the tablet on and off. Right below it is a rocker switch to control the volume. Their feel to the touch is exactly the same. Good luck on being able to tell instantaneously which switch your finger is touching. The obvious answer would have been to put the On/Off switch on the top of the tablet.4) The socket for connecting the tablet to the world or the charger is on the bottom. If you plan on lying in bed with the tablet in the vertical position resting on your belly it can't be done without seriously bending the cable. There seems to be plenty of room on the left side of the tablet.I purchased the Samsung 2 7" Wifi Tablet in November. I am reasonably happy with my $199 purchase. Because there are now so many choices at the lower end of the price range it means that it is going to be more difficult to give them a hands on try. That being the case, make very sure you can return your purchase if you try it out and are disappointed.Good luck - but caveat emptor.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|My first tablet was Acer A500 10 inch tablet. It still runs well but I'm starting to find the weight was starting to bother my wrist after extended use. I have checked several 7 inch tablet models (Apple, Nexus 7, IBM etc.,) and decided to take chance on Samsung 7 inch tablet. Because several early reviewers have posted issue with battery/charge problems, I have hedged my bet by ordering from Costco due to its very generous return policy of 90 days.As tablet goes, set-ups are pretty straight forward, I activated Google and Samsung accounts and the tablet was set to go. As others have already noted, this tablet comes with paltry 8GB of internal memories with half of it already taken over by bloatware. It can however, take 32GB micro-SD card so that helps to store your video, e-books any download you will inevitably do.Some reviewers have complained of having issues with wi-fi connectivity depending on how you hold the tablet. I have had no problems here. Signal reception was excellent both at free wi-fi spot at Kaiser Hospital and my home wi-fi network.Anyone who have owned android smartphone and tablets should have no problems playing around with this toy. The screen is veritable fingerprint magnet so I have ordered screen protectors which I will apply as soon as it arrives.If you try to read in bright sunlight....well, good luck. But indoor, it is pleasure to use. It may not have the best screen but I found it more than adequate when compared to my old Acer 10 inch.Battey life is not the best. If you do not have power-saving features on and you have wi-fi enabled, you can almost see the battery drain noticeably.In closing, I picked Samsung 7 inch Galaxy Tablet 2 for its low price, ability to accept external memory card, decent screen and light weight. I am not a power gamer so not having the latest CPU is not an issue for me.If I have issue with battery/charge down the road, then I will do an update.UPDATE: 03/05/13I've noticed that on some website, Samsung installed browser may give you problem with accessing. If so, install another browser like Opera portable and access problem will go away.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I was a little nervous about this tablet only because of the Nexus also being out and seeming like a better deal in many respects. The reason I mention this is because it gets rid of my need for other device and remotes as long as I have my Galaxy Tab 2 with me (which of course I do).Tablet is very solid, and feels well put together, not plastic-y or cheap build.Cons: Battery life is ok, 7 hours or so I think, this could be better, and I am really not a fan of proprietary connectors, I wish they would stick with Micro USB etc.

tablet_galaxy_tab|To be fair, this is my first tablet purchase so my review is not relative to any other tablet options. However, I do consider myself a tech junkie and did a good bit of research before my purchase.My motivation for buying a tablet was to make my job easier. I'm an outside sales representative and meet with many clients in their homes or businesses. I needed a tablet that had a rear facing camera, expandable storage, and blue tooth capabilities.I thought I had found the perfect tablet, and had until I tried to print. When I'm meeting with clients, I need to print contracts, product literature, financial information, etc. Normally, I do this from my laptop to my blue tooth portable printer.However, carrying a laptop can be cumbersome and time consuming to set up. The Galaxy Tab 2 was the perfect solution, except that you can only print to a Samsung printer! Yes, there are apps that allows you to print to other printers, but only via wifi. Blue tooth printing, however, is limited to Samsung only.I realize my application is very specific, and not likely to be an issue to many others. So, to be fair, it seems to accomplish other tasks admirably. My daughter plays games on it. I've watched a few YouTube videos and music sounds great through the speakers.So, all in all, a good tablet but the printing limitations are a deal-breaker for me.*** Edited Review - a follow-up comment to my review suggested an app that may work for Bluetooth printing. IT WORKED!! I'm beyond relieved that this tablet will do the job. I'm changing my review to 5 stars. At this price point, and with the ability to run my business through this tablet, there's nothing more I could ask for.

tablet_galaxy_tab|The unit has so far has impressed me. I am not a standard (regular tablet user.) It was purchased for my daughter in Mid November for a Xmas present. So I had it a while. I did not play with it much at first because I didn't want to drop it while it was not protected. Once in the protective cover, I had a chance to use most of the neat features of the unit. I have not tested the video quality yet.Pros:In comparison with the iPad, I find it quite useful if not more so. For one thing I was able to get it to print to my Epson R2000 since it was on my network. This is likely something the iPad can do but I have not really looked that hard either. The network connection seems to hold very well. I was even able to do limited network intensive operation while tethering to my BB on bluetooth. The mapping program works great, even on BT. The camera takes really good pics, much better than the iPad ver. 2. The movement around the screen was just as fluid as the iPad's. As far as loading apps, that was relatively painless with Google play, I can even send apps to the unit while logged into my google account. That is a huge plus, since I am not the primary user of it. The battery life seems to be on par with what to expect from devices such as these. With about 8 hours daily use it would be good to plug it in for the night for an overnight charge. One of the biggest pros to me is the remote app that you can use to program all your devices in your home (bye bye Harmony!)Cons:The only thing I can think of is the fact that the antenna is not that strong. I was in a hotel and easily picked up the wireless with my laptop. With this unit it seemed a bit more difficult. This seems to be a problem with many tablet devices. But while in my home it does just fine.Conclusion:Pound for pound this unit will hold it own with the iPad ver 2. But with the cost in the equation, this wins out big. Especially with the remote app. Now I just have to figure out away to get it from my daughter. ;)Also, nothing gets 5 stars from me...

I would say the one downside is the backside is smooth and doesn't provide much grip, so the right type of case may be necessary for some. I do not play resource-hogging games, so I can't speak for the performance of those apps, but as for the email app, web browser, and Kindle app (the 3 apps I use the most), the performance is excellent. I would consider this more of a productivity tablet and less of a gaming tablet, but if that's the type of tablet you need, this is the perfect balance of price, features, and performance.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I was loving this device until this past week. I was using it primarily as an eReader and was thrilled with it. This past week it began shutting off while in use, and it would not restart after a shutdown. I can plug it into the charger for approximately 24 hours and it will then usually restart. On this last incident it refuses to restart after several days on the charger.Since I still have my Amazon receipt, the box, and all materials I thought it would be no big deal; I'd just send it back to Samsung for repair. No such luck, Samsung tells me that my serial number is not valid. That's real funny, 'cause it's the same serial number I input when I registered the tablet on their site. At that time the serial number was valid and they even provided the manufacture date of the device.I'm not at all pleased with having a $250.00 paperweight or with getting the shaft from Samsung. I wasn't particularly upset with the problem with the device, things happen and electronic devices fail at times. What I cannot tolerate is a company that ignores their customers. I'm finished with Samsung products.-----In the interest of honesty and full disclosure I must update my review. Since my initial posting I was able to make contact with a Samsung customer service rep via online chat. I was finally able to convince them that my tablet was dead, and get return authorization. They emailed a UPS shipping label and my device went out this afternoon. I will update this review after my (or a replacment device) is returned.I have upgraded my opinion of the device and Samsung by one star. I still love the device, but I am troubled by the failure of it after only two months. I've read numerous other reviews by users who state that they have the same problem.I'll update my review when I see how this situation plays out.--------------Now, nearly three weeks after I sent my device in to Samsung for repair, I find out that my device will not be repaired. My device will be exchanged; apparently there would be a long delay waiting for parts to repair my device. I've spoken with a few very nice ladies at Samsung this evening. They're all pleasant, all very apologetic, and can't really give me a definitive answer on when I'll receive a replacement device. The third young lady I spoke with this evening was very pleasant, very professional, and did seem interested in trying to find answers for me...unfortunately it seems that another department has to call me to discuss the exchange of my device. When will they call me? Nobody knows.I was told that it should take another 11-12 days for the process to be completed. I'm just having a hard time understanding how, 3-4 days after you've determined that you cannot repair a customer's device and you're going to exchange it, how can it take nearly two more weeks to resolve this? I could understand a situation like this if I had an older unit, out of warranty, and they were doing me a favor. How can you drag out the repair or replacement of a new unit and call that customer service? How can you drag a customer through so much bureaucracy and expect that they'll be a happy customer and want to continue to purchase your products?I suppose my review has turned into a review of Samsung's customer service instead of a review of the Galaxy Tab 2, though Samsung's performance directly affects my opinion of the Galaxy Tab 2.Samsung does not seem to be a customer oriented company, instead it gives the impression of a government bureaucracy where no one seems to have a definitive answer and the solution to your problem is always one call transfer away. I LOVED the Galaxy Tab 2 while I had it, but the Samsung experience leaves much to be desired.Enjoy your Galaxy Tab folks and I wish you the best of luck. I think I'm giving up on this adventure and going to another brand.

tablet_galaxy_tab|Love the tablet, it works great. There isn't a horrible amount of bloatware installed (netflix, samsung store, and a few others).There are a few things that irritate me though. First, samsung uses a proprietary usb connection interface where a simple micro usb would have sufficed. Their "kies" usb transfer does not have linux support, and the device does not support "mass storage" mode, only MTP and PTP protocols which mount the device for media transfer or as a camera.For transferring data to the device, I have had some luck using sshDroid, but this does not consistently work, especially on local area networks, even with port forwarding. Kies Air did not work well with the Ubuntu system and kept giving transfer errors on large media files like movies. A good cloud service might be helpful (I'm using MS skydrive and google music). It seems like the best option may be to just use a micro sd card usb adapter to add content and insert it into the tablet.

To be honest I never wanted to upgrade a perfectly working tablet. This type of things makes me stay away from these companies. tablet_galaxy_tab|Amongst my family members, we have the ipad mini(which I own), nexus 7, and galaxy tab 2. Though not mine, I would rate the Samsung as the best deal. It's by far better than expected. Very Apple-like with respect to function and aesthetics. I use Macs and the transition to the Tab 2 would be easy-- more so than going from a Mac to a PC. I like the keypad feature with numbers across the top of the letters, which means you don't have to shift to access numbers. The word suggestion feature includes several possible words and is displayed in a row above the keypad. I find this much more comfortable to use than a pop up suggestion box. The screen is clear and colorful, similar to the ipad mini, and doesn't have the dull resolution of the Nexus 7. The Tab 2 also includes a document and spreadsheet app which is it's own version of word/excel. The sound quality of music played is not as high as my mini. Out of the three small tablets, I would recommend both the Samsung and Apple, as both are similar in quality and function. The Nexus 7 would rank in a below category-- not worth it's full price, and the quality does not attain the level of the other two. This device has changed my view of Samsung products for the good.

tablet_galaxy_tab|This device has an amazing feature set for the price point. I own the iPad 1 and the current iPad, and my beefs with them are lack of expandable memory and no flash. This little device has both, although you must download the flash app from the google store first for it to work. The IR blaster set up easily with my Sony TV, and I love the TV guide that is in the Peer app. The Kindle app gives a very clear text display. There is photo editing and even a cute little movie making app on here! Polaris office is good. I love the keyboard because the numbers are set above the letters like a regular keyboard. Dictation works great. No problems with WIFI here. My only disappointment is that the screen display lacks the vibrant color of other Samsung devices, but some people might prefer that. The display is adequate for most purposes, and you can set the font size to large, which helps with text. Pinch and zoom is smooth. The only app I find unacceptable is Facebook for Android. The text is very small and fixed. You cannot zoom it, so I can read it easier on my phone than on here. It looks better by going through the web browser, but still won't zoom. Other web pages are easily enlarged. There is a slight lag sometimes while scrolling, but you can open multiple pages with tabs, which the original iPad lacks. The speakers and volume are better than you will find in most laptops and netbooks and other tablets. Screenshots are so easily done that you have to be a little careful not to hit that button accidentally. If you install the "active applications" or program monitor widget, you can monitor what is open, and shut apps down periodically to save battery. Bluetooth works great, and will accept my Apple devices, but the Apple devices won't accept my Samsung devices. Unfortunately, it's my understanding that the adapter to load pictures from an SD card does not work with this device. I got the sleeve for the 7.0 and it fits well and doesn't add a lot of bulk. I just wanted something to protect it when I threw it in my purse. For me personally, I prefer the8.9 size and screen, but it costs more and does not have expandable memory.6/8/12 New feature! Now Bright House Digital Cable has added the ability for certain android devices to watch TV (as long as you are in your own house), and it works perfectly on this device. That's another bonus, because cable does not work on all tabs.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I have just spent over 2 hours with Samsung customer service. tablet_galaxy_tab|Let me first say that I am no stranger to the tablet market. I started with the iPad 2 but then moved over to the 7" tablet form factor because I found that size to ultimately be more suited to my needs.I'm a big fan of Samsung products anyway (already have one of their phones) and so I started to dabble with their 7" tablets, starting with the gTab 7.0 plus. I liked it, but I wasn't wild about it, so I ended up selling it.Next I tried the gTab 7.7 from Verizon and, while it had an awesome screen and it blazed on 4g, I found that many apps didn't account for the additional screen size and so fonts were disproportionately small a lot of the time...not to mention that the 2 year commitment and initial price (despite being subsidized through the carrier) gave me more than one restless night's sleep, so ultimately - given that for the monthly and up front cost, it wasn't rolling my socks up and down - it went back.Enter the gTab 2 7" tablet. This one has proven to be the Goldilocks tablet for me...just right.First of all, it runs ICS which (IMHO) makes a huge difference in the user experience on a tablet over Gingerbread. Perhaps just because I am used to ICS from my Nexus phone, but I found this tablet iteration to be the most pleasant to use out of all of them.Obviously the gTab 2 7" can't out-spec the 7.7, but having had a 7.0 Plus, I can honestly say the differences are negligible. Is the Plus faster? Yes, a bit...but it was (at the time) also $399 to the tab 2's $249.I carry this Tab with me daily in my purse. It is solid enough to feel good in the hand, but still light enough not to make having it in my bag or holding it up for long periods of reading a burden. The screen may only be 170 ppi, and only 1024 x 600 resolution, but to be honest, it looks great just the same. I stream Netflix on it as well as play movies from an SD card and in my opinion it is a very good video watching experience.The cameras are only meh, but I have Skyped on it and it does fine. There were no complaints on either end as to quality.For the most part, I use my Tab as a consumption device; I watch movies, browse news aggregating apps like Pulse, read books (and for $249 I can have both my Kindle books and my Nook books with me on one device...sweet!), stream music, spend time on social media and waste my life playing Draw Something. I do appreciate the larger screen for managing my calendar and I have had occasion to do actual work on the thing too (though not often), which has been a good experience as well. In other words, I am not what you would call a power user - I am just your average consumer looking for a good product at a decent price point.Personally, I just love it. I think the price is right for what it is, and I really like that (as opposed to the Kindle Fire and Nook Tablet - both of which are good devices, don't get me wrong) I can have an honest to goodness Android experience with the Google Play Store, etc.Did Samsung need to put out yet another Galaxy Tab model? Probably not...but I have to say, owning this one, that I'm glad they did.

tablet_galaxy_tab|Samsung is a force to be reckoned with in the android market. I have purchased a Nexus 7 which has a much smoother user experience, and a beautiful design, but it does not beat the Samsung Tab 2 7 and here is why:1. The Samsung device allows for removable sd cards. This takes away all of the storage issues that tablets have. I have a bunch of digital videos and music that I can watch or listen to just by swapping out micro SD cards. Granted Samsung should have given the device 16GB of internal stroage instead of 8GB, but the micro SD cards make this a non issue.2. Unlike the other 7&#34; android tablets like the Nexus and the Kindle this has a camera on the back which allows you to take decent videos and pictures. The picture quality is pretty good, but not great (I consider my iPhone 4 great in this area). It makes the tablet a very handy device for when you are traveling and want to take pictures and videos. I use it to shoot videos for my children when I am in Europe on business trips. This feature piggy backs on reason 1 listed above becasue you can save your video and pictures directly to the micro SD card.3. It has excellent video playback, gaming and web surfing.4. You can use it as a remote control for your TV and Cable Box. I can not tell you how liberating it is not to have to look for a remote control.The only thing that the device is missing is an mini hdmi out, and the reading experience could be a bit better. If you are buying a 7&#34; tablet to primarily read e-books then go with the Kindle Fire HD 7&#34;, but if you want a full fledged device with full access to the android ecosystem then go with the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7&#34;. The Nexus 7 has a cleaner design, and much better user experience (swiping is effortless) but they hobbled the device by copying the iPhone model of not allowing for external storage, yeah... yeah.... yeah I know about USB OTG, but it too clunky to have something sticking out the bottom of such a small tablet.The bottom line is that this is the best value in 7&#34; tablets!

tablet_galaxy_tab|I'm going to try to make this concise and hit the major points, so it will help all you tablet-seekers make an informed decision before you finish your x-mas shopping.About me: 30s, non-technie, don't care one way or the other about gadgets. I do have an iPod touch, which I love, but the screen is simply too small for me to do a lot of things I wanted to do with the tablet.What I use the Galaxy Tab for: E-mails while traveling, Netflix, e-books/audio books, apps.Since I've never had a tablet before, some of these things may be typical of all tablets or unique to the Samsung. In any event, here are my pros and cons:Pros:+Vibrant screen, easy to watch movies, read, and use apps+Touch is, for the most part very responsive (see my comment below)+Easy to navigate the unit despite never using an Android device before+Battery life is impressive, even after watching movies or reading for several hours+Easy to get accessories for (case/stand/usb keyboard)+Optional 32G SD card, which you pop right in and forget about+Price: with the exception of all of the additions you will need (case, memory card, extra charger, etc.) it cost the same as my iPod touch with much more functionality/features+Weight: perfect for travel, lightweight yet sturdy (I even take it to the gym and use it on the elliptical machine)+GPS!Cons:-The WiFi signal seems inconsistent. Not that it's bad, but hovers around average, even if I'm near my router-Links on the internet are sometimes not responsive to touch. Not sure if that is the browser or the websites themselves-Netflix can be laggy, especially when it buffers-This is a major one for me...the volume rocker and the power button are nearly on top of each other. I'm not very tactile so almost every time I go to adjust the volume I inadvertently turn the screen off. Really annoying but I'm sure I'll get the hang of it-Android apps require a ton of permissions. As in, they basically tell you how they are going to invade your privacy. Maybe iOS apps do this too and they just don't tell you. I also don't like that a lot of apps require full-time access to the internetIn sum: for the difference in price I would definitely choose this tablet over a knock-off in the $100 range. it is a user-friendly, fully-functional, and handy accessory for travel or anyone "on the go". The only thing I would consider upgrading is possibly to a bigger screen, but then you sacrifice weight and portability factors.Happy holidays!

tablet_galaxy_tab|When I finally decided to buy a tablet, I literally spent days researching everything that was out there. For the price and features, the absolutely best deal is the Kindle Fire HD 7", which I bought and love. Unfortunately, the Kindle does not have Adobe Flash Player and it cannot be installed on the Kindle. Since one of the primary reasons I wanted a tablet was to access websites that require Adobe Flash Player, I found the need to purchase another tablet. From my previous research, the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 had been my second choice, again for the price and features it offered. The Galaxy Tab is exactly what I needed and performs flawlessly! I love this tablet and recommend it for anyone who wants a small tablet that can do just about anything you want it to. The price is excellent and the compact size makes it extremely versatile. I can take it anywhere as it fits very nicely in my purse, even with the case on it.Additionally, for those who need a tablet with Adobe Flash Player, this is the only tablet on the market that comes pre-loaded with AFP. As of 08/15/12, Adobe is no longer producing AFP for Android systems and it is not available to download. So, if you do not have it pre-loaded you will not be able to get it. This may or may not be of consequence to you, but if it is then please take advantage of the days I spent researching all of this information. For more information, please follow this link: [...] OR do a search for Adobe Flash Player for Android and choose the "Android's Flash Player is dead - live with it|ZDNet published on August 15, 2012 by David Meyer.The Galaxy Tab is the only tablet in the $200 to $250 price range that has AFP. I did not research the higher-end tablets since I had decided this was the maximum I was willing to spend. I also did not research the lower-end tablets, under $150, as the majority of them have older operating systems like 2.2 or 2.3 and are only 4GB. Technology continues to change too fast to spend any more money, in my opinion, as it will be obsolete in a very short period of time.In closing, the Samsung Galaxy Tab is an awesome little piece of technology that I am sure you will thoroughly enjoy owning.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I'm an Android fan from way back, and picking this up from Amazon for a Father's Day self-gift was easy. Amazon had it to me in two days and I charged it for a couple of hours before turning it on and setting it up. Sure, I was stepping up to the Ice Cream Sandwich operating system from Gingerbread on my Droid phone, but that shouldn't be much of a switch, right?Wrong! I've been pounding on keyboards and phones for a long time, but my first 15 minutes on the Galaxy Tab 2 was not as simple as I thought it would be. I couldn't quite figure out the icons for moving around and my Gmail account did not get setup correctly. I contacted Samsung's online Support chat function and they were nearly worthless. They told me to click on options that didn't exist, so I had the Tab back in the box, ready to ship back to Amazon.Well, I gave the Tab another chance, wiped the deck clean (I reset the device to its original out-of-the-box state) and started over. The second time was the charm. My Gmail account was setup just fine (I use Google's Authentication function on my Google accounts, so that may have affected my first attempt) and the Tab has shined brightly ever since. The device is a quality build, a perfect size and integrates with my Google applications very nicely. Netflix runs my movie selections flawlessly and the battery seems to last a long time between charges. For $249, it is a steal. I toyed with the original Amazon Kindle Fire when it came out, but it is very limited in comparison with the Tab 2. If you want a really good reader and Amazon store browser, the Kindle Fire is a great tablet for those things. If you want to pay 25% more, but end up with a tablet that can do a lot more online and with Google Play Store applications, the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 is your next tablet computer.Positives:High quality build - it feels like a well designed tablet in your handGreat size - if you want a screen bigger than your phone, but small enough to read a book upon, the seven inch tablet form factor is great. The iPad is waaaaaay too big and clunky for causal reading.Fast - screen switching from landscape to portrait is 'right there'. Moving among screens is smooth and quick.Display - gorgeous. Vibrant colors, natural and realistic.Open - you can sideload apps (get them from non-google and non-Amazon sources) and the machine is not just an Amazon tool.Expandable - you can add a microSD card to this to expand your storage, add movies, music, etc.Keyboard - nice size and quite accurate. (If you've typed on a smartphone, you know how challenging it can be to keystroke accurately.)Negatives:Sound - there seems to be just one speaker, at the bottom. It is easy, while watching Netflix, to cover it with your hand. The sound is ok, but won't win any awards for faithful reproduction of low notes.Samsung support - they don't make it easy and their techs don't seem to know this new product very well yet. Phone support would be helpful, but Samsung uses a very slow paced chat service where you type in your questions and the tech takes FOREVER to respond. (But don't take long, yourself, to respond to them, or they'll terminate the chat!)

tablet_galaxy_tab|This tablet is not meant to compete with iPad 2 or 3, any of the high end android tablets like the Asus prime. This is in the medium budget category and it packs in a whole bunch of value for your money, even more than high end tablets in some cases.Pros:Android OS (you have a lot more customization, widgets, full web, easier to download and move files unlike the walled garden that is iOS)Screen (not the best, but no light bleed on my unit, and it doesn't have the diamond shape when you look closely at it like the kindle)Sound (speakers can easily fill your close surrounding, and you get stereo not mono sound unlike the iPad and Asus prime which are supposed to be high end devices)(Also headphones produce louder better sounding music the.Camera (nothing special but for $50 more than the kindle you get two cameras rear and front facing so video chatting is possible)AGPS (nothing special works, just the Kindle iPad 2,3 wifi, and some Asus primes don't even have it)Bluetooth (something the Kindle doesn't have)Performance (Both a pro and a con, it works great for video watching, web browsing, listening to music but can stutter on high end 3d games).Storage (8gb of onboard space +32gb micro sd card expansion+ because downloading and moving files is much easier than iOS online storage solutions like dropbox, of which you get an extra 50gb for one year with the tablet, work much much much better and can actually be useful and less of a headache).Music (The stock player is fine, but you can download any other player. Also I would download the equalizer app which makes the music much better).Videos (Plays any video format that I have thrown at it without the need of external apps, I use the mx player because it makes it much easier to view videos with gestures for brightness, audio, and fast forwarding. Netflix works without any issues.)Size (Is both a con and pro, because it's smaller it's more mobile and makes for an easier typing expierence).Battery life (It's around 8 hours and recharges fast especially when you compare it to the iPad 3).Remote ( Has the peel remote app and an IR which makes it compatible with most TVs and home theaters).Price ($250 for all these feautres is not a lot, and considering it's only $50 more than the kindle and you're getting so much more this makes it an amazing buy) In some sense your getting more than the $499 new iPad 3.ConsPerformance ( High end 3d games can stutter every now and then).Screen (Small for long movie watching, but this can be rectified with a samsung hdmi adapter and then hook it up to the TV.)

tablet_galaxy_tab|Like some other reviewers, I also own an iPad and an iPod (but no iPhone). I think of the Galaxy Tab 2 as filling a niche between the iOS products, mainly because of its physical size. If Apple decides to make a 7-inch iPad, that would probably serve just as well. But I was eager to try the Tab 2 to give me a feel for how Android performs relative to iOS. In addition, the price was definitely right.Bottom line: I'm happy. Not deliriously so, but happy. It does take a little time to get used to how to manipulate Android if you've been using iOS for a couple of years, but it's not a major hurdle. As a user of many Google products, I was impressed at how seamlessly Ice Cream Sandwich (ICS) integrates with them; no contortions are required to access them or sync with them. I also appreciate the greater flexibility in setting up screen views, the use of widgets, and the fact that seldom-used apps are kept in the background. Also, Android/ICS lets you keep track of your files in a number of ways, which iOS keeps hidden from the user.A few minuses. First, the physical switches on the Tab 2 are easy to press by mistake; since the Tab 2 is relatively small, you're almost bound to hit one of them while holding it--I'm clumsy, to boot, which makes it even more likely. Second, the software keyboard has the small delete and enter keys right next to each other; I can't count the number of times I've pressed enter while trying to delete an entry. Third, the camera is nothing to write home about. And finally, there's very little documentation on how to use ICS; if you've been using a previous version of Android, it's probably a no-brainer, but those of us immersed in iOS could use a little help getting started.As for overall value, no question about it: The Tab 2 is great value for the money. It's only fifty bucks more than a Kindle Fire, and it uses pretty much a generic version of ICS, not a proprietary version, which means that most apps from the Android store can run on it without bother (I've found exceptions, though). It's definitely found a permanent home with me, and is likely to be what I carry around with me day-to-day. The iPad is a heavier-duty big brother, most useful when I'm sitting and doing a lot of reading, or need the larger screen real estate that it offers.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|I purchased the 7-inch Galaxy because it has good reviews and I preferred the smaller size. Two things made me return it. First, it is supposed to be an 8gb tablet with expandable memory up to 32gb. Nearly half of the pre-loaded 8gb was taken up by apps I didn't need, wouldn't use, and couldn't delete. I could have dealt with that since I purchased a 32gb SD card. However, I soon discovered that even downloaded apps can't be placed on the SD card - only content.I had also planned on using the tablet for reading documents and doing some minimal editing. The word processing program on the tablet is very difficult to use and has extremely limited capability.On the positive side - listening to music, reading books, and watching video on the Galaxy were all easy and enjoyable. The Galaxy was definitely made for entertainment.Bottom line - if you need an upgraded version of an e-reader, then the Galaxy is a great option. If you need more space and functionality, look elsewhere.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I was recently in the market for a small tablet and had to make a choice between the Galaxy Tab 2.0 7-inch and the new Google/Asus Nexus 7. I chose the Galaxy for 2 main reasons: - Expandable memory - Rear-facing camera (with video)My use for a tablet is primarily for checking e-mail and Web browsing throughout the house (much more portable and quicker to use than a laptop).For me, having a camera is useful for those times when the tablet is closer/quicker than hunting down the digital camera, or for quickly taking a picture and posting it online. There are also some apps that make use of the onboard camera, and having a rear-facing camera allows you to point the camera and see (on the screen) what it's looking at.The expandible memory is a nice-to-have but hasn't been an issue so far. If I start putting lots of music or videos on it, being able to add a 32GB memory card is going to be helpful.The one big benefit that the Nexus has is that it comes with Android 4.1 (Jelly Bean) out of the box. I'm hopeful that my Galaxy Tab will eventually get 4.1 (it came with 4.0, Ice Cream Sandwich), but it's no guarantee. But even with 4.0, the interface looks great and is speedy and responsive.As for the Galaxy Tab itself, it's been an outstanding device. It comes with great apps, easily integrates with the Google Play store, and easily syncs up with both my Yahoo and Google accounts. Web browsing is great, and the few games I've installed have worked perfectly. A video chat I tried with Google Hangouts worked seamlessly. I even recently tried the audio input (you talk, it types what you say) and was surprised at how well it worked.Unfortunately, it won't let you print to anything but a Samsung printer - so I have to go back to my main computer in order to print an e-mail or a map.Overall, a great tablet that I would recommend.

tablet_galaxy_tab|It can't be compared to an amazon Kindle or Nook. It has to be compared to any full size, full price tablet on the market right now, and I have to say it's incredible! The touchscreen works great, it is really responsive and the grease marks are not that apparent. Also the screen has a great viewing angle and the image is crisp and bright (although i haven't used it under direct sunlight). The user interface is easy to use and I only noticed any real lag when downloading and installing several apps at once. The GPS works great, but as said on other reviews, it works better when you have an active Wifi connection. The TV remote app works great and it was a breeze to set up, all in all its a fun function to play around with. I also have some sections in my house where Wifi is not as reliable, but the tab managed to get a lock and stay connected so I'm impressed with the antenna. The audio from the speakers is surprisingly loud although not that crisp. Also the option of having two cameras is great! As expected the front camera isn't that great but for video chatting it's just what you need and the back camera is better than the one I have on my phone so I'm happy with that. I haven't tested bluetooth or the headphone jack, but I expect they will work great. Finally for the specs you get the price is unbeatable!

tablet_galaxy_tab|This is the first tablet I've owned, and overall i really like it. I already have a Galaxy S2, so I'm a fan of Samsung and the Galaxy series. The tab has a quick response, smooth transitions from screen to screen. Apps all load pretty quickly, and downloads are fast also. The camera is pretty low quality, but i can use my 8mp camera on my phone so i don't mind. I have yet to video chat on this, so i can't comment on the front-facing camera yet.The battery seems long to me, but i only use this tablet at home when i have wi-fi, and my phone all day at work, so its not being used by me for 8hrs straight. I've used it for probably 3 or 4 straight in a day.Since its running ICS, and I've never used a tablet, i had to adjust to the layout, with the commands being in the bottom left, along with the task manager/dropdown menu bar etc. The dedicated screenshot button is completely unnecessary and in the way, but once i was used to it being there it was avoidable.I was very impressed by the inbrowser video playback. Youtube videos and flash were great and smooth. i watched an entire HBO show last night with no problems. Netflix runs smoothly, and so does HuluPlus (thought the Hulu app is not in the market yet).The IR remote is cool, but is really only needed if your feeling lazy, but when you are lazy its cool, and works well.The screen isn't the best, but its nice. Again, its hard for me to be impressed by the screen and cameras since i've experienced the AMOLED screen on my GS2. If it weren't for the larger screen size, i'd be tempted to continue watching video on my phone. But once i buy a microSD card to expand the storage, i think i'll get more use out of this tablet.I have a mac, so in order to transfer files to this tablet, you need to download a program to your computer to sync files, movies, etc. Also, you can only transfer files no larger than 4GB, which was disappointing for me since alot of my movies are HQ blu-rays that are 4.5+GB each. So a microSD card may be a must since large transfer can't be done via USB.Summary: Basically, if you already have a Samsung Galaxy phone (S2, Note, etc) I wouldn't buy this tablet, just because your phone is probably better. But if you have $250 to spend for fun, it's not bad to have. Its good for watching movies in bed, surfing the internet, playing games. Also remember it's running Ice Cream Sandwich, so that could be incentive to buy for alot of people who want to play with the new OS.it isn't a bad tablet for the price, and is definitely a great choice for a first time tablet buyer who wants something entry-level.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|I owned a 10.1 in galaxy tab for almost a year and ipad 2 the same period of time. I strayed from the apple (i-Shackle) product because I hate being told what form factors I NEED to buy or use to obtain seamless transfer.To the 1 star due to seeing it had a proprietary port LOL yes lets give an item 1 star for that. Lots of companies are going this route because it helps in the development of far more future upgrades. The vast array of connectors gives developers more options on what they can come up with. i.e dock stations with keyboard and mouse. Yes a usb also can but since 2.0 has a VERY limited power source and a tiny contact patch it makes for pathetically slow connections when using something with multiple inputs. Say keyboard dock with mouse pad, 2 attached usb devices to the dock etc.To the other 1 star review who likes gingerbread more, stick with the old form factor. Ice cream sandwich (ICS) aka android 4.0 is brand spanking new. When Gingerbread was first released we had to hustle to make all of our apps compatible. I have had no such problems with mine and I'm sorry you did.Remember this is not a PRIME class device. You want that then by all means go buy a Transformer Prime. This is the 1 and only (until later this year with the asus/nexus google branded tablet) 7" device by a major manufacturer to compete in this very low price category. For the price of one 10.1 inch high end tablet or Ipad you can get 2 of these.The device is very snappy. I love android 4.0 ICS and look forward to the slew of improvements samsung will inevitably make. Camera isn't the greatest so just use your cell phone which I'm sure has a better one. I don't know why you would rather turn on a tablet to take a picture instead of yanking out your cell anyway. Screen is very bright. Though not 1280x800 like I wish it was reading is still very easy on the eyes. The screens touch response is PHENOMENAL. IPAD level response, it's so very nice to have.7" is the perfect size for us personally. If I want larger I use my laptop at home. The remote control feature is an A+ extra.1 CON - The moment your fingers or hand touch the back the WIFI drops 1 signal bar. Consistently and always. Same deal that the iphone 4 suffered. I use mine in a case so it doesn't happen to me but it is a definite note to take. HEAR THAT SAMSUNG PLEASE FIX THIS PROBLEM FOR THOSE WHO WILL INEVITABLY COMPLAIN AND GIVE IT 1 STAR BECAUSE OF IT.I whole heartily disagree with people giving 1 or 2 stars to an item when they don't like one, two, or even three things about it. Remember you are buying a $250 full feature tablet. The very same features you are paying $200 for when you buy your cell phone but without a 2 year contract.Android phone users (baring htc and Motorola i believe) download FoxFi app from the marketplace and turn your phone into a wifi hotspot for free. Internet for your tablet anywhere you go. Just mind those data charges if you aren't with sprints unlimited plans for some reason. I hope this review was helpful.(update 3 months later)We love this tablet. Again it's worth noting that without a cover/case on it your fingers contact with the back drops the wifi signal 1-2 points. 4.0.4 update was received over the air this morning. The fact that it has a microSD card memory slot is a huge perk over the nexus 7. I had been waiting to purchase the nexus 7. However with only 16gb available with the high end one, it doesn't seem enough. With media for the kids alone it's almost full. We love this tablet and my 2.5 year old has already figured it out. If that doesn't tell you how easy it is I don't know what will. Definitely a Samsung family now.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I was excited about it for the first few weeks, but I've run into a number of limitations that have me questioning this purchase:I can't move Apps to the SD card. While the box says it's an 8GB device, expandable with an SD Card (32 GB) the reality is different. 4GB are available to use, the other 4 held by the OS. 4 GB might be a lot for some, but try installing a few Gameloft Games, and suddenly you are out of space with no option to move the data over to the SD card. What's the point of a 32GB SD card? Photos? Unfortunately, that doesn't really work either. Photos taken with the camera seem to show up on the SD card, but if you use any fancy Apps for taking or editing pictures, they are on the device - not the SD card. Photos downloaded from Flickr or Picassa using different Gallery Apps also stay on the device. After syncing a gallery app with Flickr, my device was full again.I cannot mount this device to either of my computers. They both run variations of Ubuntu (Linux) but this device will not mount no matter what I try (and I've tried lots of options offered by the internet). I've downloaded drivers for the MTS mounting system, switched USB debugging on and off, and tried connecting it as a camera. No dice. Can't connect. Can't transfer files. My 2 year old Android phone and my iPod touch both connect and transfer files to the same computers with no hassles!If I try to just plug the SD card into my computer and manually add music and videos, I get all sorts of errors trying to write to the card. Plug it into the tablet, and they're not there. In fact, the only thing on the SD card is a DCIM folder with pictures from the default camera app, and LOST.DIR. No other folders can be added. No other folders exist on the card. the 32 GB card is completely empty but for a dozen pictures yet the device itself is full.I bought this device for the smaller form factor and to avoid the Apple walled garden, but it seems just as bad (if not worse) on the Samsung side of the fence. Booo. I'm going to have to jailbreak this thing and start over. I can't believe I have to jailbreak an Android device to make it connect to a Ubuntu computer. So much for open!

tablet_galaxy_tab|Here in brief is the Kindle HD vs Samsung Tab2 Comparison.I bought this Samsung after a lot of thinking about maybe getting a new Kindle HD where the Samsung seemed to be a little better and after few days of use here is my thoughts:Comparisons between Samsung Tab and Kindle Fire HD:1- Kindle has a better and friendlier User Interface than the Samsung, specially for Novices and Kids. Easier Navigation and switching between apps.2- Kindle has a more sensitive and receptive touchscreen, it seems that I have to push the screen several times sometimes for the Samsung to respond.3- Samsung have a better App Store(Google) compared to the Amazon.4- Samsung can have a SD drive added.5- Samsung has back and Front Camera, Kindle just front.6- Samsung has less memory(8GB, 4.5 usable), Kindle starts with 16GB.7- Kindle processor is 1.2G while the Samsung is only 1GHz.8- Samsung seems to get a little sluggish at times specially when opening several apps in a row where never had that issue with the kindle, maybe because the kindle will not allow apps to continue running in background after closing them.9- Seems that the battery life is a little better with the Kindle.10- Kindle does not come with a charger(Ridiculous!) and alot of complaints of ads while using Kindle.11- Amazon customer service is superb, I don't think anyone beats them.12- Samsung has GPS, not the kindle.13- Kindle has hDMI output, not the Samsung.14- Samsung measured usable Ram is around 700MB and not 1GB.15- Same Price.16- Amazon Video Library and access is great, Parental control is great. Don't think Samsung has a Parental control and still haven't used their video library and to see if u can download bought movies to watch later?!17- Samsung options and settings are more versatile and editable for the experienced than the Kindle.18- Battery life is worse for the Samsung compared to kindle, 6 hours on continuous use.19- Samsung Tab Glass is NOT Gorrila Glass, Broke after a drop, Kindle took alot more beating and no scratch.So far, Seems the Kindle might have been a better option but not sure, I'll keep the Samsung for now and update this review as things change.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I admit I am a techno freak. I've tried using a couple of other devices (Chromebook, iPad, etc.) before landing this device, and it blows the doors off all of them. This thing is just plain FUN to use, and it does everything and more than I want it to do. Being a heavy Google Apps user, and deep into cloud applications, the more I use it the more I find uses for it. Some of the apps I have installed include Citrix Receiver for login to my most used cloud app (Thomson Reuters SaaS), A1 Keyboard Plus, Chrome to Phone, File Manager HD, Flipboard (very cool), GrooveIP, Kayak, NOAA weather, Open Table, Play Music, Sports Tracker, Spotify, Spotimote, Xfinity TV, Zinio. Plus, lots and lots of games. Out of the 5gb of included storage, I still have 3gb left. Plus, I installed a 32gb microSD card, but I'm not sure yet when I'll need it. My home screen shows me my Gmail account, Google Voice, Drive, and Calendar, plus six more of my most used apps. The only app that doesn't want to work for me is the Peel remote control, but I'm working on getting that going, it would be great, if it worked. With GrooveIP I can use it to make outgoing calls over wifi. The 7" size makes it great to use while eating breakfast, or in bed or on the couch. It even fits in my pocket. Battery life is great, and the screen is more than enough for my needs. At times, it will bog down a little, but I find restarting it fixes that issue. The volume can be way louder than I need it to be. Screen brightness is best left on manual, and it gets brighter than looking at the sun. The five home screens hold a lot of icons, and I have one I haven't even started to fill yet. The widgets are useful, as well. I highly recommend this product, and the Amazon price and shipping are awesome. For $250, it's the best deal out there. I love my Tab 2 7.0, and I feel sorry for my old Android phone now. It just pales in comparison.

I plan on using the Galaxy Tab 2 for every day use like editing documents, writing email, viewing websites, watching movies on netflix.I found the tablet to be very responsive and installed all the applications I wanted but this is where I take one star away and only give 4. If you have an investment in some HD tablet applications like quickoffice HD the market, play store, whatever will claim the device is not compatible. You can install the "phone" version with no problems. I believe that this is because of the display size primarily but if someone knows more, please let me know here.Getting ICS by default is nice and means you can get the thing up and running as you want and not sit through updates at first. This makes a very nice difference on these tablets especially. I believe that this form factor is the future for tablets. The Google Nexus tablet will probably come in at this size and we'll see new tablets I believe through this year stress-testing this size.Finally, the tablet has a very nice feel in the hands and the screen is quite nice and fresh. Installing wallpaper does not result in the usual "cropping" requirements.I was never tempted in the final analysis to buy the Kindle Fire or this tablet. I view the Kindle Fire as a "Amazon Experience" device only. If all you want is that content, by all means get one. I want one that is expandable, has the market/play store on it, can do more tasks and be a light-weight companion when I do travel. I think traveling with this little slate will be quite enjoyable. If you journey forth for pleasure, try doing it with no laptop and using a tablet. Along with the games, wifi connectivity, bluetooth, etc; I'm sold.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I purchased this item from Crutchfield but decided to review it on Amazon since more people would probably see it. There were many who said this would be a bad purchase with the Google Nexus 7 being released. The Nexus 7 is a nice tablet and trumps the Tab in screen resolution and processor power. But neither the Nexus 7 nor Amazon's Fire appeals to me, and many others, because they lack a micro-SD storage slot and support for USB host mode (also called USB On The Go). The lack of a storage slot alone is a deal killer for me. And since I use the tablet to control my Canon T1i using a very cool Android app called DSLR Controller, the USB OTG function is important also. Though no match for the Nexus 7 in resolution, the Tab's screen is very nice and the dual core processor is very peppy. HD videos play beautifully with MX Player. I also installed GPS Test from the Google Play Store and the Tab picked up more than a dozen satellites inside my home under a metal roof and got a position fix in seconds. So it should be a fine GPS navigation device with the appropriate software. I could go on about how well it runs other apps I've installed, but the point of this review is mostly to disabuse potential buyers of the notion that this tablet has become completely obsolete because of the Nexus 7. It's still a bargain and for some of us a better choice than the Nexus 7. I love the size, features, and performance. You can safely make a buying decision based on your particular needs.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I have owned and used several android tablets and I have to say that this is a really nice buy for your money. I currently own the ASUS transformer T101 and was looking for a smaller screen size that still has Ice Cream Sandwich. I needed the device to be able to stream movies over my network at home or on the go, and let me VPN to my work site and monitor equipment. The Galaxy does both with ease, and is just the right size to take with me to lunch and catch up on the news with Pulse or Newsreader. Compared to a Fire or a Nook Tablet this thing just blows them out of the water. This is not Android with a locked down interface thrown on top....this is pure ICS goodness with a few Samsung touches that can be bypassed with ease. What that really means is that you can customize the tablet to fit your needs. Example: Don't like the built in browser? Install Dolphin and enjoy fast tabbed browsing. Don't like the built in Samsung Music Player? Install Google Music, Rhapsody, TuneIn radio or any other player no questions asked. Add Kindle and Nook apps and you are good for reading, and apps like PlayOn let you watch Amazon video and Hulu on the go. You can do some of these things with Fires and Nooks, but you can do all of them with the Galaxy. Add a 15 dollar 32G Mini-SD card and you have plenty of room for your stuff. I even like the TV app. So check this Tab out, you won't be disappointed.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I was in the market for a tablet for my son. I was considering the Kindle Fire, but then saw the Samsung Tab 2. This is a much more versatile tablet. Looking at the specs, the two are very competitive. However, on closer inspection, the Tab 2 came out the winner. And here's why:- The Samsung Tab 2 has upgradable storage. I can add up to a 32 GB micro SD card to the Samsung. The Kindle is not upgradable.- The Samsung Tab 2 has both a front and rear facing camera. If all you want to do is Skype, then the front-facing camera is fine, but if you want to take pictures using the Kindle, good luck.- The Samsung uses Android Ice Cream Sandwich, and I prefer it to the Kindle's UI. The Kindle seems to use Android apps, but these must be purchased through Amazon's front end. I guess I prefer the versatility of the Samsung App store and Google Play.- The Samsung uses a "standard" tablet UI environment. This is a minor point, but I like the thought of my son getting used to a more conventional UI, as it will prepare him to use a real tablet in a real world. He's growing up in a world where tablets are commonplace tools. If he learns how to navigate and organize his day using a standard tool, he will be better prepared in tomorrow's world. Again... a small point, but an important one.Cons:The Sammy DOES have a proprietary charger as opposed to USB (This is where the Kindle wins). For this reason, I cannot give the Sammy a full 5 stars.The Sammy also lacks the app time-out feature of the Kindle, which lets parents set time limits on some apps. This is easily accomplished using apps on Google Play, however.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I really do enjoy my Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 - The tablet was at a great price, it is fast and is well built - however, there are some quirks and some Samsung-isms that detract from what is overall a very nice 7" tablet. I'll try to be brief but thorough, scroll to the bottom for the cliff-notes.::Hardware::Processor: Dual 1.0ghz - Pretty standard for 2012, zippy for most things but not record breakingRam: 1gb - Again, pretty standard for ICS in a middle price point device; fine for 99% of tasksScreen: 1024x600 WSVGA - Gorgeous. Samsung makes pretty screens and good hardware.microSD: Accepts microSDHC (Up to 32gb of external storage) They use a dumb mnt name though ...microUSB: NONE (Samsung! What were you thinking!)miniHDMI: NONE (Samsung!! Seriously!!)30 Pin Proprietary Port: Yup. Instead of industry standard ports Samsung saddles this device with a 30 Pin port (*cough Apple rip-off cough*) You will be stuck with Samsung brand cables and accessories. I don't know why companies think that proprietary ports are a good idea ... whatever.Camera: 8mp Rear / 3mp Front. They are decent but only really useful for Skype and video chat. Taking pictures on a Tablet is awkward and there is no flash.IR Blaster: You can control your TV (I had wondered where this feature went 7 years ago when it disappeared from devices. I'm glad it's back, it is by no means life changing but it is fun.)Speakers: Better than I had expected, but unfortunately they are located on the bottom so when you play games or watch movies in landscape the stereo experience is lost. Also, if you have big hands and hold it from the right your hand covers the speakers muffling the sound. Oh well.Audio out: Headphones work. The jack is a little tight so you worry about breaking it the first time ... but it works fine.Bluetooth: Works great. Keyboards, mice, gamepads, etc. Go nuts.Battery Life: Much better than I had expected. It generally lasts a whole day even with heavy use. It lasts longer if I am just checking the web and email occasionally. It won't last much longer than 3 days on light to moderate use.Connectivity: I bought the WiFi only model and it connects well to a Wireless B/G/N router.Bezel / Case: The device is well built and does not feel flimsy. It has a little weight to it, but the appearance is very slick and attractive. Occasionally, because I have big thumbs, I accidentally touch the screen when holding the device one handed. I suppose someone with smaller thumbs would not have this problem. (Thumb-ectomy?)::Software::OS: Ice Cream Sandwich is awesome. Google made some great improvements with this release of Android and it is much more polished than Honeycomb .... unfortunately Samsung has included some "Customization" and several of the Android menus are truncated and some options are missing. (Mostly things like Themes.) I guess this is leftovers from the "Touch Wiz" era. This is too bad really, because on a stock build the device would probably run a little faster and have some more UI options. Samsung ... STOP IT!Pre-Loaded Apps: This is the part of the review that makes me sad. Samsung really does make gorgeous hardware, but their software is kinda crap. They have pre-installed the Samsung Media Hub, custom gallery and calendar apps, and a slew of other Samsung branded "Features". Most of them work o.k. but you can't get rid of them and they don't really add anything to the Android experience. I wish manufacturers would stop trying to provide "extra content". As usual the Samsung Experience apps are protected and cannot be removed without rooting. You can however hide them in the app drawer so you don't have to look at them and most of them do not automatically load into memory unless you tell them to. More or less I find they just take up space. The Galaxy also comes with the standard Google apps pre-loaded. The new Ice Cream Sandwitch email app works so much better than the Gingerbread/Honeycomb one and Gmail's App is much improved as well. Also, Google Chrome is available for Ice Cream Sandwich. It works well and syncs all of your bookmarks from your desktop browser if you let it.::Summary::Great price, nice hardware. Runs most apps flawlessly. (High end emulators will have to accept some frame skipping to get past the standard processor.) If you like spending extra money on proprietary cables, there are a slew of accessories from the Galaxy Tab 1 7.0 that will work fine with this.Hardware - 5/5 (*For this price point)Software - 3/5 (*Ugh! Samsung warez!)Galaxy 2 7.0 vs. Kindle Fire = Buy this tablet! It crushes the Fire in processing and overall user experience.Galaxy 2 7.0 vs. Nexus 7 = Hmm ... depends on how important microSD is to you. Probably get the Nexus 7.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|Let me start this review by saying that I do own a "New" Ipad. I do love the Ipad I wanted a smaller tablet, something that I could put into my pocket if possible, but something smaller and easier to transport.The pros:The 7" screen my not be "HD" but it you would not know that unless someone told you that. The images are very sharp. I like that I can change memory cards so I can have tons of video or pictures. Basically I'm only limited to how many and the size of the memory cards I own. This is very light.Cons:While I can change the memory card when I want to, I do have a hard time sometimes getting the memory card out of the tablet. It's supposed to work on the push the memory card in and it pops out just a little so you can grab it. I have a hard time with this, sometimes. For this reason only I have to give it 4 stars because it really does bother me.In conclusion you can't go wrong with this 7" tablet. It does everything I could possible want a tablet to do, all you need is a little patience when it comes to changing memory cards.
