tablet_galaxy_tab|This is a great tablet. For $250, you will not find a better deal. I have tried the Kindle Fire and the Nook Tablet, and the restrictions in the OS make them fall short compared to the Galaxy Tab 2. Ice Cream Sandwich is sleek, quickly to respond, and very customizable. The best Android OS out there so far, without doubt! I dare to say it's even more customizable than OS X / OS 5 in some aspects. There are numerous apps and it allows for third party apps to be installed as well.One of the silly things I care about is wallpaper customization and the sorts, and I was disappointed that Kindle Fire didn't allow for that. This tablet, however, is super customizable as far as those things go.The size is perfect. I don't care for the 10inch displays of the iPad. I wanted something I could hold in my hands, put in a purse and carry around without having to worry with its size. Display resolution is great. I couldn't tell the difference between it and the Fire. I haven't tried the IR or bluetooth functions yet, but I'm still playing with it. Yes it has a proprietary cable, but seriously, what doesn't these days? Also, the camera resolution is not that great, but I'm not going around carrying a tablet to use the camera. I am photographer so that's the last thing on my mind when I shopped for a tablet. It's okay for the occasional snapshot, but if you want superb pictures, get a decent camera or pay extra for a tablet with good camera. Can't have it all man, but this tablet is an absolute bang for the buck!

tablet_galaxy_tab|I thought that the product was great because it was limitless, but I recently found out that this is not the case. I bought the 8Gb drive expecting to use the external drive once I filled the internal drive, but this is not the case. To start out with half of the 8Gb is taken up by the tablets firmware and bloatware. That leaves a piddly 4Gb to use for apps. From what I have gleaned from my research and talking to Samsung, Samsung has disabled the ability to move your apps to the SD card. So, if you buy and download apps, which I guess you would because that is what Droid is about, you will NOT want to purchase this product. From my experience apps that you cannot move include: games, apps that use the internet for push updates, and apps that download offline content (some of mine are close to 1Gb by themselves). I would not recommend this product. If you are going to be limited by Samsung and have to store all of your content on the internal drive, you might as well get an iPad. The features are great, the speed is great,and the definition is great.Samsung's customer service will not do anything for you if you are unhappy with their product. You cannot leave a negative product review on their website either. They say that it goes against their posting rules, but it doesn't. I have submitted two product reviews tailored to their posting requirements and both were unjustly rejected. DO NOT trust their rating on Samsung.com because it is engineered by Samsung to falsely give a better impression about their products than it should. You cannot even give feedback about their poor customer worth because they say that they "appreciate your aggravation and are sorry for the inconvenience, but there is nothing they can do to help" me. Pay the extra money, get an American engineered product, a better supported product, and a more secure product. I wont be purchasing another Samsung product again. I am done with them.

tablet_galaxy_tab|After doing literally days worth of research on tablets within my budget, it came down to the Kindle Fire, B&N Nook, Blackberry Playbook, and this device. All retailing for less than $300, but after reviewing the specs of the aforementioned devices over and over, and watching many Youtube video's, and reading countless posts and discussions on this device I went ahead and pre-ordered it. First off, I tip my hat to Amazon, who got this sexy piece of technology to me a mere day after it's release (keep up the good work guys). Now on to the review.Right out of the box, I love the way this device feels in my hand. It just cradles my hands perfectly, and has a nice weight to it, and the materials to me, feel like quality stuff. Upon fully charging it, I did the initial setup, and then proceeded to download all of the apps I would need on this device (SBM, Quickpic,Camera ZOOM FX, Aldiko, Rage of Bahamut, A Comic viewer, Evernote, etc.). After testing all of them under various conditions, I am very pleased with the performance the tab offers. There was no noticeable lag or performance issues at all in starting, using, or playing any of my favorite apps. The TouchWiz interface blends nearly seamlessly into ICS, and I for one like the the way Samsung integrated the two interfaces. The capacitive screen is very responsive, and I had zero problems using SBM on this device to keep my many invention ideas drawn and saved for further refinement. Speaking of which, the screen is gorgeous at 1024 x 600, and while not the highest end screen out, is simply stunning for the price range. I tested a variety of HD videos, and all of them ran without a single hiccup in the frame rate, and had all had bright crisp pictures, and awesome sound quality (the speaker was far better than I expected it to be). Watching the HD quality video of One Ok Rock Live at Shinjiku Loft was truly awesome on this screen, and didn't stutter a single bit.Regarding reading e-books, it housed, ran, and performed far above my expectations, and I found myself reading in a variety of lighting conditions, in all of which it functioned perfectly as an e-reader. Haven't tested the camera's yet, or Poweramp, or some of the more advanced features yet but I'll update this review once I get a chance to play with them a bit more. Oh, and lest I forget, the battery life on this bad girl is beyond sweet. Since my initial charge, and using it moderately to heavily for three days, I haven't hit 60% of the battery use yet. Also a quick note for those wondering about cases, the device fits in my Navitech case like a glove, with none of the buttons or ports being blocked (besides the rear camera of course). So far, after testing all of the aforementioned tablets, the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 is serious contender with all of them, especially the Kindle Fire. For only an extra $50 you get expandable memory up to 32GB (a huge plus in my book), two cameras, ICS without the need to root anything, full access to Google Play, and more. Unless you're a serious power user this tablet is more than capable of handing most anything you throw at it. While a bit of a downgrade from it's Samsung siblings, for the price you currently won't find a better tablet.UPDATE 4-26-2012: Been using the Peel remote app with the built in IR blaster for over a day now and to say I'm impressed would be an understatement. I have a brokSonic TV that I use for television watching, as well as my PC monitor. While the input (i.e. switching from HDMI, to coaxial/TV, to component, etc.) is not supported by the app, it more than meets my needs. Turns my TV on in the morning, and is able to switch channels on my Comcast DTA. Now for those of you who have Comcast and a DTA (the small smartphone sized box like device), you know that there is no guide for us. And this is where Peel, and the IR Blaster captured my heart, as not only does is function as smart remote, but also has an awesome program guide built into the app. So now I can see what is on TV at any given time and allow me to instantly switch to the channel. This functions either automatically by clicking the Watch on TV button under the show currently on, or if like me and the app seems to want to double down on numbers (i.e. changing to channel 33 instead of 3) can be done manually by pressing the appropriate channel button in the upper right hand corner. A very minor annoyance, but considering me not having to give Comcast $9 a month more just for the privilege of having a guide, I give the IR Blaster, and Peel remote app, two huge thumbs up.UPDATE 4-30-2012: Poweramp works like a champ on this tablet. The sounds while not mind blowing, are crip, with good lows, mids, and highs. The bass is more than sufficient for listening to music through the speakers, but as always if I need deeper richer sound I just plug in my JBud J3's and enjoy my tunes.UPDATE 6-6-2012: Finally got the Poetic case for this tablet, and got a chance to take come videos and pictures with the rear camera. While I wouldn't substitute this for my DSLR (obviously I guess lol), it works awesome as a standard point and shoot camera and camcorder, taking pictures in surprisingly great quality. Also I wanted to note that in bright light, watching videos with any dark scenes is difficult, but it's not so big an issue as to take away from all of the awesome positives.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|In reviewing my Galaxy Tab 2 I compare it to my iPad 2, which is less than a year old, because like it or not, iPad is the gold standard of tablets. I was actually going to wait for the 2nd generation Kindle in hopes that it would include a memory card slot. It didn't take long to fill up 16GB on my iPad so I wasn't going to downgrade when I got a 7" device. But I have to thank Amazon for setting the price bar for 7" devices to a more affordable level. At $249 for a tablet with 8GB and memory card up to 32GB, on a 2nd generation device, the Galaxy Tab 2 is the best buy out there right now.The Tab 2 is slightly thicker than the iPad2, which, being 2nd generation, disappointed me. But at 7" in size, it was still light weigh and didn't bother me a lot. Like the iPad, the Tab 2 starts immediately. I found my finger does not slide across the screen on the Tab as smoothly as on the iPad. Finger prints are also a lot more difficult to wipe off on the Tab. Scrolling on the iPad is also a smooth fluid motion where the Tab 2 is a jerky movement. However, if you've never seen a iPad, I doubt you'd notice. Where Samsung succeeds is in just offering 7" as an option. Steve Jobs was wrong when he said no one would want a 7" tablet. I find myself using it more than the full size iPad. The Android store is also easier to search than the iTunes store, which brings up so many Asian language apps that I waste a lot of time trying to find things. But one of the best things about the Galaxy Tab is that it is a standalone device. The iPad must be connected to a PC for setup and updates. The Galaxy does not require that. Samsung Kies software is available if you want a PC interface but I was never able to get it to work on the PC or the Kies software for the Tab.It seems Samsung does not offer mobile broadband with this device, unlike the earlier 7" Tabs. That's too bad. I know people who would get one if it did.As you can see by my 5 start rating, any fault I find with the Tab, doesn't really bother me a lot. Overall, I think the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 this is the best of the 7" tablets out there today.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I'd wanted a 7" iPad. I had a first generation iPad and it was just too big and heavy for my intended use. I tried the Kindle Fire, found it lacking out of the box because it doesn't do well with Gmail and Google Calendar. I rooted the Kindle Fire, tried Cyanogenmod 7 and 9, and it still wasn't great for me.Enter the Galaxy Tab 2 7". It's lovely hardware, significantly lighter than the Fire. With bluetooth, which the Fire lacks, it plays very nicely through my Creative D100 bluetooth speakers. And it is much more satisfactory than the rooted and modded Fire--recent OS, and much fewer bugs than the unofficial Cyanogenmod ports (blessings to all the devs at Cyanogenmod and XDA!)The Tab operating system, Ice Cream Sandwich, is sleek, smooth and attractive. Although there are far fewer apps than for the iPad, my needs are met well. I really like the voice dictation and command interface that is very well integrated into the apps. Too, I'm using the SlideIt keyboard, available through the app store--much better than the stock keyboard IMO (and one of the reasons that in this instance I prefer Android to IOS since Apple doesn't make this kind of Swype-like input available in such a well-integrated manner).Other reviewers have commented on the pros and the cons. I'll just add that while there are compromises compared to, say, the iPad 3, the compromises are reasonable and don't affect my enjoyment of the device.It may be that new tablets such as the vaunted Google tablet will provide more bang per buck. But at the moment, the Galaxy Tab 2 7" provides plenty of bang, with a fluid and enjoyable user experience for this size of tablet. Glad I got it.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I waffled around for quite some time before deciding to grab a Galaxy Tab 2 7.0. After all, I had my laptop for gaming, my netbook for traveling ... WHY did I need another computer like 'toy'???From the minute it arrived and I put it on the charger, I could not resist playing around with it to see exactly what it could do. I explored the app store, which previously was only available to me on my phone, and poked around in the games, something I'd not bothered with on my phone, due to the small screen. What a MOST pleasant surprise it was to be able to sit and enjoy games, looking around on the internet, or reading (I transferred some of my Kindle content to my Tab). The light weight of this Tab is easy on the hands/wrists, even for extended periods of time. It can snap a quick picture if I need to, check my email, allow me to browse the web for something that pops into mind, and get some of my favorite phone apps as well. I became an instant fan!My hubby, who is not tech minded, saw me playing with it and commented it looked like fun. First time I got a chance, I purchased another for him - which he is enjoying greatly. The great thing about this Tab is: it's designed for easy accessibility, and you don't have to understand a lot about tech to fully enjoy it. It makes his little handheld individual games obsolete, and he is really having a great time playing old favorites, as well as trying out a few new ones. Since he has now retired, it will be something he can really enjoy using any time of the day.The slim size of this Tab allows me to take it AND my Kindle when I'm out somewhere I know I'll have to be waiting. Best of both worlds, in a convenient size ... I'm in heaven!! If you are waffling about getting one of these little gems ... grab it now! You won't be sorry!!

tablet_galaxy_tab|I'm sure none of you need a 492nd opinion (as of this writing) but I am so impressed by this tablet, I feel compelled to write about it. I should point out that I bought this elsewhere (sorry Amazon - it was easier to return if I didn't like it and it was less expensive) and it's the Student Edition, which includes a USB link and an attachable keyboard. Both are great and I highly recommend this edition if you can find it.I agonized comparing this to the Fire HD and Nexus 7. Recognizing each has pluses and minuses, I finally made the plunge with the Galaxy Tab and am glad I did. It is everything I wanted in a tabletTo put my review in perspective, I didn't want a tablet for playing games, viewing movies, listening to music, or mainly shopping. I wanted a lightweight piece of hardware that would allow me to access the internet, as well as maintain my calendar, contacts, to-do lists, and other general "workhorse" tasks. The Galaxy Tab does all of this amazingly and as I've found, far more.The Good:1. It has the best calendar program I've ever used (including Palm, Apple, Google).2. The display, though less than its competition, is clear and adequate for my purposes.3. Battery life has been great, and I've been putting it through its paces. As other reviewers note, you have to be mindful of what's running. The Tab allows killing programs easily, turning WiFi and Bluetooth on and off quickly, and generally tweaking to your heart's content.4. Navigation is fantastic and fully customizable.5. Touch is for the most part, responsive (see below for so-so.)6. It has voice dictation that is highly accurate and makes composing emails, searches, etc. very easy. It's not perfect but then again, neither is Dragon.7. WiFi performance has been excellent. I'm not sure why some reviewers have had problems but I haven't. At home, on the train, and at work, this has picked up, identified, and connected quickly, and maintained the connection even with weak signals.8. The customizable universal remote is FANTASTIC. I am having so much fun with it. It's not perfect but it's good enough.9. I was worried about performance given that the processor is lower speed than its competition and only dual core. Also, this is the older version of the Android OS. My fears were unfounded. This has performed quickly and responsively with everything I've thrown at it, including real multi-tasking.10. The USB dongle included in this edition is also great. I've moved files and so far, avoided having to get a micro-SD card.11. Though I keep thinking I should have gone for the 16 GB version, so far, I haven't eaten away that much of the storage. And I see the micro-SD as a solution should I need more.12. I've accessed my entire Kindle library and the entire Android market with ease. The Tab holds its own to the competition.13. Internet usage is smooth, fast, and I haven't experienced any clipping.14. It reads and allows editing of MS Office products admirably, as well as reading pdf's.The So-So:1. Touch response is usually fast but sometimes lags. I've found that sometimes it's because my other hand is overlying the screen somewhat, but there are occasions where I have to keep tapping.2. The feel of the screen is dampened by a plastic overlay, so this lacks the smoothness of moving your fingers over true glass.3. The overlay is a true fingerprint magnet.4. The camera isn't that great (haven't used it for Skype yet) but this isn't what I want in a tablet anyway.5. No manual on the device. I personally don't tend to read them and enjoy finding my way around hardware and software but others might be daunted. The manual is available on Samsung's website (and other reviewers have given links in this forum) but it would have been nice if they had included it.The Bad:1. As others have noted, placement of some icons, and particularly with the keyboard, are awkward. I've taken too many screenshots with the camera than I care to admit.2. Syncing software with their calendar and Outlook proper (not Exchange) would be great but is absent. There are low cost options in the Android market but then you lose Galaxy's wonderful calendar (I think - I haven't bought any syncing software yet.)With this market, the Galaxy Tab is fast becoming "old" but I think it is a very viable choice. My review may be too late to the party, but I'm so in love with it, I thought it proper to put it in writing.UPDATE 10-18-2012Still loving it. Maybe even more. My two "Bad" comments above have been addressed. Taking inadvertent pics with the camera from the bottom screen has been fixed as you can program that area to do other things. And Samsung's own "Kies" software syncs its wonderful calendar with Outlook!This tablet is the very productivity pad I wanted. With free android apps like Evernote, I'm able to keep my personal and professional life well-organized. The only hiccup I've experienced is that it sometimes chokes a little on large pdf's (such as the electronic manual to this). But other pdf's don't faze it at all.Oh, and for me, the battery life is great. But I practice conservation: shutting down apps I'm not using, turning off wifi when in sleep mode, etc..

I'm very impressed and saved $100 to $150 bucks. The user interface Samsung laid on top of Android 4.0 is excellent. The screen is responsive. Syncing with Gmail and Google Calendar is perfect. To my eyes the screen looks better than its specs. The Wi-Fi signal seems consistent and strong. Definitely worth a try.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I have been using the tablet for about a month now. I ordered both the playbook and the tab since their specs are very similar. I liked the Tab for reasons mentioned below and returned the Playbook after a week. I'm quite happy with it's performance, if not mind blown. Its definitely worth the money I paid but I still see a lot of scope for improvement.Form factor: The biggest pro for the Tab I'd say is the weight. Even without getting into the specifics of the OS the Tab wins hands down compared to the Playbook given its much lighter build and better screen. The Playbook has a much solid build and the rubber finish on its back feels much better in your hands but it's a little too heavy for comfort.Display: Speaking of the screen, the 1024x 600 display is vibrant and sharp. One of the best ones out there. It a joy to watch HD videos on this baby. The display is definitely much sharper than the Playbook. The auto brightness wouldn't work properly out of the box - the screen was always way too dim. But I got an over-the-air update 2 weeks after the release date and it's working fine now. I haven't noticed any other changes from the software update.Battery: The battery is also good. This is my first tablet so I don't really know how long these things are expected to last. Checking my email 3-4times a day and about an hour of browsing/video means I need to charge it once every 90hours. Reading books with the display inverted (white letters on a black page) means you can go for two days without having to recharge.Keyboard: One of the best things about a 7" tablet is you can type with two hands in portrait mode as if it were a smart phone. The stock keyboard is really miserable though. It's extremely slow and the auto correct behaves like a 5year old baby. I use the free version of GO keyboard and it's just brilliant. If not for this I'd have returned the Tab. There's a bug in the software that doesn't allow you to move the cursor to the second last line when composing email - which leaves some unnecessary space between the content and my signature. And removing the two extra lines takes more time than writing out the entire email since the keyboard doesn't have arrow keys. If you use the Tab for writing emails a lot you'll find this really frustrating. God bless Go keyboard! It is not only much faster and has a better layout, it has a better auto-correct (though not as good as that of iOS) and the much needed arrow keys.Speakers: The speakers are loud and clear, with two separate speakers at the bottom. This however is a bad design - putting both the speakers next to one another. Isn't the whole point of stereo having one on each side? Unless you're holding the tab upside down in portrait mode you're blocking one or both speakers. The playbook does a much better job here with two front facing speakers. No wonder playing NFS on the Playbook gets your adrenaline going. The Tab on the other hand doesn't even have a supported version of NFS. Blah!OS: This is my first Android device. And I'm pretty satisfied with the performance. The device is responsive and navigation is fairly intuitive. The device does slow down after continued usage though and a quick reboot brings it back to pace. Roughly 600MB of RAM is under use all the time - I'm not sure what causes the slowdown. I wish there were something like a favorites menu to access the most frequently used apps without having to put them on one of the home screen. The Playbook OS 2.0 is clean and minimalistic and does the job. But if you want to go beyond just emails and work, you would want to choose an Android or iOS device. One of my main reasons for choosing the Tab over the Playbook was the android eco-system.Email: The default email client is buggy (like I mentioned before). The mail widget seldom doesn't respond when you click on unread emails. You have to open your inbox and then open the unread mail. The unread mail count on the email icon doesn't update when you've read your email, which is also really nagging. The Playbook has a much better email client; that's BB's home ground after all!Music Player: Nothing out of ordinary. You can scroll down easily by the letters on the right side column for songs/artists only, but not for albums. I don't know why. The music player widget is convenient way to accessing your music player but the playlist always scrolls back to the top. This is really irritating when you have a long playlist with hundreds of songs and have to scroll down each time.Really smooth with docs. Renders pdfs superfast, even the bulky ones with thousands of pages. I'm a grad student and this was my main reason behind getting the Tab.I could go on and on. But I've hopefully touched base on the most important points.tldr; The Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 still has a few kinks but it's the best 7inch tablet available in the market as of now if you're looking for a tablet for more than just reading. If its ebooks you're after you might as well stick the Kindle.

I love the touch screen. Even with a screen protector its a easy touch. It does everything I need it too. tablet_galaxy_tab|I almost returned this. I got it for the IR remote, which turns out to be a waste of time. The provided free remote is very limited. The play store remote is very very very expensive. I used the trial, and found out the database is limited. Most of the devices I needed to control by IR are NOT in their database. But I would not pay the fifty bucks for it anyway,,,,,,the better remote app should be under $20. There seem to be only two remote apps for it, the provided one for free, and the squid one...which is too expensive, and as I said, limited in database/devices.The IR feature problem, and the proprietary cable connector took off one star. I would give it three stars but it is such a good value, I gave it four stars.Setup was frustrating at first.1) Be careful about getting the Samsung account. I did not get the registration email. Their system is not capable for correcting this. I had to create another gmail account to use it.2) Of course, you need a gmail account with payment method attached if you want to use the play store.3) Don't bother using the amazon app store, as you need to install the app store app to use anything you bought on the amazon store. Just use play store.4) Tech support is outsourced out of USA and is totally useless, I found. It should get one star less for the crummy ignorant and arrogant support, but that is the way of the world for an international company like Samsung.5) Most apps I use run fine. Dish, Squeezebox, Kindle reader, cool reader, and many more.6) Video app built in is better than most.7) DOes NOT seem to support flash, and I could not get it to load.8) Works well with the Pogoplug home device. This allows you to stream video and must, as well as see files on pogoplug device in your home network. Pogoplug app seems to be ok. TO stream video you must "optimize" video on the pogoplug (it does that itself, but is VERY slow). Once the pogoplug optimizes the video, it will play on the Galaxy fine. You can get pogoplug cloud storage too, cheap, and have all your stuff in the cloud if you can;'t get to your home network stuff.9) Video and audio quality during playback are fine.10) Touch screen is very sensitive, but good.11) You can get spare cables from amazon. Including a cable that converts to female usb connector. I think you might be able to use usb flash drives with this.12)Many cases or covers available.13) Battery life is ok. Depends maily on running apps that constantly stay on to access network stuff. You need a task killer to effectively kill these when not really using them.Overall for the price, an excellent value. Worth the extra bucks over the cheaper nasty tablets.Recommended, overall.

tablet_galaxy_tab|Personally I prefer e-ink Kindle 3 (aka Kindle keyboard), which I have for 1.5 years, but in two weeks after release of Kindle Fire I bought it too, because my son, who is medical student, wanted something compact to read his color textbooks. I'm not a fan of gadgets, at least I do not like to have more than really necessary, but I'm quite experienced with them and my friends bring them to me to set up very often. So, I played a lot with different Android phones and tablets as well as with different IOS ones, like iphones, Ipods and Ipads. I do like Apple products quality, IQ and interface but for me they look like handicapped ones comparing to Android devices - no USB host and memory extension, limited number of supported file types, need of iTunes to copy files (no chance to download anything from other computer without it when you are travelling), so sometimes it is even not a lack of features, it is lack of freedom. Actually it relates to Kindle Fire in some aspects, too )))Anyway, I wouldn't buy this tablet, but I'm going for vacation and it seems that it will be necessary not only check my e-mails, but to read some documents and to answer, my smarphone is not very convenient for this and I do not want to carry my 13" laptop, so I decided to give this tablet (Samsung Galaxy Tab 2, WiFi, 8Gb) a try. I played with it for two days and may say the following:GOODScreen: Excellent. Very similar to Kindle Fire, though of different type, probably viewing angles are a bit different, but anyway very good and comfortable screen for reading, browsing and watching movies.Battery: Excellent. I fully charged it and it worked for 10 hours 43 minutes during two days, when I checked it yesterday (there is a battery meter in the Settings). Today it worked for about 20 min and switched off completely at 5%. I think that 11 hour is very good for first cycle of charging, usually it became a little better (10-15%) after 3-4 cycles of training. This 11 hours were active browsing, downloading applications, reset to factory defaults, WiFi was on 80% of time, screen brightness - 30-40%, manual. Overnight it eats 2-3% in sleep mode, so the battery is really good. UPDATE for battery - the battery meter shows the time from the last charge of the tablet. Mine restarted after reset to defaults, but anyway, its estimated work time was more than 10 hours, it's why I desided it shows real operation time.OS: Good. I did not notice any significant difference in speed and touch sensitivity over regular Cyanogens, Kindle or IOS, but I'm tolerable enough to some delays. Actually, after initial set up we do not work with OS, we work with applications and widgets, so I do not care what type of OS is hidden behind, as soon as it is stable. And I do not care if it requires 10 sec to find an icon and to start application, if after that it works okay without lags for hour.10 sec may kill some guys, but I usually survive. But it is not the case, Tab 2 OS is intuitive and responsive. The only thing I did not like - it is impossible to set two and more languages in Samsung keyboard, so I had to install additional keyboard. Well, it is stupid, any Samsung Android smartphone has this feature.Applications. It seems that many applications are not optimized for ICS. I live in different country, but I usually set US as home country for the devices bought here - sometimes it helps to avoid stupid software limitations. But Skype could not be downloaded from Google Play, it told it is not available for my country. Probably they track IP, but even the version, downloaded from 1mobile market told that the device is not yet certified for it. Anyway, Skype works perfectly.Quality: Good. It seems that it is assembled very well. A bit plastic, of course, but I put it into Roocase leather case immediately and now who cares what is inside?WiFi: Good. No problems with connection to office, home, and restaurant WiFi networks.BADNo external LED battery indicator. Or it is hidden somewhere inside the case, but all the other buttons and connections are accessible. So you have no idea, if it is plugged in, is it charging or not and is it charged completely before you switch it on. Not very convenient. Sometimes you even could not see on screen battery indicator when the device is charging and off. And charging time is very long - at least 5 hours (from 5 to 100%). But its because of good battery )))Proprietary cable. Well, it would be probably okay, but supplied cable is very short, it seems it will be very difficult to handle device when it is charging.In general, very good tablet. I'm not going to use it for a long time, and after I'll be back from this travel, I'll give it to my son to replace Kindle Fire, which he will sell to his mates. At least it's what I recommended to him, though he likes his Fire and have laptop for any serious work. I'd recommend this tablet to anyone who wants good multimedia device. Frankly, all this stuff, including Ipads and other 10" tablets, is mostly for entertainment, if you want to DO anything, regular cheap netbook is better.

I was open to iPads, Galaxy Tabs, Thrives, Nook, Fire, Sony's tab, Asus's tab, etc...I ruled out the Nook and Fire for their locked ecosystem.I went to best buy, and ruled out a good number of tablets based on their responsiveness and ease of use. So it was between 7+ or Tab 2 7.0.I'm cheap, so I went with the Tab 2.@Pros: Very responsive UI Android 4.0 Runs games fairly well Plays movies very, very well (including netflix, or those on sd card) Camera on front and back (back camera is not bad) Has external microSD card slot Peel SmartRemote stuff@Cons: !!Fairly small internal memory, and it's difficult to move things back and forth Not top-of-the-line hardware A little bit of bloatware@I use the tab for a few things, for which it is perfect:- SmartRemote that knows when my favorite shows are coming on, and I can actually switch to them with the tab (the app isn't perfect, and I haven't found a better one, yet)- Quick games- Checking email- Quick SSH sessions for checking disk usage and things- Reading online documentation- Small edits of MS Office docs- Looking up something on IMDB quickly- Watching a 20 minute show in bed on Netflix (it's the perfect size for 2 people to watch a short show on without arms getting tired)- Skype works better than my computer- It's okay for watching something longer (and it plays it very well off of external microsd cards)@There are a few tasks it's not great at, that I occasionally use it for:- Note taking- Using Citrix to do database work (if there's a tablet that did this really well, I would be all over it)

tablet_galaxy_tab|I am truly overwhelmed by this tablet. I purchased this to replace my aging Palm Pilot. I primarily use this tablet to organize all of my work files and it is turnng out to be a great tool.I transferred all of my notes from my Palm consisting of nearly 500 procedures. The transfer was tedious and required beaming them to a laptop with an IR beam. I then dragged and dropped the individual procedures from the laptop to the tablet. The tablet has Polaris Office which easily converted the imported text files and stored them in the Memo tool.I imported my contacts in a similar fashion. All but a handful were successfully added to the tablet without having to re-enter them by hand. I also dragged and dropped my photos and MP3's from the Palm to the tablet via the SD memory chip.I had numerous HanDBase databases on the Palm that I transferred by saving them to the Palm's SD memory chip. Then I transferred the databases from the memory chip to the tablet. Fortunately HanDBase has an Android version of their database program and I was able to start using my databases in minutes. HanDBase is so much easier to use on the tablet.Lastly, I opted to enter my calendar appointments by hand to the S Planner.In all, the process of transferring my information from the Palm to the tablet was painless. I now have all of my information on a much better tool and the wifi capabilities is icing on the cake. By the way, I have found the wifi to perform better than expected. I have wireless devices that do not work on the third floor of my house but this tablet works flawlessly. The GPS and mapping features are awesome. I have several GPS devices that range in price and I am really amazed at the precision and effectiveness of the built-in GPS. The battery life is very good if you don't over do it with the wifi or GPS. I usually get 7 days of battery life if I don't use the power hungry wifi/GPS. If I sparingly use the wifi/GPS then I can expect 2-3 days of usage. I have owned this tablet for 3 weeks now and I am still finding better ways to utilize it and it has been a great companion at work.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I had begun to be interested in the world of tablets, and I started to look for a small, budget conscious device, and I found the Galaxy Tab 2 7 Inch, and I am pretty astounded by the quality and value of this device, it does not mimic the cheapness found in similar tablets of this price range, with a highly responsive screen, full Android 4.0, and a good build. Also being a 7 inch device it is very easy to hold with one hand, and it is very light, it is definitely a good choice for those who are on the move often. The device is not perfect though, with a few hiccups.PerformanceThe device responds quickly to commands, plays media flawlessly, and runs every app without incident, but after a week of using the device, there was an odd slow down of the home screen that occurred for about 5 minutes, I did not get the issue again since, that is the only issue I have had with the performance. I think it was the stock TouchWiz interface, I have since switched to GOLauncher, it's great.Battery LifeThe battery life is great so far, after being charged to 100% I got 2 days of use without charging, tasks on the device included a little web browsing, browsing and installing apps, and some video/picture taking.NetworkingThe device is WiFi only; I have had no issues with it, reception is no different than the other WiFi devices in my household.InterfaceThe device uses Samsung's TouchWiz interface; which to my guess is a modified 4.0 interface, it is a nice interface, without lag, but the lock screen seems a little boring, I will probably look into using the default 4.0 interface, or something else.ScreenThe screen is very good in my opinion, it displays content nicely, and it is very responsive. There have been a few instances where I have sworn I tapped the screen and nothing happened, it could be my error, or the device's.AudioThe device features two speakers at the bottom of the device, which sound nice but are not the best I have ever heard. The microphone is located at the top of the device near the 3.5 mm headphone jack, from a little use of the Google voice command feature, I have found no issues.CamerasThe device features a front and rear camera, the rear camera is 3 MP which takes decent photos, while the front camera is a VGA camera that is good for video chat, it is no SLR camera, but has good cameras.PortsThe Tab 2 features a 3.5mm headphone jack at the top, Micro SD slot with door, proprietary Samsung USB port at the bottom. The most interesting is a built in IR Blaster located on the right side, which is supposed to be used with the included Peel Remote app ( I had to manually update the app before being able to use it) which worked very well with controlling my devices (LCD TV, Sony Surround system, Comcast DVR). My only true gripe is the lack of a Micro USB or micro HDMI port to be used with projecting content onto a TV screen, one must purchase Samsung's adapter to do so.ButtonsThe Tab 2 features only 2 buttons, which are located on the right side of the device, the first button is the usual lock/wake button, and a volume up/down button, I would of liked to see a Home button, but the 4.0 interface takes care of that.Build QualityThe Tab 2 has a solid hard plastic build, the back of the device features a soft metal like shell that feels good when held.Pre-installed AppsThis is one of my gripes with the Tab 2, the device comes pre-installed with a suite of bloatware, that cannot be installed as far as I have discovered, I prefer the default Android apps, with apps I choose to install. It does come with some useful apps such as Netflix and Kindle bookstore.Overall, it is a fantastic device, with a few hiccups that may only bother a select group of users, being a first time owner, I cannot compare this tablets to others personally.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I have been holding off buying a tablet for years now. The Ipad, Motorola Xoom, and others are great. But, in my opinion, they are not worth the $500+ price tag, especially if you already own a good smartphone and laptop. So, i tried this, and am very impressed. It's a full featured Android tablet, unlike anything previously in this price range. Ideally it would have a bigger screen, but i think that is probably impossible at anywhere near this price range. There are plenty of reviews on sites like CNET that give accurate descriptions of the strengths and weaknesses of this tablet. I think they are accurate. You are making some tradeoffs for the price, but in my opinion they are completely worth it. One of the cameras is lower quality, but the other one is great. The internal memory is small, but you can add a micro SD card, so no big deal. The tradeoffs are 100% worth it given the price savings. At the end of the day, if you want a "real" tablet, and do not think it's worth $500+, this is the perfect solution.

tablet_galaxy_tab|Pros: built-in speakers, bright display, subjectively realistic color, excellent form factor for travel, came with android 4 ics, smooth video playbackCons: un-removable bloatware, unable to move apps or data to external SD card, should come with 16gb internal storage, touchscreen sometimes slow to respond (adding a screen protector makes that worse), battery life with WifI on could be better, shortage of compatible accessories- - - - - - - -I wanted to replace my first-gen iPad with a 7" tablet. My choice came down to this device and the Nexus 7. Samsung won for one simple reason: the micro SD slot. If you have any desire to carry video around to watch where you can't stream, you need storage space.The Gtab is lighter than the iPad -- though hardly lightweight, especially when compared to a Nook Touch -- which makes a difference for extended reading of e-books, or reading while lying down. Being a smaller device, it's also easier to travel with; it doesn't take up as much room in a carry-on and it fits in a coat pocket (or even a cargo pocket in my shorts!). The micro SD card slot means I can carry more videos to watch on a plane, though the battery life for video isn't as long as I'd like. Battery life while streaming Netflix via WiFi is even less; it's good for 2 - 2.5 hours and then it's time to recharge.I don't understand complaints I've read about the screen and its resolution. The screen is bright (turn off the auto brightness adjustment and do it manually), colors look reasonably good, and playback is smooth. Any artifacts I've seen in videos come from the videos themselves, not the screen. It's a 7-inch tablet; how many more pixels do you need?Small speakers don't sound particularly great, but these are at least good enough to let someone else listen with me on occasion. Sound through good headphones is quite good.The Gtab is good for reading, too; the size makes it easier to handle than the iPad. I've had some issues with certain e-books, but they're from the e-book or the reader app, not from the tablet.I'm not happy about the lack of an adapter for video out so I could watch purchased movies/TV shows on my HDTV (although reading elsewhere indicates that you can't port DRMed material on any of the Tab devices to a TV through Samsung's HDMI adapter (which is not compatible with this device)). For that matter, not happy with the custom connector in the first place. A mini- or micro-USB connector would have made life easier all the way 'round. There also appears to be no docking station of any kind that's compatible with this particular device. (Seriously, Samsung? You have other tablets with the same type of connector, but you changed the pin-outs or something on THIS device so that it can't be used with any of the accessories that work with them?)I'm glad that the Gtab came with Android 4 installed, so I didn't need to wait for an upgrade (the Gtab recently upgraded itself to version 4.0.4). However, I'm not happy that there is so much bloatware preinstalled, and no way to remove it without rooting the tablet. I also dislike the fact that there is no way to move apps -- or data that they download/install -- to the external SD card without rooting the tablet. Some apps can't even see the external card (which, I realize, could be the fault of the app rather than the tablet).Given that Samsung has locked down so many things to internal storage, it would have been nice to have a 16gb device available. I'd have paid an extra $50 for that. Instead, I'll get around to rooting the tablet one of these days so I can ditch stuff I don't use and move data (downloaded videos and books) to external storage. For now, though, the combination of price, usability, and form factor means that I'm fairly happy with the Gtab.Note: If you're switching to the Gtab from an iPad, and want to continue using iTunes for organize your music, get the iSyncr WiFi app. You may have to create special playlists -- iSyncr doesn't support picking & choosing songs/videos, it just grabs the whole playlist -- but this is the best iTunes tool available on Android right now.

I enjoy watching streaming video movies and my only improvement suggestion would be for the battery to last longer and recharge faster, but this is not a major concern.

tablet_galaxy_tab|My wife wanted my Kindle Fire so instead of purchasing another I wanted something with a little more. Something with expendable memory, Bluetooth, gps, mic, and camera and this tablet hits on all cylinders. I have a 32.gb micro .sd card in mine loaded with movies, pictures, and music along with documents. Plenty of internal memory for apps and games. The display is excellent, making for excellent video watching, and sound quality is excellent for music as well as movies. There is very little I can't do that I could do with the Kindle namely watching Prime videos and shopping on Amazon is a much better experience with the Kindle Fire. However with this device you overall get much much more for only $50 more than the Kindle.When using this device the drop down menu is actually a pop up menu on the bottom right of the screen for easy and quick access to a quick settings menu including Wifi, screen brightness, sync, GPS, silent mode, screen rotation,Bluetooth , notifications, and ariplane mode. This menu also has a set button for access to the full settings menu and immediate access to the screen brightness control as well as ongoing audio and notification. At the bottom of the screen there is also a button for instant access to mini apps including email, calculator, alarm,music player, planner, world clock,and task manager. These mini apps pull up small windows in the center of the screen that allow quick access to these features without leaving the screen you are working on. There is also an instant screenshot button and a button that pulls up apps that you have previously been working on giving you the ability to quickly return to them.The camera takes excellent photos and videos and the forward facing camera is not all that great but does allow for selfportriats and face time. I personally make VERY little use of the camera but thought it was worth commenting on.The GPS works great, just as it would on a good smart phone although it will not give you driving instructions without wifi.The built in mic allows for use if voice dictation when emailing, writing Amazon reviews etc. I admittedly have very little experience with using this feature.The Bluetooth feature was probably my biggest complaint about the Kindle Fire but this device does make use of it making listening to music untethered a pleasant experience as well as transferring data between bluetooth devices seamless and quick.Web browsing is excellent on this tab, very quick and fit to screen is excellent as although pinch to zoom can sometimes be a little laggy.This device comes with Polaris Office as it's native document program instead of Quick office. I have lots of evperience with DataViz, Quick office, and Office Suite as I read and edit documents on my mobile devices daily and Polaris blows all the other doc readers out of the water with it's (my opinion only) ease of use, and is visually very pleasing. I still use Office Suite some as I am more familiar with it by I expect that will come to an end as I become more familiar with Polaris.The IR blaster was a surprising touch as I can program my tablet to control my TV and other IR devices in multiple rooms. Though there are glitches with the native Samsung app that makes use of the IR abilities it is still very nice.Battery life is one thing I don't complain about vs other reviews. I get a full days use from a single charge, even if I use it a lot, however I keep the screen brightness down and unused features off like GPS, notifications, wifi if not on the net etc. I do the vast majority of my internet surfing from this device as well as TuneIn radio, mp3, Amazon mp3, Rahpsody, and YouTube and get a good 8 hours or more out of the device. I do believe screen brightness and of course streaming video or audio are the major factors when it comes to battery usage.Now, in the spirit of full disclosure I strongly prefer a 7 inch tablet vs a larger tablet. The ONLY thing I like a 10 inch tablet better for is web browsing , though a 7 inch is no slouch in this department. A 7 inch tablet IMO is better for virtually everything else, games, email, video/audio, portability, and especially as an Ereader. The Kindle app for Android allows me to carry all my books very similar to the Kindle Fire.I keep my Galaxy Tab 2 in a Poetic hard cover/stand with camera cutout and the device literally fits in my back pocket making this device truly portable vs, a 10 inch tablet. I use this as my Bible, web surfing device, hand held video game device, mp3 player, video streaming device, (youtube, Netflix, hulu, Crackle, etc) email, doc reader and editor, voice and video caller (when connected to wifi) PDA, and ereader. In the short time I have had this device it has become a "must take with me everywhere I go device".ProsAndroid 4.0Expandable memoryGPSPriceBluetoothMicBattery lifeCamera (rear 8mp camera is excellent, front not that great)Fast and responsivePortablePolaris OfficeFull access to Google Play store, Amazon app store.Syncs to your google account including contact list , Google Docs and calendar.IR blasterQuick access to mini apps and recently used apps.Built in screenshot with instant editorExternal and virtual volume rockerExternal speaker good, not greatConsFinger print magnetSlick in the hand without a coverHome screen takes almost a full side to side swipe in order to switch screensDedicated sync/charge cable instead of the more universal micro USB charger

Since I already own a Galaxy phone, using this tab is a breeze. I'm pretty sure anyone would find this user friendly. I feel confident that this tab will keep me happy for a couple of years until I upgrade and can pass this to someone in my family.

Unlike the Cowon J3, however, the audio quality on this tablet is decent even without EQ. I do recommend messing with the audio settings to get the sound signature you want, though. A lot of people insist on wanting flat EQ because "that's how the music was meant to be heard." This tablet plays .flac files which is a huge plus for me since that's about half of my music library.The other thing I like to use this for is playing games. Angry Birds is so much fun on this thing, and unlike my cell phone, this thing actually has the battery to play for extended periods. I do recommend getting a stylus to fine-tune the angle of bird trajectory especially if you have fat fingers.Some people complained about the resolution not being very high. I don't see a need for it, personally. The screen isn't that big to begin with. The videos I play look fabulous enough as it is.

tablet_galaxy_tab|Short review:Nice screen, halfway decent camera and camcorder (no autofocus, though), and a good size to hold in your hand.However....The Wifi antennae is VERY weak on this device. I use an AT&T Uverse Wifi modem in my house - a very standard unit and one used by a good number of people in my particular area. It's been out a while as well, so is not an odd standard or unknown third-party device. I noticed quickly that I was dropping Skype video calls on my Samsung Tab, then I noticed Netflix movies were buffering, and Youtube videos would do the same, all with me being only two rooms away from my router. Through coworkers, friends, and a neighbor, I have had people come over to my house and test their devices on my Wifi, so we've had a range of Android phones, a couple of iPhones, and one iPad in here trying it out. Everyone averaged around 12-18 Mbps download speeds on their devices, when in my living room, two rooms away from the router. My Samsung Tab barely got one bar of signal, and averaged around .5 to 1.5 Mbps download speeds (if that). Same room, same location in room, etc.There are no updates to the device software. Samsung support ranges from "we're aware of it" to "send it in for repair". I'll be taking it back to where I purchased it as my "repair" - sorry, I'm tired of companies using the public to test their devices before they have. That's my experience, yours may vary.UPDATE (April 2013):Decided to try this again as by now the kinks should have been worked out on newer production stock, so went back to the Big Box store and got one that runs Android 4.1 (instead of the previous unit's 4.0), showing it's an updated model. This time, the WiFi worked *slightly* better with *slightly* better range than the previous unit, this time averaging about 6-8 MPS on average (in a 22 MPS area, however). I noticed that for whatever reason, this unit had more "bloatware" apps installed than my last unit, that cannot be removed, and upon investigation many of them keep trying to kick on constantly even after you disable them (?). Not a deal breaker, but irritating. The "up to 11 hour" battery life is also stretched of course, too - with consistent normal use I'd say it's more like 7 1/2 hours depending on what you're doing.This is app-specific but worth noting too - I tried a very popular scanner app that allows you to create PDF documents of papers you have, and upon installing I was told by it it was not compatible with this device because the Tab 7" only has a 3 megapixel camera on the back, and you really need at least 5 megapixels to be table to clearly scan documents. I know this is specific, but something worth noting, as people do like to get smaller tablets for work uses as well.Overall I upped my rating one star from 2 to 3 but there are still enough quirks and irritations to make me tell someone to look further (maybe a Nexus) unless they are getting one specifically just for very casual uses like Netflix, etc.

And I like the little whistle it makes when I have new email.Oh, and I can't forget my Kindle app. If I want to spend an hour or more reading, I prefer my actual Kindle, but the Kindle app is great for a quick bit of reading here and there and it synchs with my Kindle so I can pick up where I left off on either device. The Galaxy is the same size as my Kindle so it's easy to take along everywhere I go.At first, typing on the touch screen drove me crazy, but now I'm pretty good at it. But, nevertheless, I'm having a lot of fun with this little gadget and I'm glad I bought it.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I am not the type to write reviews but this tablet has been such an positive experience for me I have to share my experience. First and foremost size was my primary driving factor. I didn't want the standard 10' tablet. I wanted something bigger than my droid cell phone that was easy to hold and easy the hand to type on the keyboard without having to strain or remove my hands from holding the tablet. This does that perfectly! It was easy to set up my gmail account and sync all other email accounts along with my calendar. The camera and video camera work great and deliver quality resolutions images and there is pre-install editing software for both photos and videos. The web browser took a bit of time to figure out how bookmarks are set up and managed but aside from that it works great. The speakers are way more than I expected out of a tablet. This is a dual core processor tablet which is reflected in how well it responds when navigating from app to app or within a specific application. I was able to use the tablet for extended periods of time with heavy camera and video usage without having the battery drain on me. I would say I had the tablet on all day while traveling in Manhattan and was constantly taking photos and video from early am till late pm and the battery still had life to it. Very impressive. Navigation is easy from app to app to settings with easy access touch screen options for viewing active/open apps or navigating to the task killer (nice feature) to quickly getting to settings. The wifi works great in detecting wifi networks. The Samsung comes with a feature to track your tablet should it get lost/stolen.Things that could be improved (but not deal breakers). In BRIGHT outdoor sun, viewing the screen image is difficult depending on the angle, even with the brightest screen setting set (which is easily accessed from screen). It would also have been nice to have a USB port to easily transfer photos/file/etc to and from a flash drive (although the existing power cable easily connects to a USB port on your computer to get around this).Side note: My first couple of days after setting up the wifi connection in my home, the internet connection would repeatedly drop for a few seconds and immediately reconnect. After a bit of online research I found out it was not the tablet but rather the channel my router was set to. This was easily resolved by installing a wifi analyzer app from Google Play, seeing what channels had less usage in my area and switching to one of those channels. My tablet has internet connection and has yet to drop the connection.I really am very impressed with this gadget/tablet and would recommend it to anyone.

tablet_galaxy_tab|Overview:I am very happy with the Tab and use it daily for many things. The highest praise I can give is that my wife is jealous of it. But you have to go into it with reasonable expectations - if you compare it to an iPad you are likely to be disappointed. I had no previous experience with an iPad, other than testing it an an Apple store, or any smartphone, so the capabilities were a revelation to me. I chose it primarily because of the price and size - the iPad seemed too big and heavy for use as a book and magazine reader, and I did not want a phone with a monthly payment. The Tab is comfortable to use standing on the Metro, on airplanes or lying down on the couch. Others have complained that it is laggy, but I don't find this a big problem. Like others I have found that it can be difficult to press the right button, especially in apps where the buttons are closely spaced, but somehow over time this has ceased to be an issue for me. Typing with two thumbs is easy and responsive, especially in portrait mode. Caveat: the market for small tablets is changing rapidly, with Google's Nexus, new flavors of Kindle Fire, and a rumored mini-iPad in the offing, so the competitiveness of this device is up in the air - it will have to evolve to stay viable.Specifics:1. Reading books: I chose this over the Kindle Fire and BN Nook because I did not want to be tied to one vendor and wanted a more open Android experience. I do not regret this. I also considered some e-ink readers, but have not found any problems with eyestrain reading the LCD screen and can read in sunlight to a degree if I crank up the brightness.2. Reading magazines and pdfs: I chose the Tab over an e-ink reader in part because I wanted to read media other than books. This works well despite the small screen size. While not optimal for 8.5x11 or A4 size pages, expanding 2-fold by tapping or pinch-and-zoom is available in most magazine and pdf apps and is good enough. I mainly use Zinio for magazines and repli-go pdf reader for pdfs, which in addition make it easy to jump around in long documents.3. Camera: Specs are not impressive, but I have found it quite useful for close-up photos like portrait shots. The convenience of having it on a device I often carry with me anyway and direct upload to Dropbox or Picasa make it preferable to a stand-alone camera.4. Web browsing and email: A great convenience to have on-the-go or when you want to look up something in a book. For serious usage, I still prefer my laptop.5. Calendar: Sync with my Google calendar is very handy. Again, for serious usage, a laptop is better.6. Storage: I don't store movies or much music so even the 8 GB on board (4.59 GB usable) is adequate, but I bought a 32 GB micro SD card for extra space (and a bargain at $20 plus shipping). Most apps can't use it, so it is not a complete solution, but it is a convenient place to stash photos and documents that are not tied to a dedicated app.7. Battery life: As advertised if you limit Wi-fi use, Bluetooth, and GPS to when you need them. It also helps to keep the screen brightness down as this is the main power hog.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|I purchased this tablet with second thoughts thinking I didn't "need" a tablet, as my smart phone and laptop are excellent. After much pondering, I purchased it. I absolutely love it! The browser is much faster than I expected and the visual quality of the pics and videos are much better than I expected. This device is axiomatic for most people probably, with not much use for the user manual. I looked at the manual after I had used it all day and already had it set up like I wanted it with apps, icons on the screens, etc. The battery life is better than I expected. I often checked the battery level after watching a Netflix movie and found only about 10-12% drain on the battery level.I would recommend getting a stand and a nice case for it. The stand so you are less likely to drop it and the case so if you do drop it, it hopefully will protect it. It is very easy to slip out of your hands, so be careful. I'm still looking for a rubberized perimeter protector for it and haven't located on yet. Buy a micro SD card too for extra space. I bought a 16 GB to go with mine.I have noticed that I use my laptop less now, so that will extend the life of my laptop hopefully. Facebook, e-mail, weather, and reading news is a very nice experience on this device. I got the 7 inch one instead the 10 inch. I held the 10 inch and it just seemed too big to be convenient. I have no regrets with the 7 inch. It is large enough for ease of use, but not too big for a bulky experience. I hope this is helpful.

tablet_galaxy_tab|First of all, I have to really wonder about the many reviewers who bought this device, then returned, and gave it bad reviews because it doesn't save apps to the SD card. Since about 1 in every 5 of the 274 reviews (and counting) clearly complain that it doesn't save apps to the SD card - do you people who still continue to buy it, return, and complain because of that NOT bother to READ any of the reviews first before buying it???Anyway, I've had this device for over 6 weeks now, and it does everything I wanted in a tablet - and within the max price I was willing to pay. I previously bought a $150 tab and ended up returning it because it was under powered (IMO, you really need dual core CPU to properly run ICS 4), and my research indicated that the really cheap devices couldn't even play netflix movies properly.I added a few 'accessories' that further enhanced the quality and usage- a Poetic case for ~$18 that fits like a glove and is very functional (multiple viewing angles for movies, enhanced grip and no fingerprints, good protection)- a good screen protector (originally designed for the 1st samsung galaxy tab 7) that gives a smoother feel when swiping on the screen- turned on the "hotspot" feature on my android phone (extra monthly fee from verizon), so now I have 4G with this tablet anywhere there is 4G service...sweeeeeet!Pros:- netflix runs great on it- good ebook reading experience- screen quality is very good for doing the above- camera - only because it's better than not having one at all (it's not great, but not as bad as some have written).- 7" rules for portability and comfortable reading. It's kind of funny watching folks trying to comfortably hold up their clunky (compared to 7") ipads for reading during the daily commute.- internet surfing is excellent, either with home wifi or connected to my 4G phone via hotspot.Cons:- Peel remote app doesn't work at all with my Sony 40" tv. I sent a support request to the company, a couple of times, and received no response.- guess what? YOU CAN'T SAVE APPS TO THE SD CARD FOLKS!!Since neither of the above Cons impact what I need a tablet for (still have plenty of internal memory to install more apps, if I need to), I gave it 5 stars, for overall quality and functionality.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|I really have to hand it to Samsung when it comes to their 7 inch Galaxy Tab 2. I've been waiting for an inexpensive 7 inch tablet to come out and this one really hits the mark for me. It has the features that I need and does without the features that I don't care about to give me a fantastic piece of awesome for only $250. You get the full tablet experience minus some arguably, unnecessary extras. For instance, HDMI out is not supported and there's no flash. Other than that, this is like a Kindle Fire with two decent, basic cameras, a fully functional Android 4.0 ICS build, and the 7 inch frame that my thumbs and back pocket love. On top of that it sports the best battery life of any 7 inch tablet available, and that's what really sells it. I would recommend this to anyone who wants a great 7 inch tablet and doesn't care to spend over $300. Thanks Samsung! I'll be looking forward to investing in the 7 inch Galaxy Tab 3 when it arrives on the scene.P.S. If you're a Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 owner and are having battery life issues you can take some steps to make it better. The first thing I would recommend is controlling your display brightness. That's the biggest culprit. Another recommendation would be to learn how to root your device, load Clockwordmod Recovery, and load a custom rom. Cyanogenmod 9 is out for this tab and it really makes it a pleasure to work with. I don't really care for Touchwiz anyway.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|I had been wanting a tablet for a while, but I couldn't justify paying $500+ for something I didn't absolutely need. I had considered other, less expensive options, but not been happy enough to actually purchase anything. The Barnes & Noble Nook Color was an option, but I would have wanted to root it, and I didn't want the hassle. I wanted to use my tablet, not work on it. The Kindle Fire is nice, but it has limited storage (which isn't expandable) and doesn't have access to the Google Play store.Then Samsung finally got my business. A 7" tablet with a good processor, expandable memory, and decent battery life, all for the great list price of $250.The screen on this isn't the highest resolution, but it is clear and represents color well. I am not crazy about the auto-brightness control; it seems a little too bright in dark light and too dim in bright light. But lock the screen brightness to 50% and I rarely have to touch it. Plus, you can set up a screen widget to change the brightness if needed.The body of the tablet is nice to hold, not too slick, but no rubbery feeling. The heft makes it feel solid, but it is not too heavy to hold for long periods of time.The battery life seems to be doing well for what I need. The only caveat is that, as with all wireless devices, the wifi will drain the battery faster when it is searching for but not connected to a network. Not a big deal if you are at home and connected, but you may want to turn the wifi off if you are taking a trip.And the OS is Android 4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich or ICS) straight out of the box. There is no need to root this device to improve the software; its already as good as you can get (at least for now).Is this going to match the experience of an iPad? No. It isn't really meant to either, since the screen is only 7". But it isn't locked into the iOS/iTunes ecosystem either, like an iPad. This also isn't as expensive as an iPad.If you don't plan to take the tablet away from wifi, don't need expandable storage, and are happy living in the Amazon ecosystem, the Kindle Fire is a good choice and a little less expensive. If you are willing to spend $500+, there are tablets that can do more, run faster, or have more features. However, if you want a tablet that can hold your music or movies while you travel, want the full Android ICS experience, and aren't made of money, this table it for you!To sum it up, this tablet is the best value of quality, features, and value currently on the market. I fully recommend this tablet.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|I already own the Ipad 1 and I share that with my kids. Due to the 16 gig limit and my kids needing to stuff it with apps I wanted to get something to call my own. Truly I didn't want to spend a lot of money since I already have an Ipad and I wanted something with significant memory so that I wouldn't have the same maxed out storage issues I have with my Ipad. So I decided to purchase the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 and for the most part it meets my needs. It runs smoothly and the additional storage option (32 gig mini SD) is welcomed. I don't miss not having the App Store because The Android Market has many of the same apps as well as more than enough apps to keep me happy.My only issue is that I wanted to play movies from my digital download library so I could watch a movie when I wasn't in a WIFI hotspot. Although the specs say that this thing plays most codecs I found that to be untrue. After attempting to load 15 or so movies I literally got only one to play. To me this is very disappointing and frustrating. It also takes a long time for movies to download onto the device unlike iTunes. I hope this is a temporary glitch but it's enough for me to take one star away from the device's score.Other great features are the cameras. Although they aren't up to actual dedicated camera standards they are more than adequate for a small tablet. I don't plan to use them that often since I own cameras. Being able to view websites with Flash is also nice. The size of the tablet is perfect for on the go as well. I don't find that the 10" Ipad is that cumbersome but this 7" tablet just makes it that much easier to take with you. The screen size and quality is nice.In my humble opinion this device is well worth the money. It really meets most of my needs. Now if you want the fastest device with all of the premium specs you will be disappointed. This is as good as it gets at this price point for now. I am happy with my purchase so far!PS. If anyone has any information on how to make my digital downloads play on this device please share. Thanks.
