tablet_galaxy_tab|Original review:For this review I thought I would provide some details about this tablet from a comparison point of view to the Asus Transformer Tf101. I won't focus on the obvious hardware differences (screen size, port differences, etc.) But instead will talk about some of the lesser known differences.Pros-mini app bar - this is a nice feature (but also a source of annoyance) and can provide quick popup access to some features (calendar, alarms, email (not gmail), calculator, music player, task manager, world clock). Asus provides nothing like this.-a dedicated screen capture button on the Galaxy while Asus requires holding the Recent Apps Key.-the Galaxy keyboard is way better than the Asus provided keyboard. It uses a much smaller percentage of space but yet is still easy to use. I am used to using Thumbs Keyboard app on the Asus and even that app occupies more screen space than the Samsung keyboard.-Samsung provides a better application list UI than Asus does. With Asus you can just view the apps and jump to the store. With Samsung you can also customize the order, hide apps and create folders of apps on your home screens.-Samsung doesn't require an insane amount of power to charge the unit. My Motorola droid USB charge adapter (which I have several for use with ipods ) is powerful enough to charge this. Asus on the other hand requires an insane amount of power.Cons-mini apps bar reduces visibility to notification icons when in portrait orientation. I can only see the battery, wifi, time, and weatherbug temp. No ability to see email notifications. When held in landscape, the other notifications become visible. It is odd because there is still about 3/4" of space between the mini app ^ and the last icon.-mini app bar is not able to be disabled. This means if you value the notification area more than what this feature provides or get annoyed by hitting it instead of the spacebar there is no ability to shut it off.-Asus provides the ability to disconnect wifi when screen is off setting to help preserve battery life although no similar offering exists with Samsung-Asus provides the ability to disable the screen capture feature-Asus provides several custom Widgets while the Samsung does seem to have anything special.General notes I am disappointed that when adding a memory card it does not allow it be used like on a phone where you can install apps on it to recover some internal memory. This seems to be a flaw with Android's ICS OS and is not specific to this device, as the same is true for my Asus. I just didn't buy a memory card for my Asus since it has 32gb. I am not certain if I would have got this had I known about this before. In any event I suspect that I'll be able to manage as I can have the camera use the sdcard and I can also store music on it. And these should be the main consumers of space.The home screens have grid dimensions of 6 cells wide by 5 high. On Asus it is 8 wide by 7 high (this makes sense given the resolution difference)So far I have run into one app that I wanted on this that play store said isn't supported (peapod) but I was able to transfer it to this from my Asus and install it, and it seems to work just fine. I like knowing that this is an option that I can try if more apps have a similar issue.Now if I can only find a better way to prevent purchasing content through one click through the Amazon Appstore I might be inclined to get this for the kids. The price point and features are certainly where I wanted it to be and I am happy with this purchase. My only wish was that it had a 1280x800 resolution but it seems less of an issue now that I have it.UPDATE 12/2012 - Comparison to Google Nexus 7So my kids wanted a tablet and they ended selecting the Google Nexus 7 (16gb) instead of this one (and at the time it was purchased the same price. Now you get a 32gb Nexus for the same price). Now that I have been able to use both I have a few comparisons to point out about the Nexus to this tablet.The main issues I see with this device compared to the Nexus is the 8gb of built in memory. Although true Galaxy allows a memory card for music/photos/movies and the Nexus doesn't, my wife often complains that she runs out of room for apps. There are a few apps that are quite large that just limit what she can put on this. The kids have 8gb of space still available so I don't foresee them complaining of space issues anytime soon.Another issue I see in day to day use of the Samsung is with the size of the back, home, app manager on-screen buttons. They seem to be a bit too close to each other and also seen to be harder to reach if a case is installed (they both have the same brand/style case) . The design change that was done for the Nexus OS which puts the buttons in the middle with more space between them actually works very good for this size tablet. I first didn't like the Nexus change but now I find that it was a good change.As for speed comparisons I do feel that the Nexus is faster than the Samsung. The Nexus is significantly smoother than the Samsung. Its even smoother than my Asus. As for network speeds, the devices are the same. I saw 19k kbps/3.8k kbps on both units. This is slower than my Asus which received 22k kbps/3.8k kbps.The screen resolution is the same on the Nexus as the Asus so it also looks better than the Samsung does.The only point which I feel the Samsung exceeds the Nexus in is the fact the Samsung has 2 cameras while the Nexus doesn't. This means that the Samsung can take quick pictures of things for easier reference later, while the Nexus can't.So if the kids need a quick copy of a document they must scan it and save on the device instead of just taking a quick photo. The scans are obviously better quality but less convenient.The other advantage the Samsung has is due to the fact that it is an older OS so it still supports flash content, while the Nexus doesn't. I'm certainly disappointed in Google's change in direction on this as it means like Amazon video reviews are not viewable on the Nexus.So in the end now that we have all 3 of these devices, I must say that I prefer the Nexus over the Samsung (and I think my wife wishes she had it instead).
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|So far, this tablet, an early entry for Samsung in relatively discounted tablets, has more or less met my expectations and I really like it (if Amazon would allow half star ratings I would have done 4.5).One thing new buyers should be aware of is that as the operating system version, Ice Cream Sandwich, is still fairly new in deployment, there are still some shortcomings albeit on the whole minor. The only prominent shortcoming I've seen so far, and it's significant but short-term, is that nearly all of the applications are not yet capable of taking advantage of the external SD card, and the very popular apps that allow one to move data and applications to an external SD card don't seem, from my experience, to function yet with this new version of the OS or at least on this hardware implementation. It's clear this will change in fairly rapid order, but given it's only a 4 GB internal card it's quite easy to fill up the storage on your first day if you are a content-heavy person (I was loading the hundreds of songs I would typically put on, not realizing it wasn't going to the external card at first, even though one of the "move 2 SD" apps said the app in question had its data on the external card).But the performance is great on this device, and I've already loaded dozens of apps and am able to run everything quite smoothly.The only other notable disappointment is Samsung does a poor job of giving a user a good start on the device, at least in my opinion. Instructions on how to start using it are quire spare. If I were not an experienced Android user I think I'd be at least somewhat upset; even as an experienced Android user I experienced a few frustrating moments but nothing insurmountable or lengthy. Some of this isn't Samsung's fault (though they really could have provided a far better guide), rather there's also the issue of the ongoing changes in Android's environment. For example, when I went to use the Android App Market, I suddenly got the Google Play app asking for permission, and I had somehow totally missed the news about Play replacing the Android App Market. This led to some issues as I tried to stop this "strange app" which was appearing with no explanation whatsoever.For my uses, this is really an excellent product (or at least it will excel as soon as more data and apps work on the external SD, which clearly will happen), and I'm glad it came out so I didn't have to spend more on the prior "Plus" 7" tablet. I think the design tradeoffs (the lesser camera, and some other things I read about that I don't recall) are quite fine and I look forward to using this device for some time to come.Oh, one other frustration I should mention, the plastic door/gate/whatever it is that is supposed to hold the external SD card in is really wonky and at least feels like it's going to break off with any real use. Just trying to open it I felt like I was breaking part of it, but I think that's because it hangs by a plastic thread, so to speak. Not sure. But I want to note that once I seated it back properly it has fit fine and so I cannot tell if my concern is mere perception or if over time, especially if the card is taken in and out on occasion (though not sure that will happen), it will detach.Otherwise the hardware is really quite nice.
---

I do not like the extra spacing between the clock and the weather, should've made it a little tigher together. I felt the open spaces between widgets and icons just was useless and a waste of screen real estate..Sound -Much much louder than a Kindle for sure. This is awesome on flights where you sit near the engine.Battery -So far so good, I left it on with my WIFI on all day and came back after 9 hours of work to find it at 97%. Not bad at all. Have yet to play 2-3 movies to see if it'll hold up against what the Kindle can do on a 5hr flight. TBDWIFI -does not see ad-hoc wifi (wifi tethering on phones), but nothing Foxfi BT or Rooting won't solve. Not a killer deal but sucks compared to Kindle.Signal strength is fine for work or office and locks on quick.GPS -Not not yet used, don't care to use it since I have a Galaxy 2 phone.Form factor -Love it, great size, good feel to it, light enough to not feel fatigue when holding. Though I have ordered a case and screen protector (which I always do).Memory size -Yes like everyone says, around 3.5GB left on internal memory. Nothing Rooting won't solve with APP to SD. :) Love the External SD option.Charging cable , interface -This is where I hate. Come'on Samsung don't you ever learn? Galaxy 10 and now this? After using it on my G2 phone I need it, Samsung phone is Samsung, is Samsung Tablet not made by Samsung? Does the company not talk to each other and have some kind of standard on what comes with a Samsung Android device? WTFail. No Swype is sad, get up to speed and get your act together.That's all for now. So I guess you can't have it all so I took 1 star off due to the charging cable/proprietary plug and lacking Swype.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I bought this primarily so that I could use it for ebooks in both the Kindle and EPUB formats. It has surpassed my expectations for this. An added bonus which I did not realize I would get is that it also runs the Overdrive application so that I can access library books directly from the device and not have to download and transfer them as I did with my Nook. I run all three of the major reading apps (Kindle, Nook and Overdrive) and all work well.I also use this as a web browser when I travel. It is far better than carrying a laptop, and much more readable than my smartphone for internet use. Sites seem to load well, and once you learn to not hold the device at the lower left hand corner the wireless connects easily and quickly, and is pretty stable once connected.Is it a heavy duty laptop replacement? No, but it does work well for browsing the internet, email (both yahoo and gmail), and it is a GREAT e-reader. It is far superior to my nook tablet.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I have the New iPad (aka the iPad 3) and my mom has the Kindle Fire so I have used that as well. I would have to say that overall the Galaxy Tab 2 has worked great. I received it about three days ago and I really like it. I like my iPad but I always thought it was a little too big. I liked the size of the Fire but I felt that the operating system on it was too limited. I decided the Galaxy Tab 2 7" looked right for the price. It's $50 more expensive than the Fire and $450 cheaper than my 64GB iPad 3. The screen is not as clear or bright as the iPad 3 and the video quality isn't as good as the Kindle Fire but I would say that it is not too bad. Don't expect excellent video quality because it's not but you can't expect all the bells and whistles of a high end tablet for only $250. I like the android ice cream sandwich OS. It looks nice on this device and it's a lot different than Amazon's version of android OS on the Kindle Fire. The interface is fairly smooth and intuitive. I haven't really had much delay when tapping on icons or sliding the screen. It's not quite as smooth and sensitive as the iPad but let's face it, if you are interested in buying the Galaxy Tab 2 7" it is probably for the price and you have ruled out the iPad for that reason or because maybe you have one already. I think the camera isn't too bad considering the Kindle Fire doesn't even have one. It is front and back. There is 8GB of internal memory with an expandable slot for up to 32GB micro SD card. That is a plus over the Fire. I find it easy to put music and movies onto the micro SD card, then put the card in the Galaxy Tab and it very quickly loads all of it onto the device to play. Easier than using the iTunes software if you ask me. The speakers on the Galaxy Tab are not as clear and crisp or even as loud as the iPad 3 but it gets loud enough for my taste. The sound is better and louder with headphones. With headphones it sounds pretty good. The Galaxy Tab 2 is more portable than the iPad because if you don't carry a bag of some sort to put it in you can still fit it in your front pocket. You wont be able to put much else in that pocket and it sticks out but you certainly can't do that with the iPad. As far as android play store, I am new to it. I'm used to iTunes but there are many of the same apps available on the play store. There is a Kindle app so you can still read your ebooks. As far as I can tell there is no way to play Amazon VOD for Prime members or otherwise. You also can't really sync your iTunes purchases to the Galaxy Tab 2 either. There are work arounds that allow you to put iTunes movies and music on the Tab but if that is something that interests you, you can always look that up. Surfing the web is easy and you can use firefox or opera if you want. I have read some reviews that say surfing the web on this tablet is slow but I have no found that to be the case. Web pages don't load quite as fast as the iPad but they load pretty quickly. I also read reviews about how the wifi connection isn't as strong on this device as it is on other tablets. That appears to be the case but it really hasn't resulted in slow internet speeds for me; and my internet provider doesn't provide me with very good upload and download speeds. Overall for the price I would say this is a good tablet. You can get a few cellphones like the Samsung Galaxy Note or the upcoming SIII for $200-$250 that are like this tablet but with better specs. However, that is the price you pay if you have an upgrade available otherwise without an upgrade you will pay retail of $500-$550. I think that even the Galaxy Note's 5.3" screen is a bit too small for a tablet though. The 7" screen is just right for an extra-portable tablet. I would recommend the Galaxy Tab 2 7". You can wait until July when supposedly a 7" Google Asus tablet will be released for $200. It is supposed to have better specs. Just FYI.

Lack of internal memory (just 4,5Gb free of 8Gb), and no option to install apps to external card. For us this is non issue we don't use a tablet to take picturesScreen- it is a bit reflective this would be a bigger problem if the screen wasn't so bright. I would say this will probably benefit from a slightly matted screen protector (this is just a hunched we haven't tried one yet)speaker placement- both of the speakers are on the bottom when you hold it in portrait mode this gives you good stereo sound, unfortunately when you hold it in landscape (the way most people will watch videos on it) this puts both the speakers on right side of the screen so not only do you get sound in only one ear you often also end up covering one of the speakers while your holding it.For what you get over the kindle I would have expected it to cost $100 more than the Fire.In the current market I consider this to be a bargain $249 buys one heck of a tablet!!!I hope this helps

tablet_galaxy_tab|So I've been looking for a tablet for a few months and I hadn't really seen anything that looked very spectacular. Either the tablets are priced at the cost of a mid-line notebook, or they don't provide near enough functionality/power for what I want. My primary needs for a tablet is to be able to read books, watch movies, and occasionally browse the internet and check email.To that end, this little tablet is great! I've tried bigger and more expensive tablets before, including the galaxy 10.1", but they always just seemed too big and clunky, and not very comfortable to hold. Plus their size made them a little less portable to carry around. This tablet on the other hand is comfortable to hold in both portrait and landscape mode, and is powerful enough to do anything I need it to. The fact that it was the same dual processor and nearly the same specs as the Galaxy 10.1" is pretty awesome!The only complaint that I have, is that although the screen is capacitative, and the device itself is highly responsive, the touch sensitivity seems a bit on the lower end. It's hardly noticeable the majority of the time, but when you're doing something touch intensive, you can tell.

tablet_galaxy_tab|Ok, the title of my review might be a little extreme but I stick by it. Anyone considering a Nook or Kindle should give this tablet a long, hard look. For an entry level, low cost tablet it has a lot of features the purpose built readers leave out. Not the least of which is this tablet is not tied to Barnes & Noble or Amazon. With this tablet you can get content from anywhere you want. Also, the Samsung has a GPS, front and rear cameras and a memory card slot. I believe the Nook has a memory slot too but the Kindle does not. The Samsung also has an IR blaster for controlling your home theater.My only other Android device is my nearly 2 year old Motorola Droid X phone and this tablet makes my phone feel very inadequate in almost every way. The tablets screen is bright, crisp and clear and it is very responsive with little to no lag. I believe that this screen has a higher pixel density than many of the 10" tablets as it is nearly the same resolution as the larger tablets in a smaller screen. I was holding out for a high res 10" tablet but decided to jump on this one because I was tired of waiting. I am not disappointed. It will be interesting to see if I end up preferring the 7" tablet after I use it a while. It is very light, small and portable and the screen real estate is really quite usable.Universal Remote:I just got my tablet last night and setup my home theater easily. I am disappointed with the interface of the supplied remote app though and will look around for a better version. But at least the tablet provides the ability to do it. To be fair though, I did not spend a lot of time with it so it may be better than I think.Kindle Reader:The Kindle reader app is very nice as the text is sharp and it turns pages very quickly. I think anyone coming from an e-ink based reader will enjoy using this tablet as a reader as well. My wife has the e-ink Kindle and has often wanted a back lit reader instead of using a book light. This screen will not be as readable outdoors though but I think most of my and my wife's reading is indoors so there is always a trade off.Streaming Music:I have not tried other media yet other than Pandora radio. You do get a little hiccup in the audio if you are surfing data intensive apps like Google Maps while you are streaming music. This may be the result of my pitiful DSL connection at home though. Will have to try it on a faster broadband connection sometime to see.Maps:Google Maps looks great on this device. Fortunately this tablet has a GPS chip so location based services/mapping are possible. It is a great size for mapping and once I get a 4G phone with WiFi ability, I will try it out as a navigation device. Hopefully Samsung will come out with a car dock for this tablet. Google Streetview is very nice on this tablet as well.Gmail:The Gmail app is extremely nice on this tablet. Even in portrait mode you get the folder list down the left side and your email in the currently selected folder displayed on the right. On my phone, you only get one folder at a time.Google Reader:I use Google Reader as my RSS app and it is very fast on the tablet compared to my phone. I go cross-eyed staring at my phone for very long but I can tell from my limited use of the reader on the tablet that the tablet will be great. The reader is really one of my most used apps and a big reason I wanted a tablet.Facebook:What can I say, Facebook is much nicer on a tablet than on the phone.Real Estate Apps:I am currently in the market to buy a house so I have the Realtor.com and Zillow apps. Both are much nicer on the tablet than on the phone. The photos on the Realtor app are much larger than what Zillow provides though which is odd. Photos on the phone are ok, but are hard to tell much about. With the tablet, the photos are much more usable.I may come back and add more to this review as I use the tablet more but in my 1 evening with it so far I can tell that I am going to love this tablet.**Update 5/9/2012**I got a chance to play with the tablet some more and have a few more observations to add.YouTube:YouTube looks great on this tablet. It will seamlessly flip from portrait to landscape without stopping the video. I personally think the YouTube app has a much better UI than the internet webpage.Speakers:The speakers are on the bottom of the tablet when the tablet is in portrait position. You have to watch that you don't rest it on your lap when listening to something using the speakers. If you turn it to landscape position, you have to watch that you don't cover the lower speaker with your hand. I found that if you hold the tablet with your fingers and cup the corner with the speaker it actually helps project the sound to you. I don't know where else they could put speakers as almost anywhere they are you will have to watch you don't cover them when you hold them so I won't complain about it.Games:What can I say, Angry Birds is awesome on a tablet. Words With Friends is nice as well. I haven't tried other games yet but expect them to look much better than they do on a phone.7" vs. 10" tablet:I don't know what to think about the size yet. I was trying to hold out for a high res 10" tablet that Samsung is rumored to be working on but got tired of waiting. I am really enjoying the light, small form factor of this 7" tablet though. So now I am not sure if I will want a 10" tablet or not. My brother has an iPad and that thing is a brick compared to this tablet.WiFi:I am a little worried about the people complaining about WiFi issues. So far mine has been working fine. It is indicating the same signal strength that my phone and laptop show. Maybe the problem is hit and miss but I hope if there is a real problem it is something a software/firmware update can resolve. But so far I have no complaints.Battery Life:I charged the tablet overnight and took it off the charger in the morning. I didn't use the tablet until I got home about 11 hours later. It was at 98% charge so it only drained 2% in 11 hours of no use. I used it for nearly 3 hours and it dropped to 66%. So 3 hours was about 1/3 of the battery life. That should translate to about 9 hours of battery life. I could turn the GPS off since it isn't needed most of the time, I also saw a tip about having it turn the WiFi off when in sleep mode and I have manually set the screen brightness to around 25% which is plenty bright indoors. Overall, I think it is going to have pretty decent battery life. I should get about 3 good evenings or a full day on a charge.**Update 5/21/2012**I have lived with the tablet for a couple weeks now and have a few more observations.Screen Sharpness:I got to compare it with my brother's iPad 2 this weekend and the screen on the Samsung is much, much sharper than the iPad. In fact, my dad's Nook was much sharper than the iPad with the Samsung being sharper than the Nook. The difference was amazing.Browser Speed:I was completely happy with the browsing speed of the Samsung until I compared it to the iPad. The iPad was much, much faster. Not sure why, but it is very noticeable. I installed the beta version of Google Chrome and it appears to be better than the built in browser but still not as fast as the iPad. But like I said, I was happy until I found out there was better.Connection Issues:I have observed the connection problem some people are reporting. If you hold the bottom left corner, the reception does drop down. As soon as you left off, it goes up 1 bar. But I also found out that my router was not operating at full strength. I had the old standby Linksys WRT54G but recently upgraded to an ASUS RT16N. As soon as I did, I noticed my cell phone and laptop were not showing nearly as strong reception as before. I am running Tomato on the router and discovered that you can turn up the signal strength. By default, Tomato is dialed back. My nearest neighbor is a quarter mile away so I dialed up to full strength. That upped my reception by 1 bar when covered and uncovered. So now I have better signal strength, even when I cover the antenna. I am not worried as I don't lose connection and it is showing a similar signal strength as my phone and laptop.Overall, I love this tablet.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|Like the first review, I wasn't planning on buying this today...but after playing with the Fire and Nook and being underwhelmed with their performance, I almost left Best Buy empty handed. We stumbled upon this, and I loved it. My main problem with the other two was that they seemed very sluggish (compared to the iPad2 my fianc&eacute; has). This on the other hand, is finally a quick and responsive 7" tablet at nearly the same price as Fire. Apps just launch, graphic intensive magazine pages flow, and the touch screen keyboard is easy to use with my relatively large hands. What's more is you aren't locked into anything, get a very accurate GPS, a smart remote, bluetooth, and a nice and bright screen. I'm sure I'll be adding more praises as time goes by.Only issue I'm having is that the compass is always 90 degrees off, it always points West instead of North. Sounds like a software issue, but time will tell. When using the GPS enabled apps, North is dead on (as you'd expect). That's the only reason I gave it four stars (I'd actually rate it a 4.8 or something, but I had to point out the issue).

tablet_galaxy_tab|I am a newbie to tablets so I can't compare to many different tablets except the Kindle, which I owned for about 3 days. Got the Kindle for a great deal, $139, special 1-day deal, refurbished direct from Amazon, 1-year warranty. Couldn't pass up this deal. Played with it for about 3-days. Everything about the Kindle was OK. Nothing great, did everything as advertised.Then I saw the SGT 2 7 advertised. There were 4 things that appealed to me as upgrades from the Kindle. Extra storage capability (huge), camera, availabilty to full android market and ICS (the newest android operating system). I decided if I was going to have a tablet, I wanted something I would be happy with for several years not just the next 6 months. So I pre-ordered the SGT 2 7 from Amazon. Was told I would recieve on the 25th but was actually delivered on the 24th, nice suprise. Have played with it for 3 days now, very impressed. Gave the Kindle to my wife. She loves it. Now my wife and daughter can swap Kindle experiences, whoo hoo.Review:Overall, love the tablet. Everybody has different reasons to get a tablet. This is simply a play toy for me. Do not need for business. Not looking for or needing the best tablet on the market.* Look and feel are great, lighter than the Kindle. Not difficult at all to hold and read book for an hour or so.* Screen is good! Everything looks clear and sharp. Not the best on the market but definitly OK for the price. Watched Neflix movie last night, picture and sound were great!* Touchscreen very responsive, minimal delay in opening apps.* Wi-Fi is good. Goes down from 4 bars to 2 bars when I go upstairs. Does not seem to effect reliability much.* Sound is great. Cranked the volume all the way up and had minimal distortion. Better that expected for this tablet.* Love the ability to set my screens up the way I want (unlike Kindle)* Many more apps available through Google Play then Amazon's App Store. Big plus.* Camera sucks. But I generally take pictures with a real camera (remember those). Good enough to take some pictures when you forgot you camera or your cell phone isn't working. No big deal to me.* I have heard people complain about the proprietary cable. Really, get a get a life. Cable is used to charge and connect to my laptop to xfer video/music files to tablet. Works perfect.* Only real issue is the remote control app. Started Peel setup, recognized my Vizio OK, could not recognize DTV box though. After 2 trys, app loaded up email to send trouble tik to Peel, pre-loaded all info, I just needed to enter DTV model no. Received email within an hour from Peel advising they had received my email and would look into it. 72 hours later no response. Not a Samsung issue but dissapointed Peel doesn't support there product better.Overall, very pleased with the tablet and confident I will get many years of enjoyment. If your in the market for a good tablet to play games, watch movies, listen to some music or surf the net, you will not be disappointed with the SGT 2 7.

tablet_galaxy_tab|So I did a lot of research; I've been in the market for a tablet for 5 or 6 weeks. You might notice a small amount of lag if you have tons of apps open (as I tend to do) and if you have a samsung/nexus smartphone as I do, you may notice the setup is not quite as set it and forget it as that. I am still looking for a couple of apps/widgets such as my photos from my google accoutn. I've heard other reviewers say that ICS seems a bit cramped on a device this small, and I can't say that I disagree, but for the most part it does what it says on the box and I imagine you'll run into the same situation on nearly any 7 inch tablet with a similar resolution. I wanted this device for Netflix when I'm on the road, Google Reader for cooking in the kitchen, and Evernote for taking notes in meetings. This does that and then some and you can't say that about the kindle fire. To me that's worth $50. I haven't run through an entire battery cycle yet, but so far it seems solid, moreso than my phone in fact due to the lack of cell connectivity drain.The BadAs I said, the GB of RAM, and downgraded processor are noticeable vs beefier models only if you have lots of apps open. Other reviewers have talked about the junky camera and I will echo that sentiment, though if you'd just doing instagram or something of that ilk I doubt you'll be disappointed.The Bottom LineI have no regrets about pulling the trigger on this device at this time. It does what i want, and I even got a logitech bluetooth keyboard. Easy to hookup. Easy to use. My wife took to it like a duck to water while watching TV last night. One other bonus, which I didn't know when I bought it was that it's incredibly easy to switch between accounts. If she has a recipe on her google reader, or in her email, the device is connected to both accounts at all times, so it's just a few taps to get there. Good stuff.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I bought this recently. It is a fine tablet, except for one MAJOR flaw. You will never be able to do anything with your SD card other than use it to hold pictures and videos. Even books cannot go on the card. Instead, Samsung creates a fake SD card space inside your limited 4gb free internal memory, and any ap that wants to access the SD card is sent there. I am unclear if this can be circumvented by rooting the device. As far as I can tell, even those aps that use music and videos may have a hard time accessing the sd card to get to them. So far I have only been able to copy stuff to the card via a PC and then if it is music or video the stock built-in ap can see it. But I am not sure even the normal music and video aps (like podcasting aps) can even write to the card (although that may be something I can overcome, I am not sure).Anyway, I am forced to describe the SD card feature on this tablet as essentially useless. And I think most of the 5 star raters are people who have not yet discovered the SD card limitation.For those who think differently:In answer to questions concerning their SD Card, here is the answer direct from Samsung on their support site:We apologize for the delay in addressing your question. If we are understanding you correctly, are you asking if you can copy/store apps on an SD card? If this is the case, apps can only stored on the internal memory only. The only thing that can be stored on the SD card is pictures, music & video files.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I periodically review the comments on this product, and am disappointed in some of the reasons given for providing low ratings; therefore I am submitting the following general information and suggestions.The following is a response from Michael S. to negative feedback on the SGT 2 7, recently published by an individual on Amazon.Michael is obviously a very savy guy, as his comments provide numerous tweaks that every SGT 2 owner (and most ICS users) should be vividly aware of. This info will truly rectify most problems and help you get the most out of your SGT 2 7".-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Edited by the author on May 2, 2012 6:55:32 PM PDTMichael S says:Right now my Tab 2 stats show the device is going 2 days 14 hours on a battery charge with 43% left. I use the Tab a few hours a day web surfing, doing research, checking and responding to emails. There are a number of ways to save juice so I'll mention a few that I use; which some, all, or none, may be applicable to others' situations:#1 - Go into "Settings", then "Wi-Fi". At the top right-hand side there is a icon of "3 bars and a small triangle" (basically an option button) click on it and when the "Advance" box shows on the screen, click it. Then click on "Keep Wi-Fi on during sleep" then check "only when plugged in". This will turn off the Wi-Fi when in sleep mode & running on the batteries. I use a login pattern to unlock my Tab and every time I unlock the screen it states "establishing Wi-Fi connection" I'm using WEP2 encryption on my network and the Tab starts Wi-Fi within seconds of waking from sleep. If one wants their Tab running multiple apps and to always have the most up-to-date information "pushed" to the device even while sleeping and running in battery mode, then one has to trade battery life for always-on information. The Wi-Fi will be active in sleep mode when it is plugged in. If you Always want the Wi-Fi off when in sleep mode then select "Never" instead of "Only when plugged in".#2 - I mostly use my Tab at home or at the office. I have both Wi-Fi network settings saved in the device, so I turned off "Network Notification" in the same area as # 1 above. This stops the Tab from periodically searching the Wi-Fi Network for "Open Networks". If I go out and want to connect to a Wi-fi hot spot, I simply turn this feature back on.Note: When you are in "Settings" and "Wi-Fi" mode you will notice that periodically the device shows "Scanning". Because you are in Wi-Fi mode, it scans to refresh the wi-fi networks its found, to help you connect to them. It does not continue to scan the network after you leave Wi-Fi settings, unless "Network Notification" is turn on, although the scan intervals may be different between the two modes.#3 - In "Settings" then " Location Services" make sure "Use GPS Satellites" is unchecked. This requires more battery and a clear view of the sky, and is really only useful outside.Those 3 settings will make a difference in battery consumption, and will not affect most people's use of the Tablet, although others' actual mileage may vary#4 - In addition, as I stated earlier, I mostly use my Tab 2 at work or home, so I always know where I am. Therefore, I also turn off "Use Wireless Networks" (Found in the "Location Service" section). This use Wi-Fi to help determine your location for Maps and such. If a App or Apps are running in the background and they have a location feature, this stop them from updating while the Tab is sitting idle, or your while your using other apps.#5- Because I use my Tab mostly at work or home and I know where I am, I usually turn-off GPS. Click on the "Clock" icon at the lower right-hand side, and then uncheck "GPS". If I ever need it, I quickly turn it back on.#6- In "Settings" "Account and Sync" I have "Auto Sync" turned off. I turn it on when it's plugged in and then have it Sync. Then I turn if off once its done charging and back on battery power. I usually sync only 1-2 per week, same as my Skyrocket.#7- Next, in "Settings" then "Developer Options" (I don't run a bunch of Apps and don't use a lot of "Notifications") so I check the box "Do not Keep Activities" This means when I leave an App, ICS closes the app instead of letting it run in the background, possibly sucking more juice. I saved this one for last, as it impacts the tablet operation the most. If a person uses "Notifications" or likes to multitask with many apps running and want to quickly switch between them, then thus option is not useful. What it does do is free one up from going into "Task Manager" and closing down a bunch of Apps you thought you closed but were only minimized when you exit-ed the App.#8- Lastly, Usually the biggest drain on the battery is the display. Currently under "Battery" in "Settings" the Display has consumed 65%, with the next closest item "Internet" at 19%, and "Android System" & "Android OS" at 5% each, with everything else at less than 5% combined. Unfortunately, I'm unable to recommend the "Auto-Display" mode, as for me, it makes the display too dark most of the time (click on the "Clock" icon and then check the "Auto" box to engage).I keep the display setting at about 20-25% as I mostly use the tab 2 indoors. As mentioned above, others' actual mileage may vary with Auto-Display turned on. I use Auto-Display on my Skyrocket, as I use it equally indoors and outdoors. When indoors, I find Auto-Display too dark also, but I live with it because when using the Skyrocket outdoors I find the Auto-Display is a must to see the display in bright sunlight, and therefore watch the battery drain accordingly. To compensation for this, I replaced the stock battery (1,850 mAh) with an extended battery (2,250 mAh) for a 22% capacity increase. This is obviously not a option on the Tab 2.(END OF QUOTE)----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Let me add, in addition, If one buys this tablet expecting to play graphics intensive action games then that person will be disappointed. That is not what these 7" tablets are designed for. Also, be aware that this is a transition period in the development of Android software; wherein developers are having to convert their programs to the new operating system (ICS), and this has resulted in some minor problem being experienced on all phones and tablets converting to ICS. The fact is, however that ICS is a big improvement over the preceding Operating Systems; and the Galaxy Tab 2 7" is a very good tablet for the money. THEY ALL HAVE SOME LIMITATIONS!Hope this is of help!! I know it was to me, and I own five tablets.__________________CbillTransformers (2), Xoom, Nook Color (MicroSD root), Galaxy 7+(Returned),Galaxy Tab 2, Optimus V (root)
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|This is my first tablet and I bought it mainly for college purposes. In addition to owning hard copies of my textbooks, I also have pdf files of them and needed a device I could save and open them (instead of lugging around 25 lbs of books). I also needed to browse the internet as some of my homework is online and needed flash support for the occasional cramster/chegg help. I HATE having to use the library's computers on campus. The people are a distraction, but I do not want to lug around my laptop or deal with it's crappy battery. Once I found apps I realized I needed to download Adobe Flash Player. Done. Website now works properly.Next, I could not figure out how to connect the tablet to my pc. I tried using Samsung Kies with no luck. It would not connect. So, before I logged into Dropbox on the tablet, I emailed myself the links for the textbook pdf's. When I opened the links, the files were downloaded onto the tablet. I cannot figure out how to officially store them somewhere, but they are under "Downloads" so I can access them w/o internet connection.At first I opened the pdf's with Polaris Office and they were hard to navigate and some parts of the Calculus book did not display right. I opened with Amazon Kindle and soooooo much better! Easier to navigate and everything displayed correctly. tablet_galaxy_tab|Have been using a friend's iPad 2, and really like it -but- it's a PITA to carry around. tablet_galaxy_tab|I am what you would call a power user. I was looking for a 7 inch tablet after using and returning an ASUS Transformer due to its size and lack of video codecs. I needed a small tablet to read books, surf the web, play games, take class notes, and watch videos. After being disappointed at the Amazon locked Kindle Fire, not wanting to pay a high premium for an iPad, and the Nexus 7 lacking an expandable storage option, I found the Tab 2 7.0 a worthy tablet that hits all the points important to me.- Affordable. After being released at a good price of $250 this tablet has hit the magical $199 price point shipped on Amazon. An amazing price for what you get.- Launched with Android 4.0.4 but now has Android 4.1 Jelly Bean! This update has made the tablet quicker and much more responsive due to Project Butter. The layout has changed and is now more consistent between different devices. Google Apps are updated with better performance. Google Now shows cards based on your location and your Google searches. A much need update has breathed new life into this tablet. Update is available automatically on start up or via Settings, Software, Software Update.- Battery Life and Performance. I easily get 6.5 hours of "on screen time" for heavy use and have gone a couple of days without needing a charge. Over 8 hours for video (will vary due to brightness). An excellent duration. YMMV. With a TI OMAP 4430 Dual Core Processor, Performance is good. It is an older processor to keep the price low but is more than capable of running this tablet. No issues. Power Saver Mode provides longer battery without any noticeable decrease in performance. Brightness is allowed to be much darker than normal. Good for night reading.- Expandable Storage. With 8GB of internal storage and about half user-accessible, expandable storage is important for those with a big library of music and videos. I can store all my shows and movies on any size microSD. The tablet also plays MKVs, Xvid, and other important video formats with srt embedded or external subs support in the default Video Player and MX Player. Tested 720p. I am currently using a 16GB microSD Class 10 card.- Features. WiFi, Bluetooth, GPS, Front and Rear Cameras(Google Hangout is great), Good Dual Core Processor (TI OMAP 4430), 1 GB RAM, 4.5GB user accessible internal memory for apps, microSD Slot, and an IR Blaster (Peel App controls my TV and DVR flawlessly(Samsung HDTV + RCN Motorola DVR)).- The Tablet. Great build. Good screen at 7" and 1024 by 600 resolution. Easy to hold. Lightweight.The cons that are easily overlooked- Proprietary charge cable (prefer microUSB)- Camera quality is not very good (I would never use a tablet as a camera... Good for QR Codes and video chat though!)Like I said this tablet hits all the points important to me. Couldn't ask for a more balanced tablet in terms of hardware, software, price, and features. At $199 as of Jan 16, 2012, I highly recommend this tablet.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I love this tablet! I purchased two right after the new year and they have been going strong since. Maybe that seems crazy, but I've heard some horror stories about off-brand tablets becoming crap within a few weeks. This tablet has a lot of internal memory and runs android. The battery keeps its charge well, and I haven't had any issues with playback of movies or music, and it plays apps perfectly. I have probably downloaded approximately 20 apps and the system hasn't slowed at all. The WiFi works well, when I take it away from home and come back, it is almost instantaneously picking up the signal. It almost never loses the connection, even when my ps3 or my laptop do.If you are looking to buy a tablet and you aren't sure which one to buy; decide what you want it to do first. Are you working or playing? Are you familiar with android or mac? Android is super easy to use, and the app store is very extensive, with tons of free apps. You need to decide how much you want to spend, long term. Apple products may be top-of-the-line, but they are priced accordingly, and so are their warranties, if you want one. Even after your initial purchase, you will still have to buy a case, possibly you might need a memory card, or a replacement power cord, and you might not want to pay $50-100. If you decide you want to go with android, now you have a variety of choices. Your first consideration should be WHICH version of android you want. This Samsung runs 4.1.1, but I've seen lots of off-brand that only have 2.1, and that OS came out a few years ago. The higher the number, the newer the OS and the better your tablet will work, and run apps especially. I don't recommend the 2.1, I used to have it on my phone and you can't save apps to external storage. At the very least, look for 2.3. There's also the kindle to consider, they run a certain android OS that has been modified for Amazon, and has exclusive rights on new adobe flash software. This is a definite perk for the kindle, but it was still out of my price range. Plus, while it can be so upsetting to miss out on the random flash ads (haha), the Samsung still plays videos from the internet just fine, as well as several different kinds of video files downloaded from a computer to the external card.After looking at the OS, you need to decide how much internal memory you want. The literal total for the Samsung is 4.49 gb. Of which I still have 2.90 gb free. Now, I am using 1 whole gb for apps, but I mostly play games and they can be large, and when you have this much memory, you don't have to constantly move them to your external card. I could potentially get a lot of that space back if I wanted to. Having enough internal memory is VERY IMPORTANT; you will want to throw your tablet in the street and crush it with your car if you don't have enough. It will constantly tell you that the storage is low, and you won't be able to even update your current apps. I would say, depending on your usage plans, you will want at least, AT LEAST, 2 gb, but even that's on the low side. If you are going to read, play games, and be on the internet a lot, you will want more.Next, decide how big you want this sucker to be. I love this 7 inch tablet, and I wouldn't want a larger one. Yet again it depends on what you want it for. I like that I can just throw this in my purse or school bag. The 10 inch ones are too big for my tastes.After these major considerations, here's the other thing about tablet buying that you may want to think about. My girlfriend received an off brand tablet for Christmas, and we looked, and looked, and looked for a good case for it. Nada. There are so many different tablets out now, a saturated market, while the accessories are about as easy to find as water in the desert; if you don't have a Kindle, an iPad, or a Nook. This may sound crazy, but in the end, what made me get this tablet was the fact that I could get a good, solid case made specifically for it, at a reasonable price. I was not going to spend several hundred (I bought 2, remember) dollars on tablets, only to break mine within a week. I'm a huge klutz, so I have to think ahead. This is a great tablet, I highly recommend it!
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|I started with a Kindle Fire and was sorely disappointed by how much it lagged, so I exchanged it for the Samsung. I am a HUGE fan of Samsung and have always felt they produce a good quality product. The Galaxy worked great ... at first. The camera in it was good, the surfing was fast (with Chrome), my apps ran a lot smoother than they had on the Fire, the battery life wasn't stellar, but overall I was happy with my purchase. After 3 weeks, however, I went to plug it in and it wouldn't charge at all. Luckily, I was still within my 30 day return window with Amazon and I simply exchanged it. That process was quick, they sent me a new one which arrived in a couple of days (I didn't have to wait for them to get the defective one). I got the new one, got it all updated, apps redownloaded and had it up and running in no time. That same night, I finished using it, shut it off and plugged it in to charge. Next morning, I go to turn on the tablet and its been completely reset to factory defaults, I had to re-enter my information, redownload the apps, etc. Figured it was just a fluke, but sure enough, the next time I turned it back on after turning it off, it did the same thing again. I packed it back up and sent it back to Amazon within 2 days of getting it. This time I've just gotten a refund. I am sadly disappointed. For the "value tabs" I felt this was the best one available, especially with the option to add a memory card (the Nexus 7 and Kindle Fire don't). Guess, I'm waiting a little longer to find a great tablet.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I did a few weeks' worth of searching and comparing before I bought The Tab 2 7.0, and this tablet offers more bang for the buck than any other tablet in its size and price point. With the right apps, this tab really shines. I find the rear camera useful for bar code and QR scanning without issue using the free Barcode Scanner app (the one with a bar code icon with a red triangle in the center), and also use the Paper Camera, DSLR and Pixlr-o-matic apps which get the most out of the camera's abilities. While the rear cam is only a 3 megapixel, it's still useful. If I want to take better photos, I have dedicated cameras but this does quite well in a pinch, and will also shoot 720p video for those times when you're caught without a camera or camcorder. The front camera is useful for using Skype or other comm apps. The speakers sound remarkably well for being so tiny, but they are both at the end of the tablet while holding it landscape mode. Not a problem. Still, for listening while watching movies or Wifi FM radio (TuneIn radio app), I'll use either my Sennheiser CX400 or Audeo Phonak ear buds. I installed PowerAmp and am impressed with the sound quality while listening to downloaded music and FM; separation and imaging capabilities, even while plugged into my run of the mill Creative T20 speakers at work was startling. It was like having much better speakers! Video while watching streaming Netflix or converted mp4s is excellent and for a 7" screen, I didn't find the resolution lacking and the colors were saturated but not unrealistic, using the built-in Netflix app, the native video player app or MX Player Pro. I did not notice any light bleed and the blacks were black, not dark gray. It was easy getting caught up in a 2-hour movie while watching it on this Tab. Wifi connection is instant, both at home and on public networks and have not dropped any connections, remaining strong even while straying 50-60 feet from my home router. I think most issues with wi-fi is having "same channel" interference from other routers in the neighborhood, so I installed the free app Wifi Analyzer (if it's not here, check the goggle Play store), which will let you know what channels the other routers are using as well as signal strength, so you can plan accordingly which channel to use with your own router. GPS works fine; I was able to get 8-meter accuracy while using Goggle Maps. Goggle Sky is also fun to use. I also use GPS Test Plus from the Play store. eWeather HD by Elecont is an awesome weather app, also with HD radar and even earthquake features, and uses either GPS or you can punch in a ZIP code. I installed a SanDisk 32GB MicroSDHC card, and as for transferring data to or from the laptop, you can use either the supplied USB cable that comes with the charger, but I prefer using WiFi File Explorer Pro (also at the Play store) which provides an easy Web interface from a desktop or laptop, but it's only secure when using it at home (provided you're using an encrypted wireless connection, right?) which makes for easy transfers and avoids the hassle of having to use the restrictive length of a USB cable; ES File Explorer also works fine. As for moving apps to the external SD, it's not happening (yet) which can be an issue, since the ShadowGun game app alone is over 450mb once the data is downloaded for the game (and by the way, ShadowGun plays fine on the dual core TI OMAP processors on the Tab 2). There are also astronomical apps which can go from 500mb - 1GB with the downloaded data (SkySafari Plus and SkySafari Pro) so there is somewhat cause for alarm, as out of the 8GB of memory this tablet has, there's only around 4GB free when it comes new out of the box. I've checked the forums, and there is much concern regarding not being able to move apps from internal memory to the external SD (MicroSDHC) card. Some think it's a Samsung issue, while other think it's because Goggle (the developers of Android) wants people to use the cloud for storage needs. With Android releases through version 3 it wasn't an issue saving apps to the external memory card, but beginning with version 4 (Ice Cream Sandwich) the code changed as far as permissions went, so I'll quote Moderator Blast (thanks!) from the Galaxy Tab forum:"Turns out Google had for some reason since Honeycomb 3.2 decided to split the write permissions for the internal memory (the path of which is confusingly named /mnt/sdcard) and external SD card memory (the path being /mnt/sdcard/extStorages/SdCard) into WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE and WRITE_MEDIA_STORAGE respectively.Apps to SDThe SD card is mounted r/w, but the owning group is media_rw which is linked to the WRITE_MEDIA_STORAGE permission.Unfortunately, this permission was not required for access to the external sdcard prior to 3.2 so most file management utilities do not request it when they run...meaning they only have read access to the card. Before Honeycomb 3.2, apps only had to request for the permission WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE and they would have write access to both the internal and external so-called "sdcard" sets of memory.Now, apps have to request for WRITE_MEDIA_STORAGE if they want to write to the external SD card, but many of them have not yet been updated to do so yet. This affects file managers / explorer / compression utility type apps most often because users would tend to use them to copy / move / zip files within the file system. As for Ice Cream Sandwich, latest reports are that, yes, they are going to continue with this separate permission model.Hopefully in the future, more apps would have been amended to include the necessary permission/security settings." So as you can see, most developers are just not aware of this change while writing apps for the current versions of Android, but hopefully they will catch on soon. For now, the only way to circumvent some of the bloat is to root the tablet, but I see some users experiencing issues after doing this, and rooting the tab will void the warranty (not to mention the possibility of "bricking" it, or rendering it useless), and since Samsung hasn't made their stock firmware available as a back up solution, rooting for me is out of the question. The Tab 2 makes a fine e-book reader. The included Kindle app works well, and the text is very sharp, clean and easy to read - to the point where I've already read 5 books since having the tablet in less than a month. It's just a pleasure to read with. You can also turn off GPS, Wifi, Sync and screen rotation to save on the battery. The new 4.04 release for Ice Cream Sandwich released by Samsung this past week in an update also adds some power saving features and a few other enhancements (it shipped with 4.03 in June when I received it). As for Web browsing, I use Dolphin HD which is fast, allows me to keep multiple tabs open while not slowing down the browsing, and allows me to browse Websites in native Desktop mode (with the Dolphin Desktop add-on); otherwise some sites will sense that you're using a mobile device and causes frustration while having to view in a different style than what you're normally used to. But browsing the Web is fast and enjoyable; pinch-to-zoom is quick and effortless with no lag. YouTube also works and plays fine. Typing on a device this size can cause frustration or outright expletives (I've experienced both), and after much research for alternate keyboard apps, I downloaded the Thumbs Plus keyboard app (the Play store) and never looked back. It costs a few dollars, but rest assured it's very much worth it. It's a real joy to use, and a no-brainer with any Android tablet.Oh, and grab a matte finish (non-glare) screen protector; you'll find them if you look and it's really worth the time finding one, as it turns the screen from it's default mirror finish into a screen that's a pleasure to work with and doesn't affect brightness or clarity. I like it so much that when I ordered the Tab I also ordered the Skinomi screen protector, which has a gloss finish. The Skinomi is still sitting in the box unused.If I can think of anything else to add, I'll update this review. Until then, I'm very happy with my purchase of the Galaxy Tab 2 7.0.EDIT 7/25/2012 - I've read some reviews where the length of the charging cable is short (and it is). What I've done is attach a ten foot USB extension cable between the end of Samsung's charging cable and the USB port on the actual AC charger and it works fine for charging (although I haven't tried copying or moving data) AmazonBasics USB 2.0 A-Male to A-Female Extension Cable (9.8 Feet/3.0 Meters). I find this to be a much less expensive solution rather than buying a Khomo 6' cable.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|I've been an Android user for a long time...I was looking for a tablet to read some books and have a bigger screen for some of my applications since I'm a computer tech and I work using remote software and other applications...after a lot of research and having a Samsung Galaxy S2 phone for a year (and extremely happy with it) I decided to go for the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0...Had it original for one day...second day I decided to root (running original stock ICS rooted) it to get the same advantages I had in my phone; like: CPU control, able to dim the screen lower than factory settings, uninstall bloatware, etc...After all the tweaks battery lasts 2.5 days (average of 4 hours a day of reading, browsing, playing games...plus receiving emails and using software for text messages), software works like a charm with no lag or freeze...widgets work great, been using the stock keyboard for now but looking for a more detailed one...charging time is normal for a large battery...screen size is great and device not heavy at all...screen resolution and colors are very clear and nice with a lot of details...tried a couple of movies and hi def pictures in it with great results...everything is really good...My advice and only concern use headphones for movies or landscape games because of the speakers placed at the bottom of the device.Overall 5 stars and great device!!!

tablet_galaxy_tab|Have owned an iPhone for 2+ years now, an Android 2.2 phone - and recently bought the Kindle Fire for my wife. I don't want to be locked or tied down - which is my experience with the Apple OS. The OS just works ... but I wanted more freedom. I am agnostic when it comes to operating systems.Here are my assessments on the Tab 2 after almost a week.Pluses:1. Screen is bright even at 50% which is my current setting.2. 2 cameras - front and back. Though I won't be using this for video calls soon, it is good to have the flexibility. For video calls, the resolution is good enough. I still plan on using a real digital camera for videos and stills. I want to have full control over the ISO, shutter speed, aperture etc.3. The micro-SD slot is a big bonus for me. My wife's Fire did not have this. For my use case - which is keeping all my files local, I need that expandability. I use google drive only for backup.4. Price is very competitive over the Fire (which I bought a week apart). Again, my wife wants an easy to use reader with the option of other 'screened' apps - so the Fire is perfect for her. For $50 more, I get 2 cameras, expandability - and more configurable experience.5. I was able to install the Amazon App Store (app). This will replace the Samsung one which I didn't find too appealing for someone who already has an existing Prime account. Now I get a free app a day!6. (Update) I just installed the Amazon Apps Appstore ... which basically gives me access (same look and feel) to the Fire's ecosystem of apps.Cons: (Not weighed)1. Charging is pretty slow - I am just used to my iPhone and Android phone with less than 2000mAH batteries - hence, faster to recharge. The Tab 2 came with a 4000+mAH battery - hence, it takes longer.2. Out of the box, you cannot load apps on the SD card. This is a limitation on the OS.3. Unless you change your power settings, the default settings will drain the Tab 2 pretty quick.4. The Samsung apps cannot be uninstalled individually. Some are good - others are so-so - luckily, they don't take up too much space - so until I find a replacement for all of the individual bloatware, I will keep them.5. The power switch/select button is too close to the volume controls. They should be spaced further apart as I have often inadvertently pressed it while simply holding the tab or changing the volume.6. Samsung uses a proprietary connector (unlike the Fire which uses a standard micro-USB).7. When charging, there is no indicator light to show that the battery is indeed charging (unlike the Fire). You would need to turn the tab on - and verify it is indeed charging.8. This is lighter than the Fire --- but still, for a 7 inch tablet, I expected something a little bit lighter.I am being picky here ... wanted to be as objective as possible.I did look at the Acer and Lenovo tablets over at BB. The Lenovo would constantly flicker - while the Acer had no power. But based on reviews and ratings (and the fact that I get ICS 4.0 at $249), I went with the Tab 2. For my use cases, this is the perfect tablet for me.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I started looking for a replacement for my 2 year old B&N NOOK Color a couple of weeks ago. One local store had the Nexus 7 and this Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0. Another store had the Acer Iconia A110. My choice was between these 3. I will begin with the one that I first rejected.Nexus 7 - The Nexus 7 was perhaps the best compromise of the 3, but the large number of reviews on many shopping sites that described problems and poor support from Asus and Google made me eventually eliminate it. I liked the better screen resolution and the speed with the quad core processor, but no microSD slot and the reported problems and failures kicked it out as a choice. I didn't want to take a chance of getting a bad one and I didn't want to have to open it up to fix loose screws and such.Acer Iconia A110 - This one could have easily been my final pick, but the screen knocked it off. Just a relatively small amount of offset from straight on and the screen dimmed. It not only dimmed, but the colors also changed, which I read is common with TN screens. My 2 year old NOOK has a better screen in my opinion. It had the same quad core processor as the Nexus 7 and the same lower screen resolution as the Tab 2 7.0, so it was in the middle as far as those attributes. It also has a microSD slot.Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 - The Tab 2 falls short of the Nexus 7 in the processor and screen resolution. However, the Quadrant score is not that much slower than the Nexus 7. In one review site comparison, the Nexus 7 had a quadrant score of 3501, while the Tab 2 had a score of 2840. After loading all of my apps, I ran Quadrant twice and the lowest score that I got on my new Tab 2 was 3131. Not enough of a difference to matter. I found rooted NOOK Color reviews and they got Quadrant scores of around 950, so the Tab 2 is a big improvement over that.The Tab 2 has the following advantages over the others:- The screen is better than the Acer and even slightly better than the Nexus, even though the Nexus has a better resolution.- It has the memory expansion that the Nexus doesn't.- It has the best speakers by a small amount.- I managed to get it for slightly less cost than the other 2, but that didn't factor in my choice.So far I really like this tablet after only using it for 2 days. My microSDHC cards and OTG cable adapter haven't arrived yet, so I haven't been able to check out the functionality of those. I've loaded Firefox and side loaded Flash 11 and that is working fine with Jelly Bean. AirDroid works fine for transferring files over my wifi network. Even though I don't plan on using the Bluetooth capability, I will have to pair one of my headphones to see if it works.Some people like the simpleness of stock Android, but I actually prefer the added features of Samsung's Touch Wiz. I'd prefer not having the added Samsung apps, but I will just have to ignore them. I don't want to root the tablet, as I will probably just brick it.Once I check out the MicroSD and OTG cable when they both arrive in a week or so and check Bluetooth, I will update this review. So far I'm happy with my choice of 7 inch tablet.Update 2 days later: I mated my old Motorola S305 stereo headphones fine and they worked with no problems. I discovered that I had a long unused microSD - 256MB. I plugged it in and tried to load some photos using AirDroid and AirDroid would not find the external card. A Google search found that this is a problem with AirDroid with Jelly Bean, so not a tablet problem. I installed the wifi file transfer app and was easily able to transfer files to the external card. It's not quite as nice as AirDroid, but it works fine. I'm still waiting for the microSDHC and the OTG cable.Update 5 days later: I received the microSDHC and OTG cable. No problem with either. I used to OTG cable to mount a USB flash drive and a mouse. Both worked with no problem.Update 7 days later: I almost forgot about the GPS function. I just turned GPS on for the first time and loaded the GPS Status app. I'm impressed. It quickly (about 1 minute) found and locked onto 16 satellites while in the house. By comparison, my HTC Incredible 2 phone found no satellites in the same time and finally locked on to only 9 before fluttering between 7 and 9. I don't think that I have ever seen either my old Droid or my current Incredible 2 ever get near locking onto 16 satellites, even outdoors.

They asked for a detailed description and I provided it and they sent a UPS label for me to ship the device back. About 2 weeks later I got an email that my device was fixed. A few days later my tablet arrived and I was shocked to see it was just stuck into a bigger box with no additional packing. I fire the device up and the first time the screen went off, same exact issue! WOW, thanks.If you get a good device you will probably be happy with it. If you have issues, good luck actually getting it fixed. I'm very disappointed in Samsung and the way they are handling this. At least offer me a replacement since they apparently can't fix mine. Not happy it was damaged either.UPDATE: I sent an email to the president of Samsung North America and got a call from someone in his office. She reviewed my case and said she would ship me a new Galaxy 2 7" tablet as soon as my old one arrived at repair. She assured me this would be a new, sealed device. Today she notified me that it shipped from CA today. I'm very happy that they went the extra mile for me. I will report back once I receive the replacement and ensure it is working properly. Nice job Samsung!UPDATE: I have been using the new replacement unit for about a month now. No issues with the new unit so far. As I recall, unit one went dead at 36 days so let's see if this one will works in a week.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I have an aging iPad 1, and have been looking for suitable alternatives. First I tried the Kindle Fire. It's a nice device, but the restrictions from Amazon make the iPad look positively open source. In retrospect, I think that for what a 7 inch device should do, it's a great buy. That, after having the galaxy for a month. I have an android phone, have had a rooted Nook Color, and a Wooted Xoom - so I think I've tested enough varied waters to avoid the inevitable fanboy accusation.I do have pros and cons for the device, but first I have to say that part of the difficulties I've had have to do with expectations. While I didn't expect a 7 inch device to do what a 10 inch device can (I do a fair amount of remote computing) I don't think that I had a good idea what to realistically do with the smaller form factor. At the end of the day, I think that the 7 inch tablet is best as a fancy e-reader, and to that extent, the Fire might be the better tab, more for what it doesn't do than what either of these devices can do with a lot of persistence. Perhaps it's best to have a restricted set of well performed functions in a limited space. I'm sure that depends on the user - I don't have to travel much, so portability isn't as big a deal as usability.Pros:Very thin and attractiveGood priceNice screen with accurate colorsCamera -I didn't use it, but it's thereMinimal bloatMicroSD slot (though it is a bear to insert a card in there)Video player was excellent, seemed to play everything, including mkvs.Cons::MTP instead of Mass storage was an absolute fail. It doesn't mount on XP or OSX, and really was a pain even on Win7 (it worked after I installed Kies). What I ended up doing was using File Expert on the Samsung and FTPing from whatever. Just silly.Wireless drops occasionally, usually on waking.Music - the native player doesn't read m4a's. You have to use something like PowerAmp, which is a great product. This isn't my idea of "open" especially when the video player can handle so many codecs. And while we're on this, Google music doesn't accept m4a's either. I don't understand this. Even Amazon will let me upload various music formats to their cloud player. I realize this isn't Samsung's fault. But still...ICS - still a mish mash mess of GUI. Even on a 7 inch screen, you are tapping in all different directions to achieve a goal. The basic soft-key elements are fine and usually helpful, but I don't get the immutable dock, the applications icon in the upper right corner, and the horrible screen capture icon (I think this was added by Samsung). And lastly, though I am clearly the only person bothered by this, is the blue line that permeates all screen elements (it's there to separate the dock from the main screen). It's there even for video. All the video and photos have a blue line on the bottom. Really?As an e-reader it was fine. Nice to have Kindle, Nook, Kobo, on the same device in one small form factor. Due to it's thin-ness, it is hard to hold for a long time, but I think a good case would help.I think that if I was going to take on this size device again, it would be more along the lines of the Fire - a limited device that performs a few tasks well, and leave the more complicated tasking to larger devices. My hope is that the retina display type screens start appearing on more devices which should improve the reading experience even more, and that my expectations for a small devices extend to reading, some video and music, and light emailing. It will be interesting to see how the Google Nexus tabs compare in a couple of months.
