tablet_galaxy_tab|Hi,I was watching (or trying) to watch some YouTube videos last night wondering why my Tab 2 kept pending the videos. I thought at first it was my internet connection but then i was able to watch the same video on my Samsung Galaxy S2 cellphone and it worked. After i tried to use my Tab 2 again and then it went dead. I thought it was some gliche so i tried to turn it on again using the power button and nothing worked. I set it aside and went to bed, woke up the next day and tried to turn it on again and nada.Of course, next morning, i am freaking out now &#34;hoping&#34; i didn't get some product that just went ka-put. I plugged it in to charge and turn it on, again nada. I went online and saw someone else's instructions that I should hold it for a full 30-seconds....i tried that and it worked! It popped up the battery showing it totally drained, so at least i felt better knowing it really was just dead. I had read another review saying they had the same similar problems and they didn't realize it went dead due to the battery getting drained from watching a video or some file they were downloading that just happened to take a very long time, so long that on a lower battery already it just drained the entire thing.Other than that I absolutely LOVE this thing. Wish it had flash though....there are some websites i can't access because there is no flash or JavaScript on this thing...other than that i am so glad i got the 7&#34; screen and not the 10&#34;....sometimes i feel like i could have even done with something smaller than 7&#34;....maybe more like 5 or 6&#34; just because i am a woman and have small hands.

tablet_galaxy_tab|My iPad 1 was starting to show its age, so I decided it was time for something newer. I had gone to Best Buy with the intention of purchasing a Kindle Fire, but after playing with it I just wasn't feeling it. I didn't like the heavily modified version of Android they run, and not having an SD card seems like a really odd decision to make. I was set to buy a bigger and more expensive tablet when I saw the display for the Tab 2 set off away from the other tablets, so I wandered over and checked it out, and I liked it immediately.The form factor is nice. I loved the large size of my iPad, but for reading in bed it is a bit too large and heavy. I dealt with it because its a fantastic device, but now that it was time to get a new one, I opted for something a little smaller.The only issues I have come across is that the stock UI can be a little laggy, so I opted to use a 3rd party launcher which immediately fixed the problem. The other problem seems to be more with Android and less with Samsung, but the new MTP protocol that is used to transfer files to your computer does not work natively with Mac/OS X, and you have to get a piece of software from google to do this. However even with the software my computer still won't recognize the device at all. The only way I can get files on and off my device is either with a SD card, or using a program that lets me connect wirelessly via an FTP application. Is it the end of the world? No. Is it a slight inconvenience? Yes.Aside from those two small issues this thing has performed well and I am really enjoying it.

tablet_galaxy_tab|First of all, I'm writing this review on my Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 :DFirst off, I'll talk about delivery.The Tablet was shipped right away (within 24 hours) of my purchasing it. The package arrived 2 days later (I'm on Amazon Prime) in wonderful condition. The shipping box as well as the original box were undamaged. The original box was also adequately protected.5/5 for shipping.Next I'll talk about the device.I've looked at a few other reviews, and I am confused as to why people complain about certain features. (such as the quality of the speakers, which aren't even that bad, or other various complaints over details) seriously people? It's a $200 Tablet that I find rivals other Tabs hundreds of dollars more than it. With this Tablet, you get what you pay for AND more.Perhaps my favorite feature is the external SD card (WARNING! THE EXTERNAL SD CARD WILL NOT STORE APPS. Due to piracy and licensing, apps on tablets are restricted to internal memory only.) despite not being able to store apps, I find the memory card suits my personality. I am a movie watcher and enjoy watching movies anywhere I go when I have free time (Road trips with family, doctors appointments, long lines at the college bookstore hahaha) thanks to my 32 GB SD card, I can have more than enough movies to keep me busy.I won't bore any readers with technical lingo and phrases describing the processing power and so on. Just know that this Tablet won't disappoint! (Unless you have unrealistic views on how far $200 can really go)Call me biased, but I would give this Tab a 5/5 and day of the week! Definitely worth the price :)

Small enough to easily carry around with you but definitely big enough to do everything you need easier than on your smartphone. I haven't had any issues with lagging, it is fast and reliable. Runs great, screen is great, sound is great. I seriously have yet to find a flaw with this tablet at all. Granted, I'm not a high end techie either, but enough to know that this is definitely worth the price and a great product. I also bought this accessory bundle at the same time,CrazyOnDigital Purple Stand Leather Case with Charger and Screen Protector For Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 (6-item). Screen protector is wonderful, I prefer using it than to the actual screen itself, seems my finger glides over it easier. The case is great as well, plus the extra chargers are nice to have, especially the car charger. I definitely would recommend buying the two together, that way you have all the accessories you need. I really can't think of anything else to say except if you are debating over which tablet to get, stop and just get this one, you won't regret it!

tablet_galaxy_tab|I purchased one of these from another vendor which has no impact on this review. I got to know it and really loved it. It is a HUGE step up from the Kindle. I was never able to register it on the Samsung Web Site due to numerous bugs. I have the SD card and USB adapters which expand the capabilities greatly. The manual is very thorough and complete compared to most.All was well until 1/2013 when I turned it on and it stated that it needed to do an update. It gave no information as to what the update was, it just assured you that your data and settings would be saved. After about an hour it completed and rebooted. I didn't even recognize it. All my home screens were wiped clean and it's touch controls were a completely different layout. My apps were still there in the app drawer is all there was from my original setup. Searching the web, a number of people had stated that Samsung pushed an Android upgrade to 4.1.1 which did the same thing I experienced. Sure enough I was at a different version of Android, so tried emailing Samsung but there was a web site bug there too, you cannot find this model in the email form and cannot send if you don't. So I called Samsung Support to find out how to get the manual for this version as the one on their web site was for the version I purchased 2 months earlier. They said they don't have one and have no idea if one is coming but I would be emailed when it becomes available. How's that for customer support?!I don't mean there are a few cosmetic changes, EVERYTHING changed, browser, home screen layouts, where to find notifications and settings and now all the home screens were split. I had to search the web for tutorials on how to use 4.1.1. They are of some generic help pages, but every manufacturer tweaks Android a little. So good luck if you get hit by this upgrade. Samsung will not be there to help you in any way.Update 4/2013 - finally the manual which goes with this Android Upgrade pushed to these devices in 1/2013 is now available on the Samsung Web page/support for this model. When I contacted support at the time of the upgrade to ask about a new manual to go with this version, they said I would be notified when it came out. NOT. It says it was posted February 2013, which I know it was not. Maybe March. It brings to light a lot of the Samsung modifications/customizations made to 4.1.1.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I just picked up this tablet at Best Buy. My old iPad (1st gen) is sorely out of date and I really needed an update. I've owned Android phones in the past and hated them (they were crappy phones), and it's made me leery of Android ever since. I've had a BlackBerry, and iPhone 4, and an HTC Radar (windows phone), so I'm pretty picky about what I want in a device.I went to Best Buy thinking I was going to end up having to choose either a really cheap eReader or spring for Kindle Fire HD or Nook HD. Neither seemed as robust as I wanted. I ended up playing with a few Android tablets and didn't hate them. Then I came across the Tab 2 7".It is extremely responsive. No lag time whatsoever. Excellent setup options and this has a great way for my to manage my RAM usage. I love the expandable SD slot, and the Play market is a far cry better than the old Android Market I was in before. The screen display is crisp and clear. I didn't even mind the 7" size. My iPad gets heavy after a while, and I had been considering upgrading to the iPad Mini. I work as Apple iOS tech support, so I was strongly swayed to choose a product I could troubleshoot and maintain myself. Once I had the Tab 2 in my hands, though, it was love.I was so enamoured with this device I actually managed to convince 3 others into buying it as well. And it was a steal for only 179 plus tax.If you want something small but robust, clean, sharp, clear and tidy, this is the tablet for you. I can sync my OneNote books from my Win 8 laptop, I can sync my Gmail, sync my Facebook contacts and so much more, and I haven't had to pay extra for the apps I love and haven't had to spend 6 hours trying to figure out how to make it work.And if 7 inches is too small, try the Tab 2 10.1 inch tablet :)

You cannot select two languages and use them simultaneously, you either type your message in Russian or in English. As far as I understand this is the Adnroid 4 problem - you cannot switch the language using the virtual keyboard, there is no special button (if I'm not mistaken there were few ways previously, including sliding on the space button etc), so everytime I have to go to preferences and switch it there; it is quite irritating.PS In few days I found the way to select few languages, it is quite deeply hidden in keyboard preferences, so now I have a special button on it to switch from English to Russian. But as far as I understand, many users could face the same problem, so maybe there should be some clarification from the Android developers regarding this.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I bought one of these 3 days ago and could never get it to connect to my network. Support chats and phone support could not resolve the issue. I was told I had a unit w a faulty network adapter and to send it in for service or return it. I returned it and picked up a new unit yesterday. Same issue. Same lack of success w support.I do not like to quit, so I kept at it.Here is what resolved it for me. I went into my routers settings and manually added the tab to the wireless card access list and voila it connects.I called support to advise them of the solution so they can assist others and update their troubleshooting procedures.Hope this helps someone here as well.

Being able to run games or movies AND connect with my friends around the world.I am still toying with and learning about the Tab 2, but so far it has been everything I wanted. I haven't abandoned my Kindle, but I enjoy being able to see color images from books and comics. Honestly I still prefer the e-ink format for prolonged reading, and the backlight (as expected) lessens battery time.Connectivity via GPS, wifi, and Bluetooth are all very stable. Android is a comfortable and easy to learn OS, Icecream Sandwich seems incredibly stable, and customization is elegant. Unfortunately the IR/Remote function does not work for me just yet, but I will experiment and work on it further- this was a novelty to me, and not key.Networking in order to access files on my PC from my tablet is my next project.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I bought this to replace my Kindle Fire which I was hacking and updating almost every week so I could have an inexpensive and small tablet with plain Android 4.0. Having the front and rear cameras is nice when you want to have a video chat or take a quick pic of something to Google Goggle. Bluetooth works really well for tethering and uses a lot less power than WiFi tethering on both the devices involved. The TV remote app is a good idea but does not work with all devices and cannot be used like a plain old universal remote (you are locked in to using it as a guide). As usual Touchwiz and all the other Samsung crapware ruins the device and slows it down. It also has a proprietary iPod like connector instead of the a standard micro USB connector like the majority of other devices in the world. Samsung if you insist on including a useless dock connector at least add a micro USB connector as well. I will probably end up selling this tablet and getting a Google Nexus 7" tablet if/when they release one so I don't have crappy software customization and get updates in a reasonable amount of time.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I have had this tablet now for a week, and I must say that I am completely in love with it. It's small, and easily transportable, but provides a bigger screen than my smartphone, and makes interacting with Google Play apps much much easier. The apps themselves run extremely smoothly, with no apparent form of lag. The interface ICS provides is sleek, smooth, and rarely bogs down from background apps. I love the ability to jump from one app to the next simply with a push of an on-screen button, and how easy it is to close a background app with a swipe of a finger.The battery life on this tablet is amazing. It lasts much longer than my laptop every did, even running apps continuously. I leave it on overnight sometimes; when I wake up, I am pleased to see the batter has only been reduced by 2-3%!Setting up all my email accounts was a breeze. It basically walked me right through it. Calendar synced up with my hotmail account too.I love this tablet; perfect size, perfect speed, perfect interface, perfect price! If you're looking for a tablet to provide you an awesome intermediate between your smartphone and your PC, this is definitely a great buy. I couldn't be happier with this tablet!

tablet_galaxy_tab|I received my Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 (7-Inch, Wi-Fi) a few days ago. While I'm still learning to use it, I can say already that I'm very happy with this purchase.I am a Spanish teacher and I have a long commute. I wanted a light tablet which allowed me to read books, as well as work on my lessons during my commute. I also wanted a tablet that could fit in my purse. After using my sister's Kindle for a couple of days, I was sure that I didn't like it. I needed a more user-friendly tablet that allowed me to do things easily.After reading many reviews, I decided to buy this one. I'm so happy! I have been using it for only a few days. Reading is comfortable (I prefer to hold it horizontally) and my eyes are also happy. I uploaded some material for my classes and used it already with one student. He enjoyed it very much and I know this will be an excellent teaching tool.I am still discovering new apps but so far I love the possibility of reading newspaper articles even without being connected to the Internet. I can check my e-mails, take notes, visit my favorite sites and even take pictures (and videos) without any problem. Videos look great.Typing is smooth but I still have to find a way to add Spanish accents marks, which I'm sure is possible.So far, it's the perfect tablet for my needs and I find myself using it also at home, instead of my laptop.I also bought a SanDisk microSDHC 32GB Flash Memory Card to expand the memory and Poetic Slimbook Leather Case for Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0. They are also perfect. I might get a stylus pen for taking notes.One day later: I found out how to add Spanish accents marks. Just hold the letter for a second and the keyboard will show you the options. For ex.: hold the "e" and it will give you the possibility of adding an "&eacute;".Two months later: I still love this tablet. I've been using it daily and the only problem I had so far was with the SanDisk microSDHC 32GB Flash Memory Card. It crashed twice when turning the tablet on. In these occasions I got an alert that I needed to format the memory card and that all my content would be lost. It was annoying but at least it happened at home and I was able to copy the material I needed from my laptop. But if it had happened during one of my classes, it would definitely had been very frustrating.

tablet_galaxy_tab|First the product review:After going through a round of 10.1 inch tablets, I felt that 7" is better to hold and does essentially most of the things you need a tablet for. So I bought this tab. After 3 days of usage, I would say it fits my needs well. I don't care much about HD or full HD or WXVGA, I would reach out for my laptop anyway for most of the tasks, as I find it more productive. The battery is decent, comparable to most of the tablets on the market. Charging time is a little longer than say Asus tablets, but I do it at night mostly. Another thing I noticed is that the charging cable is short like all other Samsung tablets, which is slightly frustrating.Now comparing it with the nexus. The Nexus has all the hardware better than this, but there are a couple of reasons I am considering keeping this device. 1 - No sdcard support on Nexus. I will be using my device mostly for music storage, and 16 GB is quite limiting for me. I can manage by juggling my files around, but that would be frequent enough to annoy me, I think. Plus, if I use streaming services like Spotify or Rdio, I will have serious loss of space. 2 - It's Asus. All those who have tried their tablets know about the pathetic browser issue. Given the fact that even Prime has it, I doubt they would have resolved it in this one. That's something to look out for!

tablet_galaxy_tab|The new Tab 2 7-inch is a perfect blend of size, ease of use, and power. Ice Cream Sandwich is very smooth and fast on this pad. The image quality and touch screen sensitivity are excellent. The Gorilla Glass (R) screen surface is very sensitive as well as very strong allowing for use without the need for a protector overlay. I installed a 32GB class 10 SCHD card so it has the same total storage capacity as my Tab 10 and the combination cost was less than half of the Tab 10. It has also proven to be a great ebook for use at night or under low light conditions without the need of an external light due to the backlit screen making it perfect for a travel ebook reader. The print is not quite as good as a Kindle B&W reader but close enough. Overall, the size and weight factors make this a pleasure to use for book reading, news, and watching movies. The only thing on my wish list for this tablet is a 8 to 16 Meg camera.

tablet_galaxy_tab|Replacing the Original Tab. This was the best move I made.The form and size is less bulky and more ergonomic than the Tab. It is easy to hold the weight is good for long periods of reading unlike any 10" tablet I have owned or used. Transporting in a suit or back pocket is a plus.Speed and UI is snappy for a single core processor. Which is a disappointment since the predecessor had a dual core but, to keep the cost low it is a sacrifice I can easily live with.Battery Life is the best of any computing device I have ever owned I don't have to worry about charging it all the time nor worry about not having enough battery for daily use.Storage Capacity and SD Slot. While is was also disappointing in having only 8GB's of storage when the predecessors offering 16 & 32 GB's, The ability to add up to 64 GB's cards and easy integration of cards make this not really noticeable at all. No matter what case you may put this in accessing the SD slot is arduous task to say the least.Screen. Is bright but not as vivid as other tablets but for the price it is pretty darn good. The screen is great for watching media but not the best for reading periodicals. If you are in to reading books, manuals, & periodicals I would recommend a 4:3 ratio screen or a 10" tablet or I hate to say an iXxx device. Not wanting to have a iXxx device or a hand heavy 10" tablet is a sacrifice I am willing to make.The Tab 2 is a great value and should be relevant in years to come. I don't see it becoming so out dated any time soon.

It somehow seemed silly to me to name an operating system "Ice Cream Sandwich" or "Jelly Bean".I didn't want to spend a lot of money on something which I originally viewed as a fad but my children and grandchildren can't seem to get along without these devices. By the way - I don't have a smartphone - only a dumb phone for use in emergency. I am learning about apps and operation of the device. So far no problems and I am beginning to rely on it for information. I use it with my home wi-fi set up and I find that there are more and more locations that allow public connection. I even used the device to play a game while waiting to see a doctor. - The waiting time went by faster.Perhaps there are better devices but for the "toe in the water" experience this device works well and there are many applications for it - you just have to learn where to look and how to use them. If grade school kids can learn then "why oh why can't I".I would like to tell more of my experiences but so far they are minimal - but so far - all good!Maybe I will tell you more in the future - that is if I can tear myself away from being chained to this device.By the way - the price was right and better than what was asked for a competing device named after a piece of fruit that tempted a women a long time ago! For an older guy this was important!!

tablet_galaxy_tab|I have had this tablet for about 4 months. I was comparing it to Nexus 7 and others, but by far this is the best tablet for everyday use. It doesn't have the cpu power that the Nexus does, or the battery life of apple products, but it is not enough to make a difference if you use this to play casual games, reading, surfing the net, HD videos and of course listening to music. The reason I chose this tablet is because of the expandable memory. I have a Polaroid 32gb SD card with a 10 speed rating (which matters a lot... research SD card speed on google) and I have no lag on any of my movies or music Polaroid 32 GB CL10 micro SDHC Flash Memory Cards for Tablet PCs and Smartphones (P-SDU32G10-EFPOL). Please buy yourself a screen protector and a case both are essential to have if you buy any tablet. When buying a case for your SGT2 make sure you get one that is specifically for SGT2 not SGT Plus or the original. They all have different thicknesses and dimensions.One con is battery life. The battery isn't great, but it's not horrible either. If you use this tablet continuously all day, you have to live with at least a good 4-5 hour battery life. I charge my battery every night. Use it on my 1 hour commute to work listening to music and sporadically throughout a 8 hour span. Then another 1 hour commute, listening to music and by the time I get home I usually have about half of battery life. So I can probably use it continuously for another 2-3 hours depending if I am watching videos or just playing games or surfing the net. Buy another wall charger when you can and keep it on you. When buying charger for home or car make sure they are for tablets. Regular mobile phone wall chargers and car chargers don't put out enough juice to charge the tablets.PowerGen Dual USB Port 2A 10w (fast) Heavy Duty Ouput Car Charger - WhiteIn conclusion, if you want a tablet and don't want to get ripped off by buying an Apple iPad or get the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2. Best specifications and best price. Best value period.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I got this tablet because I wanted more screen area and was sick of using my iPod Touch for all my internet browsing on the couch and on the go. I had high hopes for this, but it turned out to be just OK. I know everyone says you shouldn't compare these cheaper tablets to the apple tablets, so I'm going to compare it to my Apple iPod touch... seems more even and what I was used to, right?The Bad: I agree with previous reviewers in that the touch of your finger on the screen seems slightly off... and there is no way to calibrate it. The keyboard is absolutely frustrating to use, in either horizontal or vertical format - it is just an annoying pain. I had an easier time typing on my little iPod!!! This is either a Samsung issue or it's an android thing... I wouldn't know as I am mostly an Apple user. I was also extremely annoyed that it didn't come with an auto-correct or any spell check built in. Also the enter button is right next to the delete button, so when I have to go back constantly to fix what I typed, I would sometimes hit enter instead (on facebook for example) and it would post my half finished, badly spelled message. Another thing is there is no up/down/left/right arrow to quickly move the cursor, you have to use the clunky touch to try to get it where you want, which isn't smooth at all (again, an android issue or Samsung, I'm not sure). Another thing I've found coming from my little iPod touch is that the Android apps for this seem to be more clumsy and with less features. I really am not too fond of the facebook, ebay, and amazon apps that are available for this... not a huge deal since you can still go to the actual website, but I would have thought they would be really similar, unfortunately no.The Good: It seems to be pretty lightweight. The screen is really nice and clear due to the higher pixel count for it's size. I like how in the browser you have the option to request a desktop website, because sometimes the mobile sites seem odd on the 7" screen, since they are mostly built for smaller phone screens. Flash does work in the default web browser, although I've found I like using google chrome instead, which doesn't support flash. It does have tabbed browsing on both browsers, which I like and was used to. Everything seems to be pretty quick on this, I've only had a little web lag when I had multiple tabs open. The task manager works great to clear some RAM if you need it.All in all, I kind of have a love/hate relationship with this tablet. It is definitely nice to have the larger screen, but at times I find myself cursing at it in my head. Don't expect to do any fast word processing, or facebooking it up : ) If you have big sausage fingers you will probably have an even harder time, as I have pretty narrow fingers and still have this thing hitting letters I don't want.EDIT: I changed my review to 4 stars since my last review. I tried out the hackers keyboard program from the app store, and also the GO Keyboard, and am using the GO. This is MUCH better than the Samsung factory keyboard. Ive been getting used to other features of the tablet as well, so four stars.EDIT 2: Updated to the new software and the standard keyboard has changed and is much more responsive and now has auto correct and spell check.

I realized the iPad was a little too bulky for my taste, no flash or microSD card slot (!!!), and I wanted an interface I could customize a bit more. The kind man that worked there asked me what I wanted in a tablet, and I replied that I'd want it mostly for e-mail, games, videos, e-book reading, and light web-browsing and he suggested the Kindle Fire. After playing around with the Fire for maybe 30 minutes, I decided the size was perfect, BUT I knew I needed a tablet with Google Play after taking a look at Amazon's AppStore. I then migrated to the Galaxy Tab 2 7.0. Much lighter and easier to hold, had Google Play + cameras and a microphone (with a 3-year old at home, a microphone is a must for Talking Tom!), and ICS, but what really sold me was the screen quality. I was wowed when I watched the Moments of Everyday Life demo video. Looked better than my TV. So, of course I had to buy it. I've now had it for 1 1/2 days, and LOVE it. My Nook magizenes and books synced to my device quickly and easily, games like Talking Tom, Bakery Story, and Tiny Tower work great, the device is much faster than I expected, and customizing my Tab 2 with wallpapers and such took minutes. I actually don't mind TouchWiz. I like waking up in the morning and being able to see the weather and top stories on Yahoo by just turning on my tablet. Multitouch is great, Fruit Ninja worked with 5 fingers. Overall it is a great buy, and the extra $50 I spent on this than the Kindle Fire is the least of my worries.

After reading some of the reviews about customer service I did not anticipate being helped. Was I wrong. It turned out that the problem was not the tablet or Samsung's fault but the password my husband insisted was correct turned out to be incorrect. AJ helped me locate the correct password and setting it up was then a breeze. He remained on the phone to help me connect to Google which then allowed me to use the apps which are already included. I could easily transfer my Kindle books and my Netflix movies. I am looking forward to all of the uses this little tab provides and am planning on taking it with me on various vacations so that I can have the internet with me. tablet_galaxy_tab|I purchased this tablet with the intention of taking it on a trip overseas, and travel in general. I don't currently own a smart phone or a laptop; and did not really want a full 10 inch size tablet. I have found other reviews of it to be spot on. It actually was the perfect size to slip in a carry-on, and take everywhere with me. Not being a terribly technology-savvy person, I did find it easy to set up and use. I used the Samsung website to read the manual for any questions I had, and the site was quite helpful. I did add a 32GB memory card, as others have recommended, and found that it ran quite a bit faster. Even though I could expand the size of the page and type, using it for extended e-mails and internet use made me a bit bug-eyed! And it actually had about 5 hours of life on a battery charge; also charges fairly quickly. Using the Amazon APP store and website to download apps, music, and books from Kindle was incredibly easy.My only negative is the cursed word-spelling prompts. On many occasions, I was not able to spell the name of a person or use a certain work because I could not override the word-spelling prompts. (Does anyone know if this feature can be turned off?) I wish I could rate it 4.5 stars!Overall, it performs well and is the perfect size to tuck in a purse, backpack, or carry on. Glad I bought it!

tablet_galaxy_tab|I am a techno geek who is adamantly against all things Apple (I don't like how obsolete their products get in a relatively short amount of time) so I was looking for an alternative to shelling out $500 for an iPad. I discovered the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2. I had been looking at the Kindle Fire but found the stripped down version of the Android operating system to be too limiting. Enter the Galaxy Tab. It was in my price range, could do everything I needed, had a slot for micro SD cards for my media, was by Samsung which is a company I've had luck with before, and the reviews that I saw were mostly positive.I went to a local shop that carries the Galaxy Tab to play with it before purchasing. It passed my tests and one came home to me shortly thereafter. I have basically been very pleased with it. Like others have said, the battery life is a bit short, but I can get a full day out of playing with it before it needs to be charged so it's fine for me. The wire that comes with it is ridiculously short (Samsung people take note, this really bites!!!), and it doesn't charge when plugged into the USB port on my laptop which I find bizarre. Also, I don't think this is a Galaxy Tab problem, but an Adobe one, I can't play the flash games on Facebook on the Galaxy Tab. I don't know of any tab that it works on though.What I like about it is: The size is perfect for tossing in my bag when I want to bring it with me. It is pretty easy to use. The Android market is getting better with each passing day and there are very few apps that I want but can't get yet. The screen is crisp, clear, and the touch screen works well. There are widgets that I can put up on the home page (and other ones) that are really helpful. By far the best feature of this Tab is the micro SD slot. The Galaxy itself only has 8GB on board which is really only about 6 with the OS and other apps loaded (some of which I wish I could delete but I can't) With the SD slot, I can buy multiple cards and load my music, movies and TV shows without losing space on my Tab. I have 3 cards now and have more on my wishlist. This is a fabulous feature for someone who has a lot of media but who doesn't need it all on the Tab all the time.All in all, I'm very happy with my purchase.

tablet_galaxy_tab|Since I know there are a lot of first time buyers out there, I am going to take you through the process that led me to purchasing the Galaxy2 for my mother, in place of the Kindle fire.1) How easy is it to use right out of the box? This was probably the biggest concern that I had. Generally speaking, more advanced products tend to require a more advanced user. Since the Galaxy2 is functionally better than the Kindle fire, I was concerned the amount of functionality could actually make this less so for my less-than-tech-savvy-Mother. Obviously, I took the chance and made the purchase. So far she has hit the ground running, and is in love with this thing. The First gen Kindle she swore she was "Not trying to replace" is collecting dust. I recently received a text message from back home with my grandfather playing a card app, something he has been doing every night since he arrived.2) It's standout features? What makes this a better decision than the Fire? Much more noticeable than the power under the hood; Front/Back facing camera and expandable memory. - Without Expandable memory, you get X number of gigs. Want to upgrade memory? Prepare to buy a brand new unit. With expandable memory, the 8 gig Galaxy 2 can be transformed into a 40 gig unit for less then 20 bucks. - Front/back facing camera really is meant for skype capabilities. I live across the state, so it's nice to be able to speak face to face with my family.Long story short, great purchase.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I really enjoy this little tablet. For the price it is very usable, but don't compare this to the speed of an Apple iPad MD328LL/A (16GB, Wi-Fi, White) NEWEST MODEL. That's not fair, and this little puppy is about $300 less expensive. But at the same time, I would be remiss in saying this meets all my hopes and expectations for a tablet. It's a bit slow... now don't get me wrong, it's usable, but screens don't snap into place quite as promptly as... say an iPad, or even the Samsung Galaxy Tab (10.1-Inch, 16GB, Wi-Fi), but once again, we're talking about a $200 price difference. So what would be a good comparison in the same price range? How about this other tablet that I bought at Costco for $190 (actually three): VIZIO 8-Inch Tablet with WiFi - VTAB1008. The Samsung is noticeably faster than the Vizio. Plus Ice Cream Sandwich is a very intuitive operating system for this tablet... far easier to use than the Vizio... sometimes I'm clicking on the [Back] button on the Vizio several times, because there is no response and no visual indication that it has been selected then I go back several screens at a time. Not good for the Vizio, but the Samsung, there is a visual selection and you return immediately. The 7" screen is very readable, and I prefer the smaller size (compared to the 8" Vizio). I would recommend the Samsung to anyone with a desire for an entry level tablet, but do not expect a lot of speed.

tablet_galaxy_tab|This tablet was released in a time when the market was hungry for a cheap-yet-decent tablet experience. You were either stuck buying a crappy Vizio (or other value brand) tablet, the locked-down Kindle Fire, or spending huge wads of cash on a 10-inch device that was clumsy and bulky to hold. Samsung apparently saw the market niche and jumped on it.This is not a premium tablet. Instead it's targeted at people who want a "good enough" tablet experience while keeping a reasonable price point. There's some tasks the tablet is "good enough" for, and other tasks that some people might find lacking.I primarily use this thing to read books and watch YouTube and Netflix in bed. The 7-inch screen is totally suitable when your face is close to it (much less eye-strain than trying to watch extended video playback on the 4-inch screen of a smartphone). I've spent many blissfully relaxed hours watching stuff on this tablet, with the added ego boost of knowing it's much more electrically efficient than watching the same content on my desktop computer.Less frequently I use the tablet for listening to music (media players are a joy to use on the bigger-than-a-smartphone screen, with the album art showing up huge and pretty), web browsing (Google News and articles on various sites), online chat (through IRC an client), and all the other uses you'd expect to get out of an Android device. Email, social networks, image browsing, screwing around with the camera for the lulz, etc etc etc.There are a two minor flaws I've noticed. The stock web browser seems a bit laggy and buggy at times and the music player occasionally suffers brief hiccups in playback, though this may have been fixed in a software update, as I haven't heard this problem recently. On that note, Samsung has been supporting this product really well. For the 3-4 months since I've gotten it, I think the device has received.... five software updates? It's always nice to see a manufacturer standing behind a product post-sale.So, the verdict. It's not a premium device, but it is excellent for the price, and good enough for my tablet needs. Even as it's made depreciated by newer 7-inch tablets, I plan on using it and loving it for a long time yet.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|First; I want to say this was an impulse purchase at Best Buy. Sorry Amazon. I doubt I would have purchased it without the opportunity to try it out first. I also don't usually purchase items like this without reading some customer reviews and researching them a little. That being said; I am more than pleased with my purchase. I am going on my third week of owning it and have no complaints. Everything exceeds my expectations. The Tab 2 came preloaded with a wide variety of Apps and has the ability to download and install Apps for just about anything you could want to do on it. It comes with Android 4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich) OS already installed. While I haven't explored all of its functions yet; the ones that I have work great. The memory can be upgraded to 32GB with a Micro SD card; I recommend SanDisk Ultra 32GB microSDHC Card Plus Adapter (SDSDQUA-032G-U46A). I bought mine from Amazon for $29.94 (USD). You can download and watch movies, stream movies from NetFlix, download books and apps from the Kindle store, retrieve and send e-mail, use the organizer app to keep track of appointments, etc. etc. Did I mention you can download an app for just about anything you want to do on this tablet? You can sync your music, video, pictures, and contacts from your computer using the Samsung Kies Software. A word to the wise, download and install the Samsung USB drivers BEFORE you install the Kies software and connect your Tab 2. If not you are going to have problems. I learned the hard way. The battery life is excellent. The WiFi connection is a breeze to setup. I bought the eWonder(R) Wireless Bluetooth Keyboard Case for 7" Samsung Galaxy Tab PLUS and the New Galaxy Tab 2 (Black) from Amazon for my tablet and it was also a breeze to setup and connect. I would recommend this tablet highly to anyone; even it is your first. If you require any more technical details go to [...]

tablet_galaxy_tab|When the Tab 2 7.0 came out it looked wonderful. Feature packed with Android 4, cameras, SD card slot (important but missing on many tablets), GPS, Google Maps, etc. and the tablet itself has lived up to its promise but Samsung unfortunately has not. I have become well acquanted with their customer service and the people are great but seem to have spotty training. It is like the "little girl with the curl".When it became evident that their Bluetooth instance had trouble pairing with a number of common devices (on access would give constant pairing requests), at first they denied the problem & said it was the adapter, then they were working on it. Finally two months after it was reported, ICS 4.0.4 came out and it was fixed.Except no-one told the service desk just as no-one told them that Allshare had been moved from a seperate app to part of settings. This is bad because from day one HDMI support had been promised except it needed an unobtainable adapter. Then it was said one of their adapters would work except it doesn't. Samsung's latest move is to redact the reference to HDMI from their specifications and user guide (is in revs up to 3, not in rev 7. Page 22). Lawyers have a word for this.So if it does what you need out of the box or with an available adapter then you are fine but if something you expected to work (like the Sat-Nav seems to need WiFi/3G access to calculate driving directions but the GPS itself seems powerful) is "different" or is in the specs but does not seem to be there (like being able to connect to an external display), good luck.In any case, be kind to the service desk people, they are trying to do the right thing.

That's something apple got right. Other then that the device runs smooth and fast. Everything is easy to use. With all the complaints about the app store i love how laid back the app store is. I have an ipod and never had an android so i'm surprised at the apps that are aloud on there without needing an exploit. Again that's the app store and not the device. The tablet is very sturdy. I like that they used plastic and not metal and glass. Metal gets cold and glass is dangerous as well as breaks easily. plastic is soft and i would think it's better if it were dropped. It also won't shatter into dangerous shards. I don't use the camera but i heard it sucked. I have an actual camera so i don't need it. The speakers are very loud. It has great screen brightness which is also easy to access. In fact everything is very easy to access. A big problem though like anything that doesn't bare the name apple on it is that the accessories are hard to come buy. Good battery life6. USB on the go! I could basically every USB peripheral, mouse, keyboard and thumb drivesCons:1. At 370gms, it's slightly on the heavier side for people wanting to use it as an eBook reader2. Screen is low-res which matters on a text-heavy webpage/app3. Slow processor, but has sufficient RAM to cater to most modern games4. No HDMI out to mirror the display on to a TV, but supports dlnaOverall, I'm very pleased with it for the price paid.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I've only used it for one day, but this is lots of fun. The only drawback is that for a 7" tablet, it is darn heavy! It took me an updated install of Netflix to get it to work without an error message of minimum requirements, but once rolling the video quality is great. It has a very similar feel to my Samsung Galaxy phone, so I was able to have a comfortable feel for using it from the start. I am a little concerned over the log in of apps such as Yahoo e-mail as I haven't been able to figure out how to log out. It appears they stay logged in (except Netflix which you can log out of). Will have to read up on it as I am concerned about security issues. The Android Market is readily available and I was able to download my favorite games without problem. Accessing Amazon Kindle books was also easy and it was great actually being able to see the book covers instead of just a list which is what my husband sees on his Kindle Touch. I was disappointed in the camera quality, but had to remember that 1.3 mp is mediocre in comparison to my phone which is 8 mp. Also, there is no flash, but no real surprise there. The video quality more than makes up for it. So far I am pleased as I was looking for a "mini computer" I could tote in my purse...might just be a little more hefty than I was expecting. Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 (7-Inch, Wi-Fi) Update: I have now been using the tablet for about a week and I must stay I am really enjoying it. It truly is like a mini computer as I can readily access the internet. I can see there are many more features I need to become familiar with, but overall I am very pleased. I inserted an SD card for the first time and did learn it is a good idea to turn the tablet off, insert the card, then turn it back on. Using the Settings feature doesn't seem to work if you inser the card while the tablet is on. It then instantly recognizes the card and makes it easy to access. You definitely need to get an exterior SD disk as the 4 MB interior memory card will fill up quickly with photos, games, video, etc. I am not a big fan of "i-"anything (i-pad, i-pod, etc.), so I can recommend the Samsung which seems more user friendly and accessible as far as available apps and other programs.

tablet_galaxy_tab|After receiving some comments, i thought I might be too hard on my review and I think a 4 stars looks more appropiateHowever the battery life is really an issue you should considered_________________________&lt;______________________________________&lt;______Having my galaxy 3 weeks now I can tell I am satisfied so far.First consideration this is a 250 bucks tablets, so don't expect a high end device, I own an iPad 2, iPod touch, so I guess I can tell you my reason to buy a Galaxy tab 2 ICS.First of all, I was tired of the size of my iPad 2 and weight, I wanted to have a small tablet just to watch movies and Internet while lay down in bed, after an hour movies, iPad 2 weight becomes an issue to hold it one hand.Since I travel often to Europe, I wanted to have a VPN tablet, so that's the only reason I didn't go for a Kindle Fire.GThe VPN is so easy to set in this tablet, it's same as easy as Ipad2. The only thing is that Netflix sometimes freezes and a reboot is required, not big deal, but that doesn't happen on iPad 2 neither iPod touch.The home screen is really remarkable, you can personalise it, and you can have a small screenshot or the most recent videos in you tube, bookmarks from your navigation, news etc, very nice.From the apps side, Android have more and better quality apps than Apple,for instance you can find complete free version of UNO card game, that doesn't have IOS, you have Hulu Plus, which doesn't run in IOS, neither exploring site with adobe plug in (great).The setting quick access from the bar very convenient, the reader for e book is good and also the remote control feature is awesome, especially if you have a Samsung tv.The only reason I dont't give it a 4 stars are:Battery life is too short, even saving putting wifi off, the battery drains after 2 hours of gaming and video vs iPad 2 which the battery really last 4 hours at that use rate?the other thing is that tapping is not so great as iPad, you miss a lot letters, the system seems to not recognised the proper spots of each buttons, I don't know if this is an Ice cream sandwich issue but is a pain.In conclusion I'm very satisfied, since from the beginning I was clear about what I wanted, a cheaper tablet for Internet and movies with VPN feature, I didn't expect to have a GPS and a slot memory expansion which are plus, but if you want to use a tablet for more complex task you should go for other brands such as apple or toshiba or asus

tablet_galaxy_tab|I bought mine at Best Buy. Performance is good, price was right (or so I thought). Everything is good except for one important aspect (for me): With Android 4, the SD card is not good for anything but storing data. This means you can't move your apps to the SD card. The internal storage is 8GB but after formatting and the operating system, you're left with a little over half of the internal storage remaining. While you may put a thousand small apps on the internal storage, the quantity goes down drastically if you load larger apps and their associated data. For example, the navigation app is larger than, say, a slot machine game, and the map data can be huge if you want to have a bunch of states loaded. I'm not sure if the map data can be moved to the SD card and have the app know where to find it or not. There are no instructions about how to use the space.Samsung should have pushed Google to enable moves to SD card like the earlier versions of Android supported, or provided more internal storage. And at least make it known to a potential buyer about this limitation.
---

I will say the first samsung tablet I picked up I found a few "lit" pixels which showed up when using a black background. I took it back to the store and repurchased another one and so far I do not see the same issue.I think the camera even though its getting a bad reputation still is nice since the Fire does not even have one. I don't see myself out taking snapshots with this thing but sometimes its nice having it and I might try Skype on it at some point. So far the wifi has worked great, I downloaded about 800mb of music over iSyncr Wifi the other nite along with downloading apps from the google market and did not notice hardly any slow down. I think for the money this is gonna be a great tablet. I currently have an ipad 1st gen, Touchpad rooted with Android and a KFire. Probably going to send all of these back. Just for fun I snapped in the galaxy tab 2 inside my old Kindle Fire case the (Ace Flip Case by Casecrown) and it fits perfect. (http://www.amazon.com/CaseCrown-Black-Smoke-Amazon-Kindle/dp/B005VR5034/ref=sr_1_9?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1336087216&sr=1-9 ). Now of course there is no camera hole in the back but all the other ports are fully accessible and this cases still allows you to pop out the corner to position the galaxy tab in landscape mode for reading. They also lay very flat when open which is nice when reading, etc. Just a thought if someone is looking for a cheaper case (no rear camera hole).

tablet_galaxy_tab|Let me start off by saying, I am an Android fan. I own a Samsung Galaxy S II phone and am eagerly looking forward to buying the S IV once it is out. So, when I got the Galaxy Tab 2 (7 inch) in a deal on purchase of Samsung 46-inch Smart LED TV I was pretty excited about it. However, upon using it for a day or so, I had no choice but to return it for a refund.The Wi-Fi receiver is extremely defective. It needs the signal to be at full strength to open web pages. If the signal drops even to 3/4th of full strength, it won't open the lightest of web pages (e.g. Google). It will simply show "loading" and will eventually time-out. I did some research of my own and found a number of hits for "Galaxy Tab 2 Weak Wi-Fi", one of the first links is actually an Amazon link: http://www.amazon.com/Did-they-ever-fix-WiFi/forum/Fx2OE7QX73W89HA/Tx2WVDVZLKXZDGM/1?asin=B007P4VOWC and the answer to that question is NO. Then you have the "death grip" issue - hold the tab on the bottom left corner (where the Wi-Fi antenna is located) and see the signal strength drop before your eyes. I even tried following some of the suggestions which point to adding the Wi-Fi network manually instead of auto-detect and that did not help either.Finally, I had to call up Amazon tech support, who were very helpful but they basically ran through the same set of troubleshooting tips I mentioned above. They also pointed to the death grip issue and the manual network addition. They also mentioned that the Wi-Fi problem was a known issue with Galaxy Tab 2. As a result, I had no option but to request a refund.The only reason I gave a 2-star rating is because I didn't "hate" the product. For someone who is willing to ignore the Wi-Fi issue, this is a fantastic product. For me, I can't always be standing next to my wireless router. In my opinion, it kind of beats the whole purpose of having a tablet and a wireless router, especially when my iPad 2 can do a much better job at receiving signal and rendering web pages at more than acceptable speeds. And it is 2 years old!Disappointed.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|Now, I know a lot of this is my own damn fault for thinking back to when it was newly advertised and not checking into what people's experiences have been so far; a lot of my problems also result from Amazon themselves, and from third parties. I just don't want people to make the mistake I did - I'm not whining about it, not asking for my money back, just letting people know what they are NOT going to be able to do with this device.First, the good parts is that it's a nice tablet and, with the price drop, a pretty nice deal. There are a lot of reviews covering the good points - I find the screen crisp and responsive (although I haven't yet put a protector on it); wifi speed is great - can stream netflix and looks pretty good. As a device to replace a lot of what I was using my phone for (besides "phone" things), this tablet is really quite nice - it's a pleasure web surfing and using email compared to a phone screen, and it's got decent processing speed and plays games quite nicely. Decent display for reading, although I personally still prefer e-ink for reading.But I'm disappointed in what I'm not able to do with it; the Galaxy Tab 2 10.1 can do video output - this can't. I was hoping to hook it up to the TV in my exercise room to watch while working out, but no dice... not even SD.On top of that, I recently signed up for Amazon Prime... but you cannot stream video from Amazon to this device - it was part of the reason I signed up for prime. This is not a flaw of the device, but of Amazon - an artificial barrier, seeing as how you can play streaming content on "blessed" android devices.As a side note, in trying to bypass using an app for Amazon streaming by accessing it on the web, we find out that Adobe no longer makes a compatible flash player for the latest versions of Android. If you download a browser, like Dolphin or Firefox, that has built in flash, Amazon still claims the device is not compatible.Again - it's not flaws of the device, really, but it limits what you can do with it, and I just wanted to throw it out there that other Galaxy's - the Tab 2 10.1, the old 7.0, the 7.0 plus - all have features and abilities this tablet does not have. Yes, they cost more, but examine whether it's worth it for you before buying this one. As I write this, the Galaxy 2 10.1 is actually a really great price given the much larger size - and for some reason it can output video while this one can't (you'd think it'd be essentially the same exact thing except for screen size, but no).I don't know how this next one compares to other tablets - but on my phone I can move downloaded apps to the SD card. At 8MB, being one of the lower memory tablets available, I got mine along with a microSD card to save on device space, but it doesn't allow me to move apps to the SD card.So it's a decent tablet, but given some of the other great deals available right now you should think of other options. If you're willing to go even higher, I bought the wife and kids 7.0 pluses last year and they are pretty happy with them (still no Amazon instant video, though); they are far superior, but of course also far more costly. If you think video output or Amazon instant video might be interesting, I implore you to examine other tablets and do the research on them.As a larger device to do what I've been doing with my phone (except calling), it's definitely a decent product. I was just hoping to do more.
---

tablet_galaxy_tab|The bad first: 1) Just bought it, and was very disappointed when I turned it on and the colors looked washed out, no matter what I did. I had heard so much about the presumably beautiful screen and I just don't see it. The colors are not dynamic at all, just drab, compared to the beautiful, vivid screen on my galaxy S2 phone. ( I am longingly viewing the two and comparing them as I write this. Where has all the vibrancy gone on the tablet screen...) Chatted with Samsung online, recommendation was to reset the tab, which I did but but it made no difference. Anyone have a remedy? 2)Lack of a micro hdmi slot for hd tv connection. Although I knew this was not a built in feature, I did not know that you cannot even get a decent HDMI adapter for it the way you can for other tablets. 3)Why no apps can be moved to the micro sd card is a mystery to me. Should be easy to fix? 4)I have not (yet)discovered a way to download videos etc. to the external sd card directy. When I download videos, pix, music etc. I have to download to the internal memory and then use cut and past via 'my files'. At least that's what I've been doing. So the internal memory fills up very fast and you have to keep moving things. Is there a way to download directly to external card?The good: 1)I love the 'allshareService' app, eliminates some of the hdmi connection peeve I have. I can play my media files on my sony tv at the touch of a button, full screen, beautifully done, but the tv has to be capable of receiving files. Don't know if this is a Samsung app or if it is part of the ICS package. 2) wifi and cpu works very fast, no glitches as others have mentioned. I had several downloads going at the same time last night as well as using the tab for other things and it worked like a charm, no hang ups etc. 3) Overall works very smoothly, and has a nice intuitive feel. Feels 'coordinated' in terms of all the different features, very easy to navigate. 4) Love that you can change fonts for your tablet. I used to have this feature on my old LG dlite phone and am delighted to see it on my new tab. 5) Online manual is well organized and covers the main questions well. Its easy to download to the tab. 6) Battery lasts longer than I anticipated, can't put an hour value on it but I used it heavily for hours yesterday without charging.So, overall, it is an excellent tab, but I really expected, and want, a more vibrant color scheme on my screen and there does not seem to be an option to adjust that.Edit: So disappointing: Three days after writing this review, the 'allshareService'application,which I loved because it allowed me to stream easily from tab to sony google tv to my galaxy S2 phone, was no longer to be found on my tablet. Called tech support four times, they said the issue was 'elevated to the next level' as it appeared the app had become deactivated and they had to find a way to reactivate it. They finally said the allshareService app had been discontinued (not aailable for download anywhere)and that only a new app, called 'allshare play' is now available. Well, guess what: allshare play is not compatible with my google tv and, even worse, my Samsung s2 phone does not recognize "allshare play" so I just lost the easiest and most important function I had for streaming of video, music ect. on this tab. It turns out "allshare play' is only compatible with two or three Samsung devices. Beware!! I just lost the main reason for liking this tab.

But I think all I need is some practice. A third way to use this tablet is remote desktoping to my work computer. It gives you instant access to everything I have at my desktop via WiFi at work. Get the "2X" app for remote desktopping.Finally, I use the PDAnet to connect this tablet to the internet via my phone. I have an HTC phone and don't have hotspot support (didn't pay for it). So I use the BlueTooth tether feature from PDAnet. Works great for reading news and web browsing.The camera leave something to desire, though. I didn't buy this tablet to take phenomenal photos but I would expect something slightly more decent than what this tablet can provide.No compliant about functionality. everything is intuitive. if you can figure this out, you should go back to chalk and slate. ;PIt took me two years before I caved in and bought this tablet. tablet_galaxy_tab|Fantastic Tablet...love it's features! Let's me do a lot more reading where ever I have WiFi, or even if I don't. Easier on my eyes that my smart phone!NOTE TO ALL BUYERS! To use the Amazon Instant Video on their web site, you will need Adobe Flash for Android. I went to Adobe's help forums and found the following link:[...]It will tell you to what you need to know to get Flash installed on your Tablet. The Google Play Store has removed Adobe Flash from it's archives due to new video formats being developed. Why you would remove it before the replacement for it is in place, I'll never know.But you won't be disappointed in this purchase! I did a search on here and am buying the USB port adapter for this, so I can off load to a flash drive or use a full size keyboard on it. I also opted to get the 32 Gig card it suggested I get. You'll love it!! It even has the ability to control your TV, it's a Super Remote control too!I compared it to the Kindle Fire HD. This has Dual Cameras, and SD Card slot storage. I do not trust online backup services. Too easy for one-stop shopping for any hackers to get to your personal stuff.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|**Edit: Without going back through the review, I must point out that after some discussion in the thread below it was exposed that while there may be several apps that allow themselves to be ported back and forth, this is not the norm and you should, for all intensive purposes accept this as a device that does not currently support moving apps to the SD card. Given this, if I have some time this week I'll root it and get back with whether or not that helps at all.This tablet has everything I wanted in a 7"'er, and I'm so impressed I'm thinking of replacing my ASUS ep121 with the 10.1 model for school and work usage. This tablet booted straight up out of the box, I inserted a preformated 64gig mSD card, which it took to without a single hitch, and proceeded to fill it with all my standard android apps (I've been using android since before it's retail release). The tablet's only irritating features, are that it does not support apps to SD, and when plugged into a 3.5mm jack it automatically turns itself down to near inaudible levels, when you turn it back up, it covers a chunk of the screen with some stupid warning about loud noise and ear damage... While I understand loud noise can certainly damage your hearing, I doubt if many people are in danger of doing this with their mid sized tablets.Vs. the Original FireI bought this with the first week of its release, and I preordered the fire, what I'm saying is, I have extensive experience with both... And because of that I don't understand the comparisons people are drawing. The Fire was never meant to be a full range experience, it's meant to be an ereader that handles color pictures. The fact amazon decided to add in web surfing or netflix support was them just testing the water. They didn't expect the tablet to sell like it did, and they didn't intend for people to use them the way they are.This on the other hand is a legitimate tablet, in a seven inch formfactor. You can read the specs, I'm not going to type them out again. But the web browsing is quick, I've only had one issue with firefox on it, and I simply reinstalled, not another issue since, using iSyncr I loaded it with all my playlists and top rated songs (wirelessly), the newest iteration of iSyncr even records your playcounts. The offline GPS function of google maps has not worked once on here, but tethered it works fine. I have synced with multiple bluetooth devices, and it handles swapping between them MUCH better than my Galaxy SII. The only real problem I have with it, is that samsung backed it up with complete trash for peripherals. Do not buy the samsung car stands or any of that stuff, there are plenty of bundles and alternatives by third parties (which I have reviewed) that work very, very well in comparison.Vs. the NexusI'm an ASUS fanboy, I love their components, but the omission of the mSD slot in the feature list for the GNexus is what made me grab this one and cancel my GNexus preorder. However, I recently spent the entire day with the two side by side, and I can tell you empirically that any differences are subjective interpretations. The screens are not so different that your eyes will melt, the speeds of function are not so different that you'll rue the day you paid for a samsung product, and when you start showing off all the content you have stored locally, the opposition gets sad... especially when you bring up how much youtube content is blocked to mobile browsing.In my opinion, the SGT7 is a clear victor here. I didn't walk away wish I'd bought a nexus, in fact I drove away with my SGT7 in the windshield clamp jamming to music off it and a giant smile on my face.The bottom line from my perspective is this:If you want a seven incher, that will handle all your basic media consumption and net needs, plus a few other things, this is it.It's also worth noting that Polaris office (which comes preinstalled) is the best MS office alternative offered for ANY tablet device.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|Love this little tablet. I also own the 10 in. tablet. Has all the power of my 10 in tablet. This 7 in is small enough to tuck into my purse to carry along with me. Connected to my wireless internet as soon as I turned it on the first time. Smooth running. Plays games very well. Love the dropbox storage. Screen does show lots of prints but I have a cleaner puff to clean it. Love everything about it. This is a keeper. Would be an excelent first tablet for anyone.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|Caveat 1: This is my first "Smart" device. My phone makes phone calls, that is all. Caveat 2: This is my first exposure to Android.When I discovered that Samsung was making a mid-sized pad with WiFi and GPS, for under $250, I was delighted. This seemed to be able to fulfill so many of my desires, including two big needs-- A mid sized pad for use with Skeye, an amazing and completely unique astronomy app, and a highly configurable GPS that was big enough to use in the car yet could still fit in the pocket of my hiking shorts. (Note that a WiFi IPad cannot do GPS or Skeye, and besides it is too big and expensive.)These two functions work great (for the most part--see below about screen) and alone make the device worth the price, but of course it does much more that is useful. I really liked that it could accommodate an external memory card to enhance the limited on-board memory, although this turned out to be mostly bogus, as apps cannot be put on the external SD card, due to terrible limitations in the Android operating system.For the first week it worked perfectly. By the second week the software was extensively corrupted. By the third week I had to "wipe" the memory and start over. This was very disturbing. But as far as I can tell, this is the weakness of Android, not a hardware issue. Fortunately, as "wiping" appears to be routinely required on Android devices, it is well supported and implemented. Many of the weaknesses of this device (corruptibility, many very buggy apps, poor memory management, crippled external SD card) are due to Android and it's wild-west ecosystem, not Samsung.But there are hardware issues too. The cameras are really poor, and no autofocus to boot. Makes many potentially useful applications useless. The main camera is said to be 3.2 mp, but has the resolution of a 1 mp camera at best. This is an area where Samsung really cut corners. My son has a fancy ASUS pad and the camera is 10x better, at least. The Sammy can't read barcodes, or work as a document scanner or as a text translator, because it doesn't focus that close. Sharpness is terrible at any distance. The main camera is not a real camera, think of it as a web-cam for Skyping (backwards) or spying on your babysitter, that is all it is useful for.The screen is good, but it lacks the brightness to easily use it as an in-car GPS in the daytime--too bad. The position of the face-facing camera is not the best, at least when used in landscape mode--it is designed to be used in the portrait position only. In terms of processor speed and internet download speed, it is about where you would think for $250--good, but not up there with the big boys. Internet download speed is 3/4 of my sons high priced ASUS pad (I got 15 mbps, the ASUS was 20 on the same wifi and network), overall speed is about 40% but raw processor speed is ~25%. For me, this is fast enough, but probably some people will think otherwise.Battery life is good but not great--when semi-frequently used as a GPS during the day, with the screen at maximum brightness, it barely lasted the day. For most uses battery capacity is adequate, however. Sound is not bad for such a device, better than I had expected, but it can't really produce sounds under about 400 hz (no big surprise). WiFi reception is good, but not quite as good as higher end products I have tested--certainly adequate most of the time. GPS works very well indeed, every bit as good as the higher end products I have benchmarked it against. It lacks a gyro, and therefore the functionality that a gyro provides (whatever that might be!).The wall charger that came with the Sammy appears to be a standard USB type, so I thought I could recharge the Sammy by plugging just the cord into the Belkin USB voltage charger I have in the car for use with my IPod, but it did not appear to work. I need to try again to verify this issue, but if this is a voltage mismatch issue, it is very inconvenient and a very odd decision by Samsung. Maybe the Belkin device doesn't produce enough current? Even with a strong magnifying glass, I cannot read the microscopic text describing the voltage/amperage output on the side of the Samsung charger!If a much better device comes out for under $350, I would consider upgrading to get a real camera and brighter screen and a real external SD card slot. Right now, no such product exists on the market in this size/price. On paper, there is no advantage with the Google Nexus 7, only downside. Maybe the hyped Apple Minipad, but I doubt it will meet my basic needs as described in the beginning of this review. So overall, I do like this device and will keep it (3 months return policy at COSTCO), but with a bit more refinement of hardware and software, this could be the Dream Device I have been anticipating for almost 20 years. It falls somewhat short of that at this stage, however.Update: The Samsung has been operating without any problems for a couple of more months now.
---

tablet_galaxy_tab|I would like to start by saying that I live in the caribbean and this is the second tablet that I have bought from Amazon ( the first being the original Kindle Fire). What I didn't know when I purchased the Kindle Fire was that the apps, e-books and amazon instant video are only available to customers in the U.S. (even though we are allowed to purchase books with the normal Kindle from our country, Trinidad). This is not case with the Galaxy Tab 2. You can download apps, watch Netflix(this comes pre-installed) and play games with other opponents online immediately after the registration process is complete. The volume button and the power button is well placed, even though the power button should have been a slide toggle switch rather than a push button toggle switch, to prevent it from accidentally activating (helpful when playing 8 ball pool), while you are turning the tablet for an alternate view. Its pretty loud even though I think there should be speakers on the sides when watching the tablet in landscape mode. There is a universal remote app which works fine( this also comes pre-installed on the tablet). The camera quality is a little poor , then again it is a 3.15 mp. The battery life is ok once not under heavy usage. I opted for 7&#34; cause it fits easily in big pocket clothing, like cargo pants and track pants. And you can't beat a price like $179.00 for an android based tablet. A good buy!

tablet_galaxy_tab|Don't be fooled by other sub-300 dollar tablets. If you go the generic route, even if the product boasts a 1.5 ghz processor, you're likely to be disappointed with the performance. You will not be disappointed with the Galaxy Tab. It's what a 7" tablet should be. It's fast enough to be useful. It can multi-task well. It's small enough to fit inside a purse or larger jacket pocket. It has good battery life and an impressive screen. Get a drop protective cover for it, and you should have a functional tablet for at least 2 years.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I was one of the early adopters of the Kindle Fire who got caught up in all the hype. It didn't take long for me to find many things I didn't like about it, but I won't mention them here. After giving it away, I decided to get the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2. Believe me when I say that it was a major upgrade. Electronics are just one of many things that I'm very picky about.Having played with a few other Android tablets, I think that Samsung makes some of the best Android tablets. They also previously listened to their customers, and no longer mess with the stock OS.Pros:Depending on how you use it, the Galaxy Tab 2 has a very good battery life (TV shows/movies will drain the battery quickly).The screen is very bright and has excellent color.It's a great deal for the price (it's actually dropped in price since I bought it).Cons:Samsung forces you to have a few apps that I'm sure most people don't want (Next Issue, for instance), and you can't delete them.The included cable is too short. They don't even make a longer aftermarket cable, so I have to use a USB extension. I also think it's stupid that the Samsung cable is almost an exact copy of the Apple cable.Overall, this is a great tablet, and I'd recommend it to anyone who wants a quality Android tablet.Edit: It seems that a longer aftermarket cable is actually made for the Galaxy Tab 2. I should've searched again before reviewing.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|We have 2 IPad 3's, and although we like them one big issue with Apple is no option to expand the memory with your own media. The Galaxy has a mini sd card slot which lets you transfer your own media to the device without having to pay for it. I have software that I use to convert dvd's to avi movies and to make MP3's from my cd collection, then I just move the files onto the mini sd card and I have it all on my Galaxy. Apple won't let you do this forcing you to repurchase any media you want.I love the Galazy so much the I purchased another for my wife. As for the I-Pads thery will go to E-Bay. tablet_galaxy_tab|This is a great gadget for the price. I've had no problems using it with my home wi-fi. This is ny first tablet so I have no comparisons. It seems to have quick response. I have been fasicnated with tablets since they first came out, but,with a 3 computer home network, including 2 laptops, and also a smart phone, I jsut couldn't justify spending $600 plus on a tablet that I didn't really need, plus a monthly cell service for it. So, I settled on this $199 wi-fi only tablet. I was already setup with Samsung and Google through my Galaxy SII phone, so this tablet was easy to learn and setup. I find the display quality very good.I plan to use the 32gb micro sd I bought with the tab to store my music and pictures on. The reason I chose this over the Kindle Fire was because of the ability to expand the memory with the micro sd, the Android OS, and the built-in GPS. I have not used the GPS yet, so I will add to this review if I have something significant to add. Even with the kind of bulky case I got for it, I can put it in my big purse.I teach a computer class at our local Senior Center and I like to stay up on the latest gadgets available so I can help others with theirs. This would be a great beginner computer for somebody.With no trouble at all, using the Smart Remote app that came on the tab, I had it setup to control my TV, satellite receiver, stereo receiver, Roku, and 2 Blu-Ray players. Very cool. I love how I could re-install apps I had already installed on my phone on play,google.com to my new tablet. If the app says 'installed' click on it, then it will tell you if it is compatible with your new device, and you can install it to just the new device.I have not tried the camera yet, but I didn't buy this for the camera. It probably doesn't take as good a picture as my phone or digital camera, so I'm not worried about it. It would be good enoug to video chat on.The only thing I don't like about this tablet is the propritary plug in for charging. I will just have to carry this plug with the tablet I guess.I would recommend this to anyone who doesn't need to connect to the internet when not near a wi-fi, and wants a nice functional tablet at a very good price.

---
tablet_galaxy_tab|Got this little treasure as an early birthday present from my wife during Black Friday ($179) and have not been disappointed by it in my 3 months with it thus far. This is my first tablet, and my main usage of the tablet consists of light gaming, web-surfing, reading (e-mail and e-books), and the occasional movie trailer on Youtube. The display is good enough for its size; while the HD displays on the Kindle Fire HD and Nexus 7 are preferred, they are more of a novelty than a necessity for me. The option for the external storage is a big plus as well. It allows me to not bog down the already limited internal memory, which is about 5GB user accessible. Not to mention, the recent upgrade to Jelly Bean 4.1.1 gave a nice bump in overall performance. The sound quality is nothing to write home about, but it suffices. I usually get about 8-10 hours of usage out of this, with wi-fi usually turned off while I read.For what it offers, while not the best or ground-breaking, the Tab 2 delivers a good entry-level tablet experience.
---

But that is a android problem not a samsung problem. I have used the peel app to turn on and off my big 20 year old big box TV and it worked well. Some people have complained about the issue with only having half the memory they clain it has but it has not been a problem for me. It also has Adobe flash player which can be install on the Adobe archives web page. It works well. If you have any question please feel free to post them and I will try to answer them quickly. Sorry if this review is bad it's one of my first.Update:I have had this device for several months now. It get over 8 hours of battery with wifi on but screen brightness on really low. I now check out books from the library on it and can even access my Barns and Noble NOOK account. I had some more trouble with the wifi but found out it was just the default internet app. Got mozzarella Firefox and got everthing worked smoothly. I now take science notes with the notes application it came with then I back them up to Google drive. Its a really cool feature. If you get the cable to plug in USBs it works with anything that does not have a battery.I still have no regrets but will keep updating my review when I find new things it can do.
