tablet_galaxy_tab|I bought a packaged deal that included a Samsung Galaxy Tab 2, a case, and a 32GB SD card. This is my only complaint so far about this tablet, but for some reason, it appears you cannot move apps to an external SD card, and moving files like photos/video (not sure about being able to move music files) to the SD card requires copying and pasting to the SD card via swapping between folders. You can set your default storage of photos/video via the camera app, but otherwise it's a bit of a chore to move files to the SD card. If you require/want external storage, you probably should look/should have looked into file transferring on this tablet and/or look into another tablet. While I don't plan on taking many photos/recording videos/listening to music on this tablet, I'll just deal with transfers for now. If not being able to easily transfer files is an Android version 4.0.X issue, then idk. I assumed it would be just like the camera app in Android version 2.3.6, which is my Samsung Epic 4G phone's version...

tablet_galaxy_tab|The Tab 2 is a good start off for entering the tablet world. Not too expensive so it's not high end but it's not too cheap to where it's hardware is low quality. It gets slow after running too many apps but theres a widget that brings you to the task manager to close them down. Battery life is good as long as it's brightness is kept on automatic and it's not being turned on every 20-30 seconds while on the road.Apps I commonly use for this:Chrome, Google+, Gmail, Facebook, tumblr, instagram, google music, and google voice.As you can see, I use it for a lot of google based stuff (it's an android thing, y'know?). Social websites run smoothly based on wifi bandwidth. Chrome can open any website/flash animation/gifs no problem, of course with bandwidth kept in mind. Like any other Android device, I recommend a SD card with more than 16GB+ on the side cause this tablet can easiley be a media hub. The screen (7in) is big enough for watching vids in comfort, and the base music app offers some interesting options. Photo app comes with a customizable slideshow option too. Games? vary on what you download. I don't recommend 3D MMO's just cause theres potential for failure and that correlates with the proccessor, not the screen size.One thing I need to mention is it's ability to act as a remote (app pre-installed) to control tv's (samsung only). The reciever for it is on the right hand side of the device. I haven't tried it yet but I guess if you just so happen to have a recent model samsung tv then by all means, go for it. regardless of this semi-useless feature, it's still worth the investment. Plus it fits in my cargo pockets.UPDATE 31JAN13So my I upgraded my Galaxy Tab to 4.1 Jellybean. Theres no real complaints about the new UI from me. I've noticed that now I can multi task while watching a video, though this feature might have always been there. Theres nothing too major to point out and with that in mind I have to say that as long as the tablet isn't overloaded with crap, it'll always run fine. Android devices are only limited by the hardware's potential and this tablet has a lot.

tablet_galaxy_tab|There are two kinds of people in the world... ones that have used smartphones and tablets.. and the ones that haven't. The ones that haven't number enough to fit on the head of a pin. I am one of those people. But FINALLY, I'm making the jump into handheld mobile computing, and this Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 is working out splendidly. So, a few remarks for anyone else just now jumping off the head of that pin into the 21st century...1) This tablet is awesome. Thumbs up. Absolutely recommend. For the price it is a great value. No reason this should not be a good a choice for newcomers. I figured for $200 if I dump it in a year for something else it would still be a good deal. But I'm sticking with this unit until the technology rolls over (probably about a year ;>).2) It runs the latest version of the Android operating system. The system is not 'locked' as on other hardware sold with Android such as the Kindle. This means maximum compatibility with the apps you wish to install. And believe me, once you have gotten used to the basic functioning of the tablet, it's ALL about the apps.3) Tablet/mobile computing is a life changing experience. Mobile computing is nearly as revolutionary as the Internet itself. I would dare say that mobile computing is more useful in your personal day-to-day life than traditional desktop computing. Desktop computing started in the 'Dark Ages' (DOS, early graphical user interfaces), and proceeded to the "Middle Ages' (evolved operating systems, voice recognition, data sharing, etc), but has basically stalled. Portable computing is the evolutionary leap into the 'Renaissance'. Computers are now beginning to behave the way people who know nothing about computers expect computers to behave (more Star Trek like).4) The 7" form factor is a great size. Not too big. Not too small. I no longer use my iPod Touch to listen to music (except when exercising). I installed the 'TuneSync' app which copied all my iTunes music and playlists to the tablet. And because the tablet is right-sized I tend to take it everywhere. A good portion of the work that used to accomplish on my laptop is performed on the tablet.5) Accessories purchased: Leather case. Also acts as a backstop to prop the tablet up on a flat surface for hands feww viewing (Poetic Slimbook Leather Case for Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 Black. A memory card to expand storage SanDisk 32 GB Mobile microSDHC Flash Memory Card SDSDQ-032G-AFFP. Both of these have been invaluable. Next purchase will likely be a Bluetooth keyboard.6) There IS a learning curve. This is a different world from desktop computing. Different interface. Different terms and acronyms. Different mind-set. Although you can somewhat intuitively learn the touch based interface and run apps and even download and install new apps, the process of syncing your desktop data with the tablet (music, images, videos, documents) is a WORK IN PROGRESS. The free Samsung application for its tablets that supposedly helps with this is a bit of a joke (Kies). You are sort of left to develop the wheel on your own, so try and hook up with a kid or someone who has figured out how to set up sync media for your tablet, specifically to the external add-on memory card (where there's more room to put everything). That will save you some headaches.---------------------------------UPDATE February 22, 2013: Best way to RootOnce you get your tablet all set up --which can take many many hours of copying songs, photos, videos, etc., plus downloading and configuring apps, plus futzing with various settings, plus arranging all your icons, plus operating system updates-- you want a way to back up EVERYTHING in case you lose your tablet, or whatever. Unfortunately it seems the native Android operating system running on this tablet does not provide a way to back up EVERYTHING. I tried several apps from the app store, the native Google cloud backup, and the Samsung Kies backup... and none of them backed up EVERYTHING. Each of these apps back up a FEW things. For example, none of them backed up my email account settings. I learned that the only way to get a true, full backup is to "root" your tablet. Rooting simply means gaining full control over the Android OS. Rooting can void your warranty, but not having to spend another couple of days redoing everything (assuming I could even remember everything I did) made it worth rooting my tablet. If you choose to the root route here is the best link I found for doing so after quite a bit of research: Wait... ok, the Amazonian Police have removed the links. Just go to the galaxy-tab2 website (add the c-o-m). That's the ticket.Once you have the tablet rooted you want to do that EVERYTHING backup I keep mentioning. Install a free app called "ROM Manger" from ClockworkMOD, which will back up ALL of the main memory card of the tablet (but not the removable external card). For the procedure google 'nandroid backup galaxy tab 2' and look for the link entitled 'How to Perform a Nandroid Backup and Restore it to your Android'.Another useful [free] backup app good for doing SELECTIVE backups and restores (it's wisest to use both) is 'Titanium Backup'.---------------------------------UPDATE February 28, 2013: A few good appsMost of the Samsung supplied apps can be replaced with [usually free] more robust counterparts from the google play store. I did the following:The built-in Gallery app for displaying photos and video doesn't allow much flexibility over the sort order of your photos, so I replaced it with Photo Gallery from Fish Bowl Software.The native Google Play Music app is pretty good, but Rocket Music Player from JRT Studio has a few extras like a sleep timer, an indicator of how many songs are in a playlist, and the ability to specify the media folder. I also installed MixZing because it is one of the few players that can display song lyrics imbedded in the music file (as with iTunes).I use iTunes, and a good app for syncing your library to the tablet is TuneSync from Fireleap software ($5.99 for unlimited version). It copies over songs, playlists, and any "meta data" in the song files such as album art and lyrics.A good non-cloud alternative to the stumbly Samsung supplied Kies app for syncing other data from a computer is Cheetah Sync. The free version will sync one folder on the PC to the tablet. For $2.99 you get unlimited folder sync. A stay away from The Cloud as much as possible so this is a rare find.Other nifty apps are Google Sky Map for viewing and identifying stars. 3D Digital Weather Clock displays weather, date, time, moon phase, and battery charge. Nav Free provides turn-by-turn voice prompted navigation without the need for a wifi connection. Handrite Free allows you to take notes by writing on the tablet with a stylus or your finger. The built in Memo app does a good job for typed notes. ListNote let's you speak your memos and converts them to text. Google Translate for speaking sentences you type in a different language.And many many many more...
---

tablet_galaxy_tab|I purchased the seven-inch Galaxy Tab 2, with 8 GB storage on board, and an SD memory card with an additional 32 GB. Of the 8 GB on board, only about 4.5 GB were available, because of space needed by the OS and by preloaded applications. I thought I would be well off, until I discovered that you cannot install anything to the memory card. That is, you can't install applications there or move them there. It's true that you can load your own videos or music there by using perhaps file transfer from your computer. But the apps have to be able to recognize data there. Direct downloads to the device will usually go into on board storage. Only a few apps are set up to write their data where you wish. For example, you can stream your Amazon MP3 music from the cloud; but if you ask the Amazon app to download any of your items, you have no choice as to where they will go.As I understand it, this is a limitation of the Android operating system, and has been true for the last few versions. And there is apparently no way around this. So this is not the fault of Samsung, but it certainly reduces the appeal of the Galaxy Tab 2, which is otherwise an attractive and well-performing unit.
---

tablet_galaxy_tab|I bought this item because it has a microsd card slot; the Google Nexus 7" that I have - which I love - does not. And I wanted the extra storage capacity. I shipped the unit back to Amazon today for several reasons, but the biggest is that the screen gave off an unbelievable amount of heat somewhere in the 1+ hour range of video watching. It was just weird - at first I didn't know what was going on because I have the Nexus and the Samsung Tab 2 10" and neither have this problem. I had noticed battery life isn't nearly as good as the Nexus but I didn't track that very closely. The heat, though - let's face it, if a unit is giving off heat, that means the battery is draining at uber speed. Plus, the screen should not be emitting heat - not in a small tablet, or even a big one, for that matter. I searched the Net and saw the issue mentioned in some other Samsung devices - phones, mostly, I believe. Make sure to check this out before ordering. The Galaxy Tab 2 7" feels flimsy next to the Nexus - which I now love even more than before. Sometimes extra weight is good - it means the product is made well with good materials - and will last longer. I like my Samsung Tab 2 10" very much - this also accepts a microsd card so I guess I'll be using that when I need more storage. In short: buy the Nexus 7, not the Galaxy Tab 2 7.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I purchased this tablet for two reasons - it was cheap but seemed well-made, and I prefer the Android OS over iOS. I use it mainly for note-taking in class (I am a first-year nursing student) and it works well. The Android app store, though lacking in some places, offered many choices for PDF annotation (what I use to take notes) but to anyone who needs this for PDF annotation purposes, look no further than the free Adobe Reader app. The functionality and interface is perfect and the app I paid $4 I deleted after a few days.The tablet is perfect for watching videos and playing games, as well as taking notes. I wish I would have bought the larger, 10.1-inch version, though, because 7 inches is just a little on the small side for taking notes.The touch screen is iffy at times if you use a stylus - I would suggest springing for a nice one with a large pad. My cheap stylus sometimes doesn't register well and can make writing illegible. I have tried using my cheap stylus on my roommate's iPad, though, and it worked well - it's clearly the Tab's touch screen that is the problem.Overall a good tablet, but I would suggest students purchase the larger version.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I bought this very affordably priced tablet to bring to work with me (slow-paced third shift job with lots of down time). One week later and I love this tablet. The battery life is great! From turn on to the time the device powered itself off was 9.5 hours, and that was with near constant use. The entire time I was connected to WiFi, running trillian, surfing the internet, using various apps on and off, and all with no task killer app. I thought that was pretty amazing, but this is my first tablet.So far I am digging the heck out of my tablet. I find the infared red blaster and pre-installed smartpeel app really novel; I quite enjoy being able to quickly switch between whatever I happen to be browsing and a tv guide type app and change the channel to whatever my heart desires. But like I said, it's just a novel addition and I am sure I wouldn't miss it if the device didn't have an infared blaster. I wish there was more internal storage, but for $50 more than the kindle (a device that relies on a cloud service for storage) and microsd card slot, whateva. I also find that the keyboard leaves something to be desired, but the app market takes care of that.In summation, if you are debating between this and another tablet, or find yourself overwhelmed by all the options available to you, just suck it up and buy this tablet. Most likely you won't regret it.

tablet_galaxy_tab|My first tablet but my second Android device. My first is an LG Ally smartpone(Android 2.2.2).Using that for almost the last 2 years I've learned what limitations that hardware has with the software.The Ally was an entry-level smartphone with the bare minimum to run Android. Even with a large SD card I often get a "getting low on phone memory" notice. The deal is That you can not run apps from the SM card. Apps run from the "phone"'s built in memory only.With this being my experience with an Android device upgrading to a Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 was very pleasant. It works and has not choked on anything I've tried on it. I've loaded everything I had on my Ally plus Skype and I still have over 4 Gigs free on the internal memory. Another nice point is that there isn't a lot of bloatware taking up resources (if I wanted Facebook on it I can download the app, Thanks Samsung!).7 inch screen is nice on all accounts, the form factor works for me, I would think the 10 inch would be too big to carry around all the time. I've watched a few movies streamed from Netflix and it was enjoyable. The speakers on this are better than the ones in my 15 inch Acer Laptop, they actually have base!Could I have spent more for better specs on a tablet? Sure but I don't think I could have gotten a better value. It has the resources to do what I want it to do.Grips:1) Why is the On/Off button on the side? I'm still learning how to hold the thing and being new I'm often accidentally hitting it, putting it in screensaver mode, why not have it on the front?2) Battery life is good unless I turn on the GPS. I may want to get a charger for it in the car.3) I would like to be able to use this outdoors sometimes. It's gloss. Got a Matte screen protector and that helps with the glare. That is the one thing I liked about the ad for the original Kindle (Electric paper) You can read it while on the beach, That's the trade-off for having a color screen, It's the Physics.I'm very happy with this. One of the justifications for getting this is that my contract with Verizon is comming up and I'm wondering if I can drop my Data plan (Why am I paying over $500 a year for data) when most of the time I'm in range of wifi anyway. This just may be able to save me alot of money in the long run and I can do more with it.

I didn't have any problems syncing my Google account.I did manage to get the peel remote to work with my U verse, Samsung TV and RCA 5.1 stereo, I think the interface is a little quirky, the controls are strange and a little cumbersome, it also has a bunch of program suggestions, none that I like. tablet_galaxy_tab|After a weak experience with a Nexus 7 that failed after but a short drop (in its protective case) from four feet, I decided to give the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 (7-inch) a try, to see whether it was better made and workable for me. My Galaxy Tab 2 came with Android Jelly Bean already installed, so it is a recently-produced unit.Here's a quick summary of the pros and cons of the Galaxy Tab 2:PROS- It's made and supported by Samsung. (The Nexus 7 is sold as a Google product, but hardware support comes from ASUS while software support comes from Google.)- Well-liked device with a good 10 months of history behind it now.- Long battery life (10-12 hours claimed)- Fast enough (dual core CPU)- Expandable memory (to 32GB) via microSD- IR port for use as a remote- forward AND rear-facing cameras- The unit feels sturdy in the handCONS- The active-matrix organic LED (AMOLED) display has a green cast to it; it's noticeable with white backgrounds and movies.- Screen resolution is now middle-of-the-pack at 1024x600 (about 170 dpi), versus the 1280x800 (about 215-220 dpi) of the Nexus 7.- Touch screen is not very sensitive compared to Nexus 7 and iPad.- Processing power, while adequate, lags the Nexus 7 with its quad-core CPU.- The forward-facing camera is VGA resolution (640x480=300k pixel) versus the Nexus 7's 1.3 megapixel. On anything bigger than a phone, you'll notice the lack of resolution.- The rear-facing camera offers weak performance.- Uses Samsung-proprietary connector rather than a standard USB port on the tablet. (Nexus 7 uses microUSB.)In view of my experience with the Nexus, I really did want to like the Samsung. After living with it for several days, though, I simply kept noticing its deficiencies relative to the Nexus 7. The screen resolution is the most noticeable thing. Smaller fonts on the GT2 show a marked blockiness and, for my mid-40s eyes, are harder to read. The additional resolution on the Nexus 7, while still not up to the standard set by Apple's Retina display, made the screen much easier on my eyes. Further, the green cast on my GT2 (which others have noticed, based on my web searches for a solution, to no avail) makes reading e-books and watching Netflix movies less pleasant.Then there's the matter of touch-screen sensitivity. You'll only notice this one if you've used a more sensitive device, like an iPad or the Nexus. However, I routinely had to touch and wiggle a finger-tip to get the GT2 to recognize a press. Flipping pages in an e-book was a bit hit-or-miss, as was adjusting volume, scrolling, or playing a card game. The Nexus and iPad are simply better here.I could live with the slightly lower performance of the GT2, but that, too, is noticeable, if you've used a higher-performance unit. Animations are a little slower, hiccups are more frequent, etc.Don't get me wrong. The Galaxy Tab 2 is a nice tablet, sturdily constructed and with attention to details from a major manufacturer, especially for the price in April *2012*. But we're almost a year past that now. For about $200, you get a GT2 with 8GB of flash, but that's not as a good a value as the competition is now offering, especially if the IR or a weak rear-facing camera isn't important to you. (Bringing your GT2 to its maximum 32GB via microSD will put you within about $20-$30 of the Nexus 7 32GB, and within $100 or so of the iPad mini 16GB.) It's time for a Galaxy Tab 3.UPDATE: I have attempted to write a balanced review of this tablet. Others may disagree with what I've written, but consider my points before answering the question "Was this review helpful to you?" The question is not "Do you agree with this reviewer?" but "Was it helpful?" If each review praised and gushed about a product, it wouldn't be very helpful, would it? Even less helpful is the "I like this product. U must get one 2." review.
---

tablet_galaxy_tab|I purchased this tablet months ago when they first came out, and pretty much totally satisfied/happy with it. It has become real competition for the others and has set a new standard in quality and price. Excellent quality high resolution screen and works well. Not perfect, but close to it. I did have one problem, when using Angry Birds Rio (free version). It would re-cycle back and start over again during play. By researching blogs I found the solution. TURN ON AIRPLANE MODE during play, and the problem is gone. I have a 16GB microSD memory card in it, have downloaded 4 full length movies so far and they look great. I would recommend a 32GB card since it will accept it. This tablet is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. (This review updated December 31, 2012.)

tablet_galaxy_tab|This is my 2nd "touch' device after my iPod Touch 4gen and it has certainly been a learning experience. A few negatives future buyers might like to know:Doesn't include headphones or FM antennae (Galaxy Players include them); the built in camera app doesn't work outdoors after update to 4.0.4 (it still does video and other camera apps work though); the 3mp rear camera doesn't have a flash or auto-focus (picture quality is only on par with the 1mp rear iPod camera); the WiFi connectivity, though adequate so far, is not as good as the iPod Touch; the IR port "Peel" app is very limited so don't buy this thinking you are getting a universal remote; it is nearly impossible to find a TPU, silicone gel or hard case for the Tab 2, only big leather type coversWhat $199 does get you vs. some other $199 devices:A functioning GPS (no GPS antennae in the $299 iPod Touch 5 or $199 Kindle Fire HD); a wall plug ($20 extra for KF HD); a rear camera and microSD slot (not on either KF HD or Google Nexus)iOS 5.0 vs Android 4.0.4:It has taken me several days to learn Android, it's about the same difference as PC vs. Mac I suppose (I hate MacOS and Finder). There are several apps missing I would like as everyone has noted elsewhere, and the "same' apps don't all work the same. I do like all the info Android makes available in settings and options which puts you in control, but if you want to sit back and enjoy the ride iOS might be more for you.EDIT: The iPad mini was just announced at $329 without GPS, similar screen resolution (1024x780) and better camera, but probably too wide to hold in my hand, so I'm still ok buying this for $199. If the mini were $229 I might have had regrets.

tablet_galaxy_tab|This is the second brand new Galaxy Tab 2 (7" model)that has not worked properly in one week. Amazon delivery and CS has been excellent but the performance of the unit and Samsung's CS sub-standard. I had great hopes based on Samsung's good name and the Tab's great features for the price. Being that this is a Wi-Fi model, I am rating it poorly because of it's inability to connect me to the internet.I have linked multiple devices, laptops and smart-phones using various OS to my Wi-Fi Network w/out ANY glitches, BUT the Galaxy Tab couldn't yield a real/true connection. I am versed in setting up Networks and Wi-Fi connections, and Samsung's CS asked me twice to send the unit back calling it faulty. Two brand new units ? Let's get real! Unfortunately I can't stop to come to the conclusion that something in the hardware or software is not being able to fully connect with Wi-Fi's properly. I am using an N router and tried many ways to resolve the issue. From the beginning the Tab would identify the signal with the correct SSID and reported a strong signal and was unable to obtain the IP address and was not able to connect. I followed their suggestions by a) manually entering my network b) resetting the tab and c) entering the network spec's w/ a Static mode. All along the security password was recognized and secured. When using the static option I was finally able to achieve a connected status ( a short lived yeah!). While under "connected" status I was NOT able to truly connect to the internet or a google account, either the one I have been using, or even creating a new one. I spent 2.5 hours combined between phone CS and Chat CS to end up with their advise to return the unit and get a replacement.I have wasted enough time and will not get a Samsung Galaxy Tab. I honestly wish it would have worked, but if it is going to be this hazzle on a perfectly good network/WiFi set-up I don't want to waste more time and/or have this degree of difficulty when trying to link to other networks. Under the CS guidance we even switched my N Router to the b & g modes and it failed as well.I am again on the research mode to see which 7" Tab to get?? I don't like to bash a manufacturer and am hoping that this is a glitch that Samsung will correct. It has been a very wasteful experience; my time and Amazon's money absorbing the shipping costs! One of Samsung's CS said to me that my case was not unique, that he has seen other reports of inability of the Tab to connect with some WiFi's.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I've owned or worked with 4 different 7" Android OS tablets. When choosing a tablet it's all about what you will use it for. I like the Acer Iconia A110 the most because it has the most "utility". It's sort of the jack of all trades of these devices. It may not do anything the best but it can do the most. I hope that makes sense. I hope my review will help you choose your tablet. Here's the comparisonsAcer Iconia A110 - $199Pros - GPS, HDMI Out, Micro SD card slot, Google PlayCons - Screen Resolution 1024 x 600, Speed is just a tad bit slower than the others,the device is physically thicker and more bulky than the others.Notes: This would be a 5 star product if it had a better screen. Only 8GB internal storage without adding a micro SD card. I am able to stream amazon flash based videos by downloading a different browser than the stock chrome. This device runs Android OS 4.1 (Jelly Bean)Kindle Fire HD - $199Pros - Performance Speed, HDMI Out, Amazon Instant Video, Screen Resolution 1280 x 800Cons - No GPS, No Micro SD Card Slot, No Android Market/Google Play (Amazon Market only by default), Have to purchase wall charger separately, Layout isn't the standard Android OS GUI. Amazon has created their own UI.Notes: Excellent product but the lack of GPS and micro sd card slot is disappointing. The amazon based apps (kindle books & video etc..) have a wonderful UI in comparison to the other 3 devices. 16GB internal storage for the same price as the others is better value. This device is very "sleek" This device runs Android OS 4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich) under the Amazon Kindle GUI.Google Nexus 7 - $199Pros - Performance Speed, GPS, Screen Resolution 1280 x 800, Google PlayCons - No Micro SD card Slot No HDMI OutNotes: Great product would easily be the best unit if they added HDMI out and a micro sd card slot. This device has 16GBs of storage like the Kindle Fire HD. This devices runs Android 4.1 (Jelly Bean) by default.Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 - $199Pros - Performance Speed, GPS, Micro SD Card Slot, Google PlayCons - Screen Resolution 1024 x 600, No HDMI Out (they make a hdmi out adapter for the other galaxy tab/note models but not for the 7").Notes: Only 8GBs of internal storage like the Acer Iconia A110. This device runs Android OS 4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich) by default. For me not having HDMI out is the killer.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I'm writing this review on the Galaxy Tab 2.Cons:1. Samsung messed it up with "their" bluetooth stack! This device will not pair or stay paired with some bluetooth devices out there. It pairs fine with my media device to stream music, but it has issues with my OBD2 bluetooth adapter for my car.I bought this device mainly to dock it in my car to use with the Torque app (great app btw) via bluetooth to my car's OBD-II using BAFX Brand - ELM327 BLUETOOTH - OBDII OBD2 DIAGNOSTIC SCANNER - CAN ELM 327 SCANTOOL - CHECK ENGINE LIGHT CAR CODE READER. I can pair using my phone or other non-Samsung device. When using this Tab it would not stay paired and would keep prompting me for the passcode. I enter the code and it pops up again (yes I am using the correct code)! I have to unpair, reboot, then pair again to get it to work. Imagine having to do this every time you get in your car!They should have left the bluetooth stack alone. I have heard that this is the case with most of their products. A workaround would be to root it and flash a custom ROM with a proper bluetooth stack but it's not our responsibility to fix Samsung's half-baked bluetooth stack! I have read that Samsung is aware of this issue and will release an update *some day*.2. Touchscreen does not respond well to LONG tap-and-holds. When tap-and-holding for long periods, it would become unresponsive and require you to retap-and-hold. Sometimes it doesn't respond on the first retap and you have to keep trying. It happens a lot when playing racing games where you want to tap-and-hold to accelerate. Out of nowhere it would lose track of my finger. Very annoying and my replacement unit has the same problem.3. Wi-Fi reception is weak! Don't expect to be able to connect to your router if it's on the other side of the house. Where I can get 1-2 bars of signal on may laptop, this Tab says the network is out of range.4. There is no way to remove the mini-apps (that arrow pointing up in the bottom-middle). The mini-apps are not that useful and it just takes up space. This should be optional.5. The camera is very poor, then again you can't expect much from one with less than 8MP these days.6. Charging is slow and requires Samsungs cable. Also, the supplied cable is too short. A standard USB plug would be ideal.Pros:-Good size where it's comfortable to type in portrait and landscape mode, and still fits in my pocket.-Not too heavy so I can hold it all day.-Somewhat quick and responsive CPU/GPU.-Decent screen (visible in direct sunlight).-Battery life decent with heavy use, power save mode on, and max brightness (a few more hours to get through the day would be nice).Not everybody will be using the Tab like me (pair with OBD2 bluetooth device or play racing games) so these issues may not be a problem. The Tab is still a great device and very robust. I would recommend it.

tablet_galaxy_tab|It is a great resource for accessing important information you need in your daily life at home and on the road. Lithium battery life last for hours, charges fast. I purchased the cheap Bluetooth leather/rubber keypad and it works great. I can read all my Emails, News, Weather, Research, and a lot more. The settings for the main controls are easy to access because of the info screen on the bottom right when you tap there it pops up. There is also a short cut screen if you touch the front center it pops up on the bottom of screen. Touch screen works very good, has many options that are customizable, and is nicely done. Many apps that are preinstalled I don't need, I have to find a way to get ride of them permanently, for now you can only delete the updates and the factory copy is reinstalled. Samsung has a full blown keyboard docking station that you can purchase for $79.There is a lot of junk you can install from the WEB, be careful, install AVG FREE Antivirus. Watch what apps you download so they don't rob your CPU power. A lot of the apps track you, in some you can turn options off in the program settings to save power or manually turn off WiFi and GPS and turn them on as needed.*** Important ***1) There is 8gb of internal storage (depending on the model you have), but they install the operating system on it which takes up almost half of it leaving you with 4.59gb left. You can put a lot of stuff in there even with only the standard memory! You can also install up to 32gb of external flash memory but be careful and take your time, it is tricky to put that little thin sucker into the side slot without dropping it and until it clicks. Kind of a balancing act on one finger then push it in with your thumb nail.2) There is no paperback user manual, you need to download .PDF file from their website. The paper manual costs over $20.00!! Call Samsung and gripe, maybe we all can get them to send us all one for free!All in all a very nice unit, buy one now if you can wait while they are on back order."This is not a toy" for children. READ THE HUGE SAFETY BOOKLET THAT COMES WITH UNIT or manual pages 206 and 207.*** Update ***It is amazing all the features this has, the apps are endless. I just did my online banking and deposited my check from home, I used the banks app and tried the mobile deposit and it worked!!You can search your TV listings, weather, read the Bible, find POI with the GPS, Skype video calls, make free land line calls with GrooveIP or Gmail. tablet_galaxy_tab|I own an original Galaxy Tab 7" wifi and the new Galaxy Tab 2 7" wifi, and honestly, I have to say the old one is better in almost every respect.Pros:*The GTab 2 is lighter, faster, thinner, and has slightly louder speakers.*Runs Android 4.0 and the screen is very pretty.*Has all the features you'd expect... with one glaring exception (See below).*Since it has a newer version of Android, it works with Bluetooth keyboards and HID devices.Cons:*The camera is horrible compared to the old one. It doesn't auto-focus, has no flash, has worse resolution, and you can't use it to scan barcodes (which I did a lot with my old GTab). I loved using the flash LED as a flashlight, too... works so much better than using the whole screen. I wish they would have left the camera alone, I would have paid the money for it.*The WiFi antenna is situated so that if you hold it upright with your left hand, WiFi reception is almost nothing. Hold it with the other hand (on the other side), it works perfectly. Why is it like this? The old GTab never did this.*When connected to a non-Windows computer, it won't let you connect as USB storage. Very frustrating, I can't just plug it in and copy files to it like my old one.*The auto-dim screen feature seems to always make it darker than it needs to be. I'm always finding myself turning auto-dim off because I just can't read the screen. Old one wasn't like this.My opinion:If I had known the camera was so bad on this, I wouldn't have bought it, even at the low price I got it for. I used the camera for close-up photos, some low-light shots, and scanning barcodes... none of which the GTab 2 can do. In every other respect it works great- good performance, etc- but I'm really second-guessing my decision to buy it based on the camera. I was hoping it would be a great replacement for my old GTab workhorse, but it falls short. I will probably give it to my daughter and reclaim my old GTab.

tablet_galaxy_tab|Let me preface by saying that I originally purchased this tablet for my kids because they kept bogarding my iPad 2. As it turns out, the device really grew on me, especially the IR capabilities which allow me to control my extensive home theater devices. In addition, my job involves quite a bit of travel and the Samsung is a great device for traveling since it's smaller than the iPad.It has a fantastic display and Android allows you the ability to customize it with active themes and personalized widgets. The device is easier to handle than the iPad, and in landscape mode the navigation buttons are easily reached with your thumbs.The only real negative are the apps. There's no question that Apple has a better selection of Apps, especially for kids. You would think developers would actually devote more effort to the Android OS since there are more devices running Android than IOS. I think once Android catches up from a development perspective, Apple is going to have real trouble. The Galaxy S3 phone for example is light years ahead of the 4S and will still be a better device than the iPhone 5.The other negative as others have noted is that the battery life isn't as great as the iPad. Overall, I've very pleased with the Galaxy Tab 7.

tablet_galaxy_tab|(I've also put this review under the Kindle Fire HD) I'm not one to typically write reviews but since I spent a long time researching the right tablet for our family I thought I'd give my opinion. First, the main use for our tablet was for the kids to play apps (fun and educational) and watch movies/shows. I wanted to be able to download movies/shows so they could watch them on the plane or if we didn't have wifi access I also plan to use it for books for them and me. I have other Apple products but didn't want to spend the money on something that the kids would primarily be using. With that said I narrowed my purchase down to the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 and the Kindle Fire HD. I actually bought both and tried both for a few days. I read many reviews and most said to go with the Galaxy. BUT, in the end I liked the Kindle Fire HD much better and here were my reasons:1. I thought the screen quality was better on the Kindle Fire HD (it is amazing!!!).2. The screen size was a little wider.3. The interface was much more user friendly with the Kindle.4. I'm a big Amazon Shopper and it just made more sense to go with the Kindle plus I plan to keep the Prime Membership up after the trial. Like that you can borrow a book a month, get free streaming of tons of shows and movies, free 2 day shipping), lots of free books.5. Supposedly there are many less Amazon apps than on Google Play but this has not been an issue with us at all. All the apps we want are available on the Amazon store.6. The big seller for me was the 16 gb internal memory versus 8 gb for the Galaxy. Also, in reality the Galaxy only has 4 gb internal memory because half it taken up already by the operating system and other stuff that is loaded that you can't delete. I do understand that there is the option to get an external SD card and in fact I have one but, FIRST, you can't store any apps on it only photos and movies, SECOND, it is a royal pain to transfer stuff to the extSD Card (you have to plug the tablet into the computer, transfer the files onto the computer and then put them back onto the tablet into the extSD card section. Weird!)7. So, even though the Kindle Fire HD with 16 gb is really only about 13 gb I like the fact that it has almost 3 times more internal memory8. The Kindle felt of high quality build.9. I have family members with the Kindle so we can share some books (not as many as we hoped but still a neat feature).10. Battery Life better with the Kindle Fire HD.11. Sound better too with Kindle.So, these are my 2 cents for what it's worth. I liked the Samsung Galaxy but I loved the Kindle Fire HD for what we wanted to use a tablet for. Happy shopping. I don't think you will be disappointed with either one!

tablet_galaxy_tab|I purchased this tablet in May of 2012 and have been generally satisfied with its' performance. I use it mostly for reading but have also found some of the applications useful for me. However, I found that Samsung Kies, which is Samsung's software for backup, synching, and downloading firmware updates, wouldn't often recognize the tablet and I've never been able to update the firmware via Kies even though an update was available. All updates so far have been done wirelessly through my home network. Online support for this tablet via email to Samsung is useless. I have not been able to successfully navigate or complete all of the required information using their support process to complete an email. That's been very frustrating! Samsung has been quite slow in upgrading from Ice Cream Sandwich to Jelly Bean and provides no schedule information whatsoever. Rumors have it happening soon but that's all they are; rumors. This tablet is okay for my basic needs but I wouldn't recommend it now given all of the other 7" tablets presently available. I'd definitely look for one that's well supported by the manufacturer.

tablet_galaxy_tab|Great cheap device with some glaring problems.I have a Galaxy Nexus, iPad 2 & 3, iPhone for comparison. I've had the Tab 2 since the 25th (1 day after launch).Pros: Price, portability and form factor. Excellent video/music player.I got a OTG cable and plugged in 3 USB sticks and that was fun but impractical.Cons:Only works if you are tied to Google's eco-system.For example, mail & calendaring. Calendar does not support open-source caldav. No support for .ics calendars.Mail does not support PUSH IMAP email unless you use Gmail. Even then, it has problem with certain Cyrus/Postfix mail servers using TLS authentication.Sure there are apps on the PLay store but I found all of them to be flakey at best. VPN , like most Android devices, is flakey and unreliable.Bottom line. Don't even think about using this device for work. This is a toy so I wasn't so hung up on the lack of business features.However, there are some other bigger issues. I bought this tablet on the premise of expandibility. My 64GB iPad cost $829. I have about 6 32GB microSDHC class 10 cards.So I figure I can have an inexpensive video player that I can swap cards with and use as a GPS/entertainment system in the car.First of all. It has very poor file accessibility support. ICS drop USB Mass Storage so you have to use MTP which has problems.On Macs, you have a 4GB limitation with the Google MTP application. Not only that, it only works 2 out of 10 times. The Galaxy Nexus doesn't have this problem.There is virtually no or very flakey MTP support in Linux - CentOS/RedHat. Considering Androoid is based off linux, there should be better cohesion.I guess you can install the SDK kit and do adb pull and push in the command line to get your files onto this tablet but I dont think most readers here are commandline Linux gurus.Heck, even the iPad has drag-n-drop apps/files support in Linux. The micro-sd slot isn't going to help as I explain further..So getting large files to the device is going to be a problem.The Tab 2 is billed as 8GB but 1/2 of it is partition for the OS and the user is only left with 4 GB of free space.The microsd card isn't very useful for these reasons:You can only format FAT32. exFAT, NTFS, HFS does not work. I even tried formatting my cards EXT2, EXT3, EXT4 (Linux filesystem).Why is this an issue? Well, most HD movies are 5-6 gigabytes and FAT32 has a 4GB limit. So forget about copying your blu-ray rips.OK. strike. I guess playing my movie collection isn't going to work.Next, with only 4GB of user-accessible storage on the internal, apps will fill it up quick.I installed Navigon ( I wanted to use my tab as a GPS for the car), Google earth and a few apps and my Tab 2 was FULL.After a day's worth of emails, I had 48 megabytes free.ICS does not support apps2SD where you can move apps to the external SD card.And for apps that store their cache and support programs, the microSD slot is viewed as /extSD and not /mnt/sdcardI have hundreds of apps on my Galaxy Nexus as the OS sees 29GB and the apps can install and see the virtual internal sdcard. With the Galaxy Tab 2, there is no luck due to how ICS handles internal storage and external micro-sd.You can root your device but it is a known issue that apps2sd does not work for ICS. You cant "move" your apps to the external mounted microsd.Other issues: poor wifi. I have 4 phones and 2 tablets of various makes and the Galaxy Tab 2 has the poorest range. It also drops Wifi N connections.It doesnt support EAS-TL certificate wifi.Bluetooth issues galore. I have an Incredible, ATT Captivate, Galaxy Nexus and all of them can pair to a ELM32 ODBC module to use with Torque.The Galaxy Tab loses pair bluetooth keys. Older HDMI cables for the Galaxy Plus and 10" Tab does not work. I cannot get it to play video thru HDMI.Sure, the iPad has a close ecosystem but it simply works better. I can copy 6GB HD movies to my iPad. I can connect to various Linux servers's email and calendaring system.Heck, I can even mount and copy files from a Linux machine to my iPad. E.G. copy movies over.I am hoping a 7" model comes out soon because I like the form factor.So I guess I will be returning this tablet and expect something to address the issues with ICS and storage.a

tablet_galaxy_tab|I use visual patterns on my keyboard to randomize most of my passwords for security reasons but easy to remember because of the pattern. For example up, up, &#60;shift&#62;up, right, right, down on the keyboard starting where ever you like. I also use the &#60;shift&#62; number keys such as %#& in my passwords.The key above F is R and above that, the 4 key on a standard keyboard but on the Galaxy touch keyboard the 3 key is above R. The number row is shifted too far right.Additionally, the apostrophe is not on the default view and requires a shift key to a symbol layout. I use a lot of contracted words like: I'm, shouldn't, don't, etc. so this is all very annoying.I also found lots of websites on my (Google Chrome) browser did not display well, or had a custom android app that didn't work well (Facebook). While entering text into website comment windows, navigating my text for editing is horrible; no arrow keys or End key on the touch keyboard.I'm playing with the remote control app for my TV, etc. but it's buggy. The facial recognition log in doesn't recognize me most of the time, luckily it has a 4 digit pin for backup. It comes with Polaris Office app that has text, spreadsheet, and slides. I have yet to test worksheets but it does recognize Microsoft .xls files 2000/XP/2003 compatible.PLUSES: I find it great for sharing photos with the 32gb micro card accessory installed. It's a large screen with great resolution and plenty of brightness, although keep it down to get the 4+ hours of battery time. Using the two finger squeeze motion makes zooming in and out very easy. The one finger flicking to move around pages includes acceleration with faster flicks and stops on a dime with a touch. Streaming video content such as Netflix is actually quite comfortable solo and the speakers sound surprisingly good. Download speed is just as fast as my desktop so streaming a movie is great.It doesn't have a phone built it but there's no monthly cost. WiFi access is easy to find and setup. It also has built it GPS that shows my location when on the road. I haven't been able to get voice directions yet. Maybe it needs WiFi? My Desktop Windows 7 system is still the best with the 24&#34; LCD for real document editing or gaming but I prefer the Galaxy Tab 2 7&#34; screen over my laptop.The processor speed reminds me of dial-up but it's tolerable. As my very first tablet ever, and as a very first time Android OS user (not a smartphone user), I am quite pleased with the device overall. Getting into the operating system will take me awhile but fun to explore.

---
tablet_galaxy_tab|Like the Nexus 7, this seems to have me a bit undecided on whether this or the Nexus 7 makes the best 7 inch tablet for Android. This falls behind the Nexus in specs, but makes up for it in other features like TouchWiz, the IR remote, and expandable memory. The one major drawback for me is that this particular model is limted to the 8gb memory capacity (with the exception of the student addition which I can't find anywhere anymore, but even that's limited at 16 gb). Something like this, I feel, should be at a minimum of 16 gb with an option for 32 gb. If it was a 32gb one, I'd choose this one in a heartbeat over the Nexus 7, but because it's lacking that memory, it's a toss up between this and the Nexus 7.To give a little bit more background information:I started off with a Galaxy Note 10.1 tablet and loved it so much that I wanted another Samsung tablet that was smaller in size for portability. I figured that besides specs, the only way the Tab 2 would fall behind its big brother the Note 10.1 would be that it lacks the S-Pen. So I bought it (sadly, I paid like $200 or $250 and a month or so later, I saw the price for this model drop to about $149). When I got the device, I saw that it performed much slower than the Note 10.1, which was expected. However, it was still a sweet device with the ability to use front and rear cameras, edit documents, enjoy the Android app store (Google Play), and so forth.But with my usage (pictures, movies, video games, apps), it filled up too fast. Of the 8gb, I think you only get to use 5 or 4 and a half, so you're pretty much restricted to space. If you're using it just for things like email, streaming video (YouTube, Netflix, Hulu, etc.), and for surfing the web with the occasional app or game download, then this should be perfect. But if you're going to use it for all those functions in addition to things like downloading games (esp. the high memory games), apps, and so forth, then you might want to look elsewhere for a device with more memory.While you can use the micro SD card with this device, it does not allow you to transfer apps to it as older Android phones and tablets would let you. But you can still transfer documents, PDF files, songs and stored videos to the card to lighten the load on the device. That helps out tremendously, especially if you have enough songs to take up a gig of storage, videos to take up the same amount of space, and a bunch of documents like textbooks for school. But you still have to limit your app selection to just a couple of games (if they're big ones), and apps.Ultimately, I found it a very useful device, but the storage limitations had me look elsewhere for a 7 inch device (I settled on the Nexus 7, 32 gb and with better specs but lacking Samsung's lovely TouchWiz that makes using the device such a pleasant experience). As for the Tab 2, I didn't return it. I felt it was still a great device. So now I downloaded an app designed for parents to customize the user experience on it that way my son can play his games and watch his videos and read his books on it when we're traveling or at the doctor's office, etc. It still sees a lot of use, just not by me.I would definitely recommend this tablet, but would also advise people to be cautious of memory usage. Many people don't need that much memory and can be fine with a couple of games or a few heavy apps and use it without any problems. It definitely beats most of the competition with the exception of its main rival, the Nexus 7. It wins out over the Kindle Fire HD easily (which I also own), and the Nook Tablet (which I sold due to the lack of apps available for it). Keep in mind, this review is coming from someone who likes to download apps for all sorts of things (games, checkbook, word processors, photo editing, etc.) so this is why it gets a more negative review than others might give it. For the price, however, I'd easily say this is one of the best choices out there and still recommend it for those looking for a great tablet at an affordable price (almost unbeatable price depending on where/when you buy it).

tablet_galaxy_tab|I am a first-time tab user and I must say I've really enjoyed this product.As for positives, I found that the screen is very clear and responsive. Also, the apps load quite quickly and IR remote is a neat accessory; I actually prefer its channel guide over the one provided through my cable carrier. I've had no issues streaming movies through Netflix or watching videos on YouTube, although it would be nice if the Netflix movies were a bit clearer. Finally, it's extremely easy to drag photos or music from iTunes and drop them into Kies (the Galaxy software). Once you do this it will sync right up with the tab.As for negatives, the power button and volume control are in a terrible location. It's way too easy to accidentally hit these buttons while holding the device sideways. Maybe a future model will put these controls on the front? Also, I could sketch a better picture than this tab could take.

tablet_galaxy_tab|*** The Positives:When I powered this thing on... What a beautiful display!! It is lovely. No wonder S^MSUNG is taking over the TV display market.The Android operating system is the best. I guess I am personally biased toward Android because the HTC Incredible got me hooked on the simplicity and openness of the OS. From the main screen there are five panes you can access with a slider, if you are familiar with how the Androids operate.*** The Negatives:Right out of the box, I had a sinking feeling when I saw the other end of the USB charger/data cable had a S^AMSUNG connector on it instead of a micro-USB. I can see it now. I go off on a trip and I have not packed that specific cable for the Tab. I can't get that cable at Target or Radio Shack!! I have to get it from... S^AMSUNG. It will not get to me from S^MSUNG before I have to go back home or go off to the next destination of my trip. If I had wanted stupid charger/connector hassles like that, then I would have gotten an Apple iPad with it's confusing array of which-generation-connector-goes-with-which-generation-iPad conundrum. OR I would have gotten a BlackBerry Playbook (*giggle*) where the Playbook insists on having the charger's data pins shorted to permit the power pins to charge the Playbook's battery! I kept that sinking feeling about the Tab pushed down in my heart, because I was trying SO HARD to rationalize being able to keep this neat device with it's beautiful display.Next con: When the Display Brightness is set on &#34;Auto&#34; the display is constantly set to be too dim for whatever the lighting conditions are. Manually adjusting it is easy enough, but why can't I set it to *automatically* adjust to how bright I want it to be? Also, when the Display Brightness is set to &#34;Auto&#34;, whatever the Tab does to set the backlighting down to it's too dim setting, well that just makes the backlighting flicker. It's annoying!The con that broke the camel's back: The micro-SD card would not stay in the micro-SD card slot! Was it the plastic-snappy-hinge-door that was supposed to keep the micro-SD card in place? It didn't. If I put some finger pressure on the closed plastic-snappy-hinge-door while my 32GB niblet was in there, a display at the top of the (beautiful) screen would say &#34;Preparing SD card&#34;. But the instant I took my finger away from the plastic-snappy-hinge-door, the status at the top of the (still) beautiful screen would tell me that the &#34;SD card was unexpectedly removed!&#34; When I called the 1-800-SAMSUNG support line to resolve this problem the troubleshooter did determine that I had not installed the card correctly. I had not pushed the micro-SD card in far enough. HOWEVER, to push the micro-SD card in far enough, I would &#34;have to use a gemclip or a safety pin to carefully push&#34; the outer edge of the micro-SD card into the Tab deep past the plastic of the slot until it went &#34;click&#34;. I successfully tried this and the micro-SD card worked in the micro-SD slot. An optimist might say, &#34;Well! Now that you have that there micro-jobber clicked into yer hoo-hah-hole just right, ya might never have to mess with it ever again! :-D &#34; To which I say ripping movies for long trips, transfering other bits of data, video and pictures to and from the Tab is going to be a constant battle with micro-SD micro-card micro-slot micro-surgery with the S^MSUNG-recommended &#34;gemclip or a safety pin&#34;. (For younger readers: The &#34;gemclip&#34; is an archaic metalic wire device old-timers used to use to hold paper documents together before the &#34;floppy disc&#34; came along. The advent of the &#34;floppy disc&#34; in the late 1970's and early 1980's effectively banned the easily magnetized &#34;gemclip&#34; from the office because those &#34;gemclips'&#34; magnetic force would erase devastating amounts of kilobytes from the said floppy discs.) (Also for the younger readers: The &#34;safety pin&#34; is another metallic wire device used in the 1950's and 1960's to cinch the waist of a cloth diaper onto a baby's butt.) I guess I was just hoping to be able to change micro-SD cards with my standard-issue hands, the way I do with my phone, camera, handheld scanner and every other device I use that requires memory! Every time I go on a trip, I will not think to pack a gemclip, nor shall I pack a safety pin! I don't even have these things from 3 to 6 decades ago IN MY HOUSE! AND I'M A BIT OF A PACKRAT!!!! So... I micro-extracted my micro-card, went to my Amazon account and clicked &#34;return&#34;.Bottom line: Beautiful display, but there are a lot of gaffes in the Galaxy Tab's design which were going to be so annoying in the years of ownership to come. If you are seriously considering this Tab, make sure my three cons, which were evident on the first day out of the box, are not a concern for you.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I generally like this tab. Has the latest Android OS, responds fast, offers multiple options. It seems, though, that most satisfied users compare this tab to a Kindle. I don't own a Kindle. But I do own an Acer Iconia which, performance-wise, supersedes the Galaxy Tab 7.0 even a year after it was released.The reason I took the first star off is that ostensibly this Tab comes with 8GB - it's advertised as such, and says so on the box. However, what it does not say is that it most of its internal memory is taken up by the system and by numerous preloaded application that you can't get rid of. What you have out of the box is barely 4 GB of memory available for your use. If you think that's enough, think again.ALL of the apps that you plan to download to your new pretty Galaxy are programed to go to your internal memory, and there is no option in the settings that allow you to move the app to your SD card. Samsung opted to label the internal memory as "SDcard" and the external memory as "extSDcard." So not only do your apps go straight to your internal precious memory (of which you only have 4gb to begin with), all the data that's generated by that app also goes to the internal memory. The only thing that's possible to use out of external SD is media - videos and pictures. Games, offline maps, word processing apps - all go to internal memory. I contacted Samsung on this before I bought the devise as I saw couple of users mentioning it here on Amazon. After 30 min of conversation with sales person and a TECH (!) department I was assured that I can move the apps to the external memory card. That's the reason for taking off a second star - incompetent customer service. I should have read reviews on Samsung website - all this was discussed by users there.Don't know if I'll keep it, aside from the above reasons the Tab is fine, especially at this price point.
---

tablet_galaxy_tab|I ordered the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 in July 2012, and actually had to exchange it for the same item just over a month later. The issue: it will shut down without warning, even with a charged battery. This is actually an issue I've had with the replacement tab that I've had since the end of August as well. There is no warning when this happens, it just does. It isn't "frequent" but I would say it occurs a couple times a month. Generally, I have to plug the charger back in (which is strange b/c there is ALWAYS a charge when it shuts down) and then after a few minutes, I can power the tablet back on and it's fine. It's an inconvenience, but it's not worth the effort of me exchanging it for a 2nd time and I believe I'm past the point of returning it at this time. I will cope.I read A LOT of review of this tablet before I settled on it. The Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 definitely had some mixed reviews, but I opted to go for it as I thought, no product is 100% perfect (that's definitely been confirmed for me). It does the job it's supposed to for the most part, I prefer the 7inch size as it's more manageable to hold on to.Would I recommend it to a friend? I did before I had issues of my own, but for the future, I may not recommend it to someone who would be impatient with it's flaws

tablet_galaxy_tab|A nice tablet especially for the price. I wanted the microSD option that higher end tables didn't offer.PROS:You can get a USB host adapter so you can plug USB devices into it.You can use a bluetooth wireless keyboard and it responds quicklyGood battery life. 9 hours of constant display use and days of battery life when I allow the screen to turn off while idle.Very slim and lightweight.CONS:Placement of the power button next to the volume buttons isn't idle. I keep hitting the power button by mistake and locking/powering off the screen. Annoying. It would have be better to have the power button on the top instead.Android lacks a decent alternative to Microsoft Office. Opening Office documents from others tend to always have some formatting problem compared to actual Office programs.No standard micro USB port for charging/data sync. It'd be nice to not need an adapter to attach USB devices either.Comes with lots of store apps. More free media content would have been nice.No 5.0ghz wireless support, but I prefer the lower price over that feature.Would have liked a 8.9 or larger screen size for the same price.No LED notification light to alert you about e-mails or other notifications while main screen is asleep.

tablet_galaxy_tab|Although not the Nexus 7, but this tablet is a must have for android freaks like me. It's very neat and does the job of storing all media and powerful enough to play games like Sonic and Shadowgun .. etc. I wanted nexus 7 since it's pure google, but this tab has extra space for extra memory (i bought 32gb immediately!). It's a bit laggy though but i got another launcher which makes it quite fast. Will wait for 4.1I don't regret buying this at all, but I'd still say, if you are choosing between this and the nexus 7, go with the nexus 7 if you don't mind limited storage space (i.e. 8 or 16gb).

tablet_galaxy_tab|First, the downsides of the tablet:-It only has 8 GB of RAM, and half of that is taken by the bloatware Samsung has installed on the tablet, and cannot be removed.-The cameras are horrible. The front-facing camera is VGA resolution and guaranteed to make you look bad in video chat, and the rear facing camera is 3 megapixels and fixed focus, so things like bar code scanners won't work with it. There is no flash or assistive light. Basically, if you ever think you want to use the camera for anything, buy something else.-There is no indicator LED on the tablet, for notifications or charging status or anything else.-Finding cases for it is tough.-Some applications don't work too well, as they assume a bigger screen.-Doesn't support larger MicroSD cards, only HC.-The connector is proprietary, so you can't use standard USB variants to charge it.-No HD out, even through the docking connector.-No 5 GHz WiFi.-Bluetooth compatibility issues with SPP class 0 devices.Here are the upsides:+In build quality, comparing it to the only other 7" tablet on the market (the Acer Iconia) for the same price you get a thinner and lighter tablet that feels vastly better. The Samsung is really well built, the materials are nice to the touch, and it's comfortable to hold.+It's fairly responsive (unless you load it up with apps).+The screen is nice, and the touch interface works well.+I've been satisfied with the battery life.+It's very good value for the money.

The only fix is to reset it to factory conditions. Of course there is no way to retrieve the data and every app must be manually re-installed.Aside from this glaring flaw, the tablet is perfectly fine. tablet_galaxy_tab|Just bought his Samsung Tab(2) with ICE. This apparently comes only with 8 GB and now has Ice Cream Sandwich. Ice Cream Sandwich has disabled the option to move Applications to the SD card. You are limited to the 8GB space for Apps, and can only use the SD card for storage of pictures, Mp3's and files. This is a change from Froyo Android on Samsung devices where you could easily move them. 8GB will be a problem as you find more apps to install. My 16GB phone would have run out of space long ago.Other than that it seems to be a fine device. My first experience with a 7". I am rethinking a 10" and even an iPad now. At least with Apple you get the GB's you buy without the promise of "expandable" memory that is really limit to file storage.Samsung should be ashamed since this is really a deception.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I have ipod touch and Acer tablet 10 inch. I was looking for something portable yet big enough to read ebooks and do basic web/email and watch videos. Considering the price and options to add android apps, I decided to get this tablet over Kindle. It's an okay tablet but not great. The screen gets dirty faster than the two mobile devices I have. It's not as vivid as apple products for sure. Micro SD card expansion is somewhat misleading as the android OS that comes with does not let the tablet to store apps to external SD card. There's just little over 4 GB space available on internal memory and that's just not enough. I have some basic apps downloaded and no game apps at all. And I already filled up more than half of what's available. So if you're planning to download many apps and videos and magazines, 8GB internal storage is not enough at all. The expandable micro SC option looks great as if it'll add more storage but it does not work that way at all. Apps will not be stored in the external SD card at all. The default apps come with the tablet cannot be deleted and just take up space in the limited memory space.Also it says it's compatible with Adobe Flash Player. Adobe apparently has discontinued Flash Player support for newer android OS and this tablet does not come with Adobe Flash Player plug in and does not work. So that's also misleading.I hope android will provide its OS updates in near future with an option to store apps to external sd card. So will adobe with its Flash Player.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I bought this product after comparing the different e-readers I was considering purchasing. I looked at the Nook, Kindle, Kindle fire, etc. I read reviews on Amazon as well as went to my local electronics stores to compare in person. I got this product along with others items I ordered at the same time a day earlier than stated when I purchased which is always great. I can't really compare this to other tablets as this is the first one I have owned, but I love it. It's very fast for the processes I use it for (mostly internet searches, Facebook, Twitter, other apps, and reading books on). I love the fact that you can add additional memory which was the main selling point for me on this product over the Kindle fire. I know about Cloud and all of that, but I don't like that you have to be connected to the internet to read your books on Cloud and if I download all of my books and music the storage space on the device would be full in no time. I will be using my tablet a lot while traveling and won't always have internet access at hand. The only downfalls on this product that I have noticed thus far are:1: That it doesn't have a "Swype" keyboard. I have an android phone that has this feature and I love it. There are ones that are downloadable from the android market, but they can store anything you type and I don't particularly like that idea. And2: Hulu does not work on this device (the app or the website) except to add things to watch later from your television, computer, or other device that works with Hulu. Netflix however does work fantastically on this tablet, so that's a big bonus.If you are looking for something that is fast, easy to use, allows extra storage space, and is user friendly I think this would be a good product for you. So far I'm very satisfied. If that changes I will update my review, but I don't see that happening.

I am not saying this device doesn't have it's flaws. I am saying that to out right lie is wrong. Had i believed the lies I wouldn't be typing this review from the darn thing right now. It does need some tweaking but it is a very satisfying and refreshing product to use2. I have an iPad and apps are great to use, it's very reliable and lasts a dang long time on one charge. But so is this thing. And it's about less than half the weight. As practicle as the iPad my be, it is big and lacksmm?KStop discouraging folks lying for personal reasons. I'm no Android advocate but I'm no apple loyalist just0er give me something that works and I'll use it.Now just a little about the pros and cons. Out of the box it is more samsung than ics. The home screen widgets are etched in stone and the other screens don't have much to offer newbies. I downloaded go launcher ex and some themes until i came across one i liked. All free by the way. Settled in with Cyanogen Iand i am happy with that decision. Certain apps still will notinstall, ie go locker ex nor the associated locker screens but that's astetics. Apps when added install quickly without any fanfare i also have a Chinese tablet called a Cube 17Gt 7 inch and the screen is an ips screen. This tablet is just as bright amd sharp. I watched kungfu panda on both with no perceiveable difference. Apps run well and i am still testing. Be back tomorrow with more on functionality. Meanwhile, haters stop hatin'. A year ago the thing cost almost double the price with less options as far as apps concerned with a few more bells and whistles.

tablet_galaxy_tab|At first I like this little tablet. I do like the size and the processor seems to be quick enough. The original Android build and Samsung software was nice. Half the available storage is taken up and hidden by the Samsung software, but i put in an SD card and since I only bought this to do Android development with the storage was fine. The size is really nice and has made me think that I'd really like the Note II. It's smaller than my iPad and is easy the take off to meetings (unfortunately the poor WiFi renders it useless). The screen looks nice - though not nearly as good as my iPad.However, the WiFi radio on this device is so weak as to be unacceptable. I wrote a Java RTSP library to stream video from IP cameras. When I took this tablet into the office I found that the range limitation was so short I simply could not demonstrate the application unless standing virtually right next to the WiFi router. All other devices had no issues with coverage - iPhones, laptops, iPads, etc.The camera is also of such poor quality that some barcode scanning prototyping I was working on never has worked. In fact while Scanlife can generally scan EZScan codes, other scan software simply won't focus sufficiently to read the "UPC" codes on products. Even "normal" pictures never seem to be in sharp focus.Finally, the touchscreen does not seem to be responsive. I'v found that I have to be very careful with my aim when pressing the menu buttons at the bottom of the screen and it often takes 3 or 4 tries to actually click the button.Overall I'm disappointed with this device. From what I have read this WiFi only version is very cheapened down - people that have the version with 3g say their WiFi works just fine.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I had high hopes for this device but, after using it for almost a month now, I am returning it because, to say the least, it simply fails to perform.I don't know whether it's ICS or, maybe I've got some faulty hardware (though, I doubt the latter)? However, the device, for me, has been CONSTANTLY plagued with performance/memory issues! I hardly ever even keep the WIFI running or the browser open, and kill any/all apps as soon as I'm done with them. Nonetheless, this thing is slow as hell! Typically, I use it for very light tasks, such as, using the stock, Samsung music app, and/or reading via the Kindle app. These two get the most use, by far. Regardless, should I try and run another app, (for a total of 2 apps!!!) simultaneously, the device lags tremendously. It becomes painstakingly slow for me to even swipe to the next screen, much less anything with the least amount of complexity. The device has also made random crashes/restarts.FWIW, I did install the update (for whatever, ICS or Samsung OS) immediately upon release, which did nothing regarding my experience. I even followed some advice I found on forums pertaining to adjustments in the Settings under Developer Options, which also made no difference.It has been a highly frustrating experience because I want so much for this thing to work. The size, for me, would be perfect, able to fit right into my back pocket.Other notes:-I also find the keyboard pretty awful, and the cursor to have a mind of its own when trying to edit text, etc. I did install Thumb Keyboard, which was a major improvement, though I still had the cursor issues to deal with.-Battery life could certainly be better, as it struggles to go a day with only the display on, running a simple app like Kindle, and no WIFI.-The speakers suck compared to those in my Samsung Galaxy SII (Skyrocket).Beware:-The 7" form factor! I wasn't aware beforehand that I couldn't run all the apps I do on my phone on this device; another downer.-I also didn't realize I'd need to buy all new cables/adapters for this device after having bought them all for my phone: HDMI, USB female, etc. The cable used here is not a mini-USB as I had anticipated. I only mention as a Caveat Emptor, as this was the least of my concerns; I'd have been happy to buy all new cables had this device lived up to the performance my phone offers at half the size.Should I tempt/convince myself to try another one to see if, in fact, my hardware was possibly faulty, I will obviously change my review. I have been reading over all the reviews here on Amazon, however, and most of the positive reviews, I find to be short and sweet, and without having spent much time actually using the product, i.e., posted after a single day of use! It seems they may not have given the device a proper test period or, are still just so happy to have joined the Tab Club for an affordable price, that perhaps they are overlooking its shortcomings? Hell, I was too, quite ready and willing to compromise for a time....
---
