tablet_galaxy_tab|After using the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 for about two weeks, I have decided to return it. I was at first really impressed by its build quality (very solid construction), speed of web browsing, and very agile response when using web applications. Oh, and it is also Made in South Korea (at least mine says), thus an original, pretty much like buying a Sony that is made in Japan, a BMW made in Germany, a Victorinox multi-tool made in Switzerland, or Oakley sunglasses made here in the U.S. of A. On top of that I was hopeful that its TI OMAP 4430 Dual Core 1Ghz processor, which is arguably stronger than the NVdia Tegra 2 (in some benchmark sub-tests the 4430 comes close to even the Tegra 3), would guarantee stability and efficient multi-tasking. I guess I raised my expectations too much. What made me decide to return is, for one, its (very) poor battery life which lasts me only about an hour of web browsing, watching video, listening to music, and playing games. Seriously, just under one hour! Also, what I am equally disappointed in is the all-too-frequent freeze-ups, hangups, and crashes of apps, offline and online. Even my eight-year old Centrino and XP-run laptop doesnt crash as much. My brother also owned a Galaxy Tab 2 for a month, returned his after experiencing the SAME issues I had (i.e. bad battery and crashes among others), but I still thought he got a bum unit then and still bought myself one, which I now realize was a mistake. Perhaps it's the device, perhaps the Android Ice Cream Sandwich, perhaps it's the general architecture, I would not not know.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|I bought this tablet two months ago from Costco and recently returned it. I was not satisfied with the tablet and I wouldn't recommend it to you, either.At first the tablet was amazing! The screen is very clear and fun to watch videos on in dark places. I was able to search the internet much faster than my iPhone and Skyping with friends was much easier on the tablet than my laptop. I thought it was a great buy because I do a lot of traveling and could use an electronic device that is lightweight and can handle light usage, such as surfing the net, checking email, Skype, etc.However, my biggest gripe (and the one that made me return the tablet) is how often it freezes and slows down. Even with only one application open, the tablet will eventually slow down until there is a 2 or 3 second delay between each letter I type and when it appears on the screen. If I was IMing a friend on GChat, the tablet would lag like this only ~10 minutes after the conversation began. The Internet froze ALL THE TIME.Also, the glossy screen is a pain if you are trying to watch anything when there is ANY glare. The screen is so glossy that it works like a mirror, more so than the iPhone or iPad screen I believe. It is a pain trying to watch movies if there is any type of light. The touchscreen is not very sensitive as well, which made surfing the internet frustrating. If buttons are close together on the screen, forget about trying to click one properly. The tablet can't differentiate between buttons closer than about 1/2 a centimeter apart, so you'll have to zoom in. Even my iPhone 3 has a more sensitive touch screen, which I thought was a little ridiculous as the Samsung is much newer technology.This may be a personal preference, but I don't believe the home screen is intuitive at all. There are 4 apps on the bottom that you can switch in and out, but I used way more than 4 apps on the tablet for the pure fact that it is a tablet - you can use it for a much wider range of applications than you can a phone (which also has 4 apps on the home screen). If you want to see all the apps you have to click/swipe through a couple more times to see the entire app inventory, and when you want to quit an app it isn't as easy as swiping the app out of the "what apps are running right now" pop up log. Even if you swipe it out, and you can't access it anymore, it still runs in the background for some reason. The fact that it was so difficult to properly quit an application bothered me a lot. I thought the tablet's software was very poorly designed because it took too many click-throughs to get to windows that you needed.Another issue is many video-streaming sites are not supported by Android or make you pay for the mobile version, such as Hulu.I use both PCs and Macs. Don't get me wrong, Apple's iPad has its own issues (I actually returned an iPad 2 as well), but the one thing I hate about PCs is how difficult it makes everything. Something has to freeze, not run properly, shut down on you, or get a virus. The Samsung Galaxy is in the same vein.
---

tablet_galaxy_tab|Unfortunately anyone considering this device should Google-search the term "Issue 36993: wifi no longer working in ics 4.0.4 " or simply "galaxy wifi authentication failed". Essentially at this time you may find yourself without any option to connect to the internet. In other words, a pretty useless paper weight.The various forums have several threads on the topic where users, including IT professionals, who own android devices are reporting the problem and not finding a solution or work around. Typical posts from the above read:* "just signed a 2 year contract. Had I known about this issue I never would have committed my two years to this device. Now Im stuck."* "I am too extremely frustrated that for $700 i have a piece of plastic doing a half job... simply unaccceptable. Google needs to push some kind of update ASAP and start treating the android project seriously..."* "Huge problem!!!! Bought 2 galaxy 3's and a galaxy tab 10.1 2 all with no ability to connect WiFi!! This is unacceptable!!!"A bug in Android, introduced in v4.0.4 and persisiting through the latest Android v4.1.2, prevents android devices from connecting to many, mainstream, wifi routers. If your home/office router is one of those, tough luck. Users have these routers working fine with all non-android devices (ie iOS, Windows...). Also, many Galaxy devices (including mine) worked fine up to the v4.0.4 upgrade.Personally I had been an advocate of the Samsung Google product family. However the lack of networking functionality, and lack of communication by these companies in the several months of this issue persisting should be unacceptable and potential consumers here should be aware and beware.
---
tablet_galaxy_tab|I purchased this 7inch tablet for use as a student in medical clinical settings and of course during leisure time as well. I purchased this based on my satisfaction of other Samsung products and my liking of their original 10.1 tablet. I won't make this too lengthy and will get right to the point, starting with a list of pro's and con's.Pros-Expandable memory (up to 32gb)-Icecream sandwich OS (Soon to be outdated, see below)-IR Port-Front and rear camera-Good WiFi receptionCons-My biggest issue with this tablet was the screen and I noticed this on all units I have been able to take a look at. The color calibration on this is EXTREMELY below Samsung standards. This was the worst screen I have ever witnessed on a Samsung product. When compared to the Kindle Fire and other tablets in this tier,the biggest thing I noted was the galaxy tab's whites are more of a cream and have a dirty look. It's possible this may be corrected in an update in the future but as for now, how did this ever make it to the consumer market?!?!-Icecream Sandwich will soon be outdated by Jellybean. I have had 4 other Samsung Android devices and they are notoriously slow getting Android updates out. Feel free to look this up if you don't believe me, it's a fact.-Also because it is Samsung, you do not get the full Android experience but instead you will get it mixed with their Touchwiz software. I have found this to have a very negative impact on the performance of this tablet and more often than not, just gets in the way.-The iconic Icecream Sandwich face unlock feature that was so advertised with the OS release? You won't find that it on this tablet because Samsung doesn't support it.-The IR port does not have a paired Samsung application to run it. Instead you will be directed to install the Peel Reel app to make use of it. It is one of extremely few apps that can make it work. Peel Reel is somewhat buggy and requires an internet connection to use (you can see it's reviews in the Google Play Store, will improve over time I am sure). I found that it works well on Sony and Dynex televisions, but for some reason it just couldn't master an LG flat screen. Something for Peel Reel to work on, but why no Samsung App to support this?!?!-I put the cameras in PRO because they are included unlike some other tablets, but their quality limits their usefulness. You will be able to video chat, but be prepared to look pixelated.-I mentioned performance before, but I wanted to throw in about requiring restarts too. I thought we had moved away from the tech limitation of having to restart a device to clear tasks, RAM, etc. but apparently not. When you turn on the tab you may be able to play a graphic intense game or an equivalent on this tab, but later in your session, you will see some lag times on it without a restart. Samsung includes it's own task manager but it does not clear up the lag with extended use.-The touch sensitivity needs to be stronger and their is no option to increase this, expect a few double taps along the way.At the time of this tablets release this is the most superior 7inch tablet and easily kills the Kindle Fire in performance. However based on the issues stated above, I recently sold my Galaxy Tab 2 7in. and pre-ordered the upcoming Galaxy Nexus 7. I will not go into it's specs on this review, but I would encourage everyone looking to get into the 7inch tablet field to give a look at the Nexus 7 or wait on the next generation of the Kindle Fire. The Galaxy Tab 2 7in. just isn't worth it.

tablet_galaxy_tab|This is my 1st tablet and I have not played with others. Verified with samsung that when you go to delete emails by selecting "delete all" it will still delete them one by one. You will have to do this twice. Once from inbox and once from trash so plan on a couple of minutes for around 100 emails. Instantaneous on my thunderbolt in a second or 2. If you're more worried about all the other apps and features then I suppose you'll be ok. I would play with it in the store 1st. I'll be returning and trying something else. Another thing, even though I deleted my sent emails it still shows that i have sent emails on it's icon. Tap the icon and there are no sent emails. I've deleted cache, data, and account and started over to no avail. I have not tried a factory reset but samsung confirmed it's performance of the email app. Maybe others are not experiencing this problem with the email app or it's not an issue to them. The missed or non responding taps and email issues are enough for me. I think a tablet needs to do the main things well and to me that is email and web. Not achieved. Missed on thing to report. Even though you delete your emails from inbox and trash it will bring them back. Say you have some emails in there and you scroll down to the oldest one. You will notice the little syncing animation starting and your deleted emails coming back.Edit 5-16-12: Adding a star back after a reviewer suggested I use "Hackers Keyboard" app to replace stock. I now have a usable keyboard that I'm much more comfortable with. I still have to do multiple taps or taps with force to get some links to respond and the stock email app is my only real issues with this tablet now. May try a reset to see if I can get better screen response.

tablet_galaxy_tab|The galaxy tab 2 7 inch looked promising coming out of the package. The design was solid, but for some reason it does not feel stable in my hand and I am constantly worried about dropping it. This is probably because this is my first tablet. I'm sure some sort of protective case will make me feel more at ease. The screen is very responsive and the internet pages open quickly. Other than that, there is little else I can offer because SAMSUNG HAS NO MANUAL AVAILABLE ONLINE!!! Customer service is very important these days, and I find no manual EXTREMELY aggravating! Fortunately,I am fairly computer savvy and can navigate most devices without a manual. Most of the time,a manual is an afterthought. I'm sure that someone will fix this problem and my experience will get better, but for now, it bothers me that someone got paid a lot of money to screw this up. After all the positive things I have read about Samsung, I expected better.Updated review: OK, for all of you that complained that I did not write a review (actually it was a review of Samsung support more than anything else). First, there is still no online manual accessible from the device itself unless you use the "full site option" hidden in the fine print at the bottom of the Samsung mobile homepage. People who are "computer savvy" will be able to figure that out, but honestly, this device isn't for your hardcore user and my wife or 15yo son might have a problem figuring that out. That's who this device is tailored for, the new user who only wants to spend $249, not people like Kenneth J. Conner, Carl E. Simms, or myself, who have the ability to assemble our own computer's from scratch. I DID contact Samsung customer support who told me that there was no manual available at the time; now there is, but again, only through the full site.The device works as expected. The screen is vibrant and great for watching movies. The screen is generally responsive, which is expected as well. I have noticed that when you need to tap something small, such as an "x" to close an internet screen, it requires multiple taps and becomes frustrating. Some people have complained about google's integration into the android system; I find far less clutter and better functionality than the extra's that are integrated into my Verizon phone by Motorola. The charging/USB cord is a little annoying as well. I find the shape of the male plug for the device unnecessary and unfriendly. If I lose it, break it, step on it, etc, I am forced to buy another from samsung instead of being able to use one of the 6 or 7 mini/micro USBs that I already own. The camara is ok if you have light (no flash), but I don't think many people take pictures with a tablet, so it's a non-issue. The power button is fairly sensitive and I have a habit of pressing it by mistake. Again, trivial, just move your hand.To wrap up, it does what it's expected to...no more, no less. It doesn't "wow" me. My phone's a better device, but it costs more and has more competition. Am I glad I bought it? Not really. Is it bad enough to send back? Not really. Will I put it to good use? Sure. Would I recommend it? I would probably tell someone to wait for another device to come out. If the Blackberry Playbook had an expansion slot, I would get that instead (got one and returned it because I needed more space).

tablet_galaxy_tab|Although it is advertised for the Galaxy Tab 2 7.0, it was never made for it. There is no access to the headphone jack....so you have to cut a hole in the case to use them. The sensor that monitors ambient light is covered by the case, so no auto control for the display. As such, you have to cut a chunk out of the case. The IR port is covered by the case....you guessed it, cut another hole in the case for the IR sensor to work. There is no access hole in the case for the camera lens....so you can't take a photo without removing it from the case....or cut another hole in the case. Basically, this is a piece of junk repackaged for use on a model it was never intended for.

tablet_galaxy_tab|The true storage of this device is 4.59 GB. It is NOT expandable via SD card. The device does not allow access to the SD card. All apps, games, etc. download automatically to the internal storage and this is limited to 4.5 usable GB. Check the Samsung and Android forums to confirm this. Some apps require up to 2 GB alone. If you require more than 4.5 GB total storage, do NOT purchase this device.

tablet_galaxy_tab|Reviewing Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 (7inch wi-fi) 8gbMarketing seems to be legalized lying for the most part so I approach every purchase as a 6 month learning lesson ignoring all the marketing hypes and reading 'real' reviews from Amazon and other forums before trying a product out.My two-cents:The 7" tablets are a nice fit for the hand. I chose the Galaxy over Kindle Fire because I wanted to use Skype (ICS). Though the Galaxy allows Skype audible, the video function would not work. I was able to view my friend, but once I tried to activate my video cam the call ended. We tried several times before accepting the fact Skype (for ICS) and Galaxy will be fine for talking but no video as hoped by me and hyped by Samsung.Though Samsung's Marketing Team chose to list the tablet as 8GB, they failed to state the fact that you only get to play with around 3.7GB. The RAM is also around half...generally the RAM read 3xx/6xx (can't remember exact#). I took that to mean 3xx is being currently used out of 6xx available.There's a slot for up to 32GB chip, which sold me on it. But when I tried to use a 2GB SD micro chip, which I already had for my Sansa mp3 player, the camera on the samsung unit could only be viewed UPSIDE DOWN....turning tablet upside down only flipped the viewing so it was always upside down. I didn't keep the unit long enough to find out what other buggy stuff could happen as I was very discouraged at this point.Amazon's Marketing for Kindle Fire was upfront stating the 8GB model has 6GB usable.If only Kindle Fire 7" had skyping capabilities...even if video didn't work, I'd buy it.To be fair to Samsung, I liked the look and feel, and the price allured me...but in the end you have to be able to use the features it boasts and trust the company behind it to be honest with you in order to appreciate a product. Samsung, please list the info the end user needs to know, otherwise it's deceptive.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I'm posting here because Samsung refused my post telling the truth. In short I purchased this for my daughter only to find out the truth about this product. I was truly impressed the first few days of use as she was able to download and use apps rather easily. However, to make a long story short, as I found out, the 8gb of HD space is far less than they advertise. Most OS on devices will take up between 1 - 2 gb which is normal, however on this device Netflix was part of the design team for the ICS OS and their software alone takes up 4.19 gb of hd space?!?!? Really??? Why not just give the consumer the ability to download the app. After you take into account ICS OS and Samsungs proprietary apps (which I have no issue with), you basically have approx 2gb of hd space. This limits the amount of apps that can be placed on the HD. That's not all, you cannot manage your photos, videos or music between the device and the expandable card slot. You have to connect the tab to your computer and manage the expandable disc space. This defeats the purpose of a tablet. Tablet's were made to free you from accessing a computer. Therefore buyer please be aware of what you are purchasing.
---

It's going back tomorrow.Jan 27, 2013 Follow up: I have purchased a Nexus 7, 16 gig tablet for the same amount of money I paid for the Samsung galaxy 2.7. So far the Nexus is superior in every way that I have used it compared to the Samsung Galaxy. The Nexus has better WiFi capabilities, a much more responsive screen, and it anticipates what I need to do and is always ready and able to accomplish what I wish it to do; and does it in such a capable way that it brings a smile to my face and appreciation for its intuitiveness. I cannot say that for the Galaxy 2.7. I would urge anyone that is considering buying a 7 inch tablet to avoid the Galaxy 2.7 and instead purchase the Nexus 7.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I bought this for my wife to use as HER dedicated media consumption device. I did considerable research on the newer, state-of-the-art 7 inch tablets. The new 7" Ipad is a lot more expensive, and Apple's closed system tyranny and draconian forced-obsolescence-by-sneaky-forced-upgrades-that-screw-things-up pisses me off, so I focused on Android tablets.- We also have a Kindle Fire that she also reads her magazines on, but that is also used by the kids for reading their school books. Since the Kindle Fire is also based on an Android OS and there is no problem accessing her magazines on it, I never considered that there might be a problem getting the magazines on a new tablet.I chose the Samsung 7" Galaxy Tab2 because, of all the 7" Android tablets, only this Samsung device provided for memory expansion.I am saddened because the 7" Tab-2 is a beautiful device, and it seems to work well for a lot of purposes, but to my horror, it is not possible to load any of my wife's favorite magazines (including Allure, InStyle, and a number of cooking magazines.) Some of these magazines are in fact available for purchase from the Samsung's magazine aggregator of choice, but they would require that my wife repurchase all of the subscriptions she already owns (they don't have a way to port over existing subscriptions, apparently). Repurchasing all of these subscriptions would more than double the price of the tablet itself.Perhaps it is not entirely the fault of this tablet, so I will concede that the one-star rating may be somewhat harsh. But I am pissed off that Samsung, Google, Amazon, Zinio, and the like, seem to be more interested in building their own fiefdoms and locking consumers into their own proprietary markets.This is not the "open" environment I was led to expect. Companies please take note: Holding your customers hostage is not a good long-term strategy!

tablet_galaxy_tab|UPDATE May 2012: I have lowered the rating down to one star. I purchased this tablet to watch movies and stream video but it simply doesn't work, probably because the processor is vastly underpowered. I suggest getting a more powerful 5" phone instead of this paperweight.Here is a list of what works and what doesn't on this new Samsung Tablet 2:1) Bluetooth Audio = Hard to pair to headphones. Often the bluetooth devices don't register, however, once paired, the signal is strong. Skill level required: above average.2) Bluetooth File Sharing = No two way file transfer with Macintosh. One way only.3) HBOgo App = Is not yet available for Android.4) Flash Video Playback = Random results, sometimes it works sometimes if does not.5) YouTube = Works fine.6) Samsung USB Adapter = Reads SD card files and can delete files. Very hard to transfer files. Skill level required: high.7) 1080p High Definition video playback = often no audio, skips frames or crashes on all Android video players that I tested. The processor can't handle HD Video and sometimes not even SD video.8) Audio Volume = Excellent. The best of all tablets on the Market.9) TwitTV Apps = No Video. Some video podcasts exhibit audio synch problems.7) Peel Smart Remote = Good luck getting this one to work, I am an expert and it took me 15 tries to figure it out. Also it requires a permanent Wi-Fi connection, no Wi-Fi, no workie. When it does work it does a nice job except for the slow volume control.8) Nice battery life if you turn off the GPS and adjust Wi-Fi setting to "off" while at sleep. GPS is "on" be default.9) Screen is not sharp but most people won't notice the difference or care if they do. Acceptable for movies of medium resolution which is all it can play anyway.10) Wi-Fi seems to work fine, have not tested for distance.11) Camera quality is very mediocre, who cares, right. Video is noisy.Software review: the new Android Ice Cream Sandwich software that runs at the core of the Galaxy Tab is still marred by Google's inept programmers, you know what I mean, the pseudo-interface that get worse with every new version? Add to that the buggy software available in the Android Market and you get an overall unfriendly experience, still a potpourri of random hangs and crashes. Doesn't look like Google cares nor is capable of creating a friendly interface, too bad because it is Ice Cream Sandwich which really ruins the Samsung Tablet experience.Conclusion: The "Galaxy Tab 2" sacrificed some key components in order to sale this tablet for $250 and it shows, the processor is underpowered, to make matters worse, Ice Cream Sandwich is still confusing and cumbersome for the average consumer. As much as I like to recommend this form factor my final recommendation is to hold off a few more months, Apple will soon release the next generation of 7" tablets for about the same price and so is Microsoft, yes, Windows tablets are supposed to be solid contenders.More free advice: Amazon reviews of 5 stars are almost always fake and can be safely ignored, I suggest reading the 3-2-1 star reviews for a less biased experience before you buy.
---

tablet_galaxy_tab|I purchased this tablet back in April of 2012 with my cellular carrier on a data plan. My original reasoning was as an alternative to the more expensive tablet options out there. I made a mistake. I should have paid more for a better tablet experience. The battery life for this device is miserable. I often find myself having to charge it twice a day with really heavy use. But the worst reason for the device is the total lack of knowledgeable tech support from Samsung. I had an issue with the device trying to do a system update and failing multiple times. After a calling my cellular tech support, who then transferred me to Samsung, they were unable to provide any help with the issue. An hour later, Samsung threw up their hands and blamed it on my cellular carrier. Needless to say, the "system update" comes from Samsung, and that is what was not working. Bottom line? Don't purchase this device as a cheaper alternative. You won't be happy.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I knew within 10 minutes of buying this device that it was getting returned. The browser is s-l-o-w... It took 8 seconds from the time I tapped a webpage until it actually started loading, then another 4-5 seconds before the page was rendered. (Comparison -- on my iPad3, the page is rendered before my finger even gets out of the way of the screen.) Even getting a 'new tab' screen takes 3-4 seconds to be ready to browse. Then, with only 4 pages active, the browser crashed. The TV Remote app seemed like a cool feature, but it worked poorly--missing numbers when changing TV channel, despite pointing the IR blaster right at the TV.I actually liked the Android 4.0 ICS interface and the LCD is really great, but the underlying operating system here seems to be garbage. Maybe the tablet did not have enough RAM also. The device seemed to struggle a lot, and the UI hitches a lot, even with only 2 or 3 active applications. I made sure to check that I had the latest software, which I did. It's just disappointing.

tablet_galaxy_tab|I have the original Galaxy 7 wi-fi version, not this newer version. But mine was new once as well, so let this be a caveat to all who consider buying a wifi tab.I admit that I totally love this toy, and it would be the best electronic gadget I have ever owned -- except Samsung's dismal service and support completely suck the joy out of it. Unless you own the top of the line product and are signed up for the most extortionate data plan you can find, Samsung's attitude is "thanks for the money, now F off."Here are a couple of things you should be ready for:1. The included software will not work with your device. Not "will be hard to figure out" -- you will get an error message saying "this device is not supported." They could have just put a message that said "F You, Chump! &lt;click OK>". Also, the software [Kies]it will take 15 minutes to install, probably crash several times, and blow up every file association on your computer, making recovering from being told you can't use their software into a nightmare.2. Want a software update? Try CyanogenMod. You'll have to root it to get one. Fortunately, their sloppy workmanship also makes it fairly easy to do this.3. The battery will crap out in under 6 months. Fortunately also, since they don't bother to seal the body with anything you can pop the thing open with a wine key and fix this yourself. No! Wait! You'll HAVE to fix it yourself, since you'll get no help from them. They'll refuse to just sell you a battery and will charge as much as a new one to fix it for you.4. The hardware inside this tab is nearly identical to the hardware in a Barnes and Noble Nook Color, which is $100 less. Samsung does not tell you this, deliberately misleading you into thinking it will be the same as the version they actually care about.In short, unless you're into rooting and tinkering, this toy will only be fun as long as it still has new toy smell. As soon as real ownership kicks in, you'll just get thrown under the bus.

Apparently all Honeycomb and ICS devices do.Cant use extSDcard for anything but the music and videos, which is pretty retarded....whomever said 5GB (about 3GB goes for the OS) is enough for apps is clearly mistaken.Fifa12 need 1.6GB... which is downloaded to /sdcard aka internal storage.... with on option to select /extSdCardGTA3 need 500GB ... which again goes to /sdcard.... there goes 2GB just in 2 games...pretty much anything that writes data to /sdcard, which are ALL the apps and games out there... will have to be squeezed into the 5GB available space in the SGT2.... tablet_galaxy_tab|I own a Kindle Fire, and haven't had it long enough to be a dedicated fanboy. I AM an apple fanboy...now. I've always wanted an iPad and was saving up for a "the new iPad", but I can't spend that much on a tablet right now. So When I saw the Galaxy Tab 2 7" I got really excited. Finally a full fledged tablet at the right size at the right price, with awesome specs. I could return my Kindle Fire and get a machine without compromise...or so I thought.I used to have an Android Galaxy S phone, but switched to the iPhone because I was tired of all my phone's random glitches and crashes. An example was being told I was in Sweden while I was in Tyler, Texas. My wife made fun of me because I used to gripe non-stop about how much I hated my Android phone, vowed to never get another one, and yet was drooling over the new Samsung Galaxy Tab 2. I called to every local dealer till I found one who would sell it on saturday (the day before official release).Right out of the box I loved it. The screen was great, the smooth bezel and perfect size, the expandable data capability, and the control bar, which is one of my favorite features on the device, made everything so much easier. I could put icons and widgets wherever I wanted to. I had full access to the google play store. That's where the benefits started to fall off. I bought the Kindle Fire to read, surf the web, manage documents and have something for my 5 year old to play on, it worked great for all those things, but it's very limited by the Amazon Android shell. OH, and the speakers worked way, WAY better on the Galaxy Tab 2 than the Kindle Fire's anemic speakers.All that being said, the Galaxy Tab 2 wouldn't/couldn't sync up to my Mac, MAJOR issue for me, I absolutely hate windows os. I tried installing the android software meant to assist with data transfer for macs directly from the Android website, to continually get a, "please connect device to initiate file transfer" (paraphrase) message. To transfer files I could only use dropbox, which ultimately is a slow and somewhat painful replacement for direct file transfer. Strike 1.There were serious formating issues with my ebooks when I finally managed to get them to the Galaxy Tab 2. I purchased and set up a handful of top rated ereader programs from google play, moon+reader ($4.99), aldiko (free), the Kindle app and a couple others. Paragraphs were separated by several lines of blank spacing, and the paragraphs were cut in odd locations not waiting for the actual end of the paragraph. I used epub and mobi formats to no avail. Calibre was also not able to be called on for assistance since my computer couldn't recognize the Galaxy Tab. Strike 2.A smaller, yet still frustrating issue, probably fixable with a different browser program, is something I'd come to respect abou the Kindle Fire. On the Kindle Fire, when viewing text on a website, I could zoom in on the text and it would be reformated to fit my page. This made it so I wouldn't have to scroll around, thus easier to read. The Galaxy Pad did not have this feature and I was scrolling constantly when surfing. As I said minor issue, but still. Strike 3.Then I couldn't get any of the Amazon HD apps to run on the Galaxy Tab 2, more of an Amazon issue really, but I didn't want to be forced to purchase all the same apps over again, expensive and a major hastle. Strike 4.The reason I got rid of the Samsung phone was because it was glitchy and wouldn't work. I got rid of this for the same reason. I love my iPhone, it simply just works, and works really well. I started having PTSD when the Galaxy Tab started to throw problems at me and decided I would go back to the Kindle Fire, like my iPhone, it just simply, works. The Kindle doesn't do half the things I wanted to get the Galaxy Tab 2 for, but it works really well for the main reasons I wanted it. I'll get over the stuff I'll lose.I know these aren't necessarily strong reasons not to get it. As I said there are a lot of benefits to using the Galaxy Tab 2, but it does not in any way replace a Kindle Fire if you are an avid reader, or if you're a mac user.
